div.p: AN ESSAY Of the Great EFFECTS OF Even Languid and Unheeded MOTION. Whereunto is Annexed An Experimental Dicoure of ome little oberved Caues of the Inalubrity and Salubrity of the Air and its Effects.
By the Honourable ROBERT BOYLE, Fellow of the Royal Society.
LONDON, Printed by M. Fleher, for Richard Davis, Bookeller in Oxford. 1685.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT OF THE Publiher.
div.p:
TIS thought fit the Reader hould be inform'd, That the inuing Tract (about the Effects of Languid Motions) was deign'd to be a Part of the Authour's Notes about the Origine of Occult Qualities,
and hould have come abroad together with the Papers about the Effluvia of Bodies (mot of which are already publih'd.) And accordingly it was printed even or eight years ago: which Circumtance is here mention'd, to give a Reaon why everal Particulars were omitted in the Body of the Dicoure, that will be found annex'd to the End of it. For thee occurring to the Authour whilt he curorily read over the Tract it elf, when
it was upon the point to be made publick, 'twas thought fit rather to ubjoin them by way of a hort Appendix, than to let any thing be lot that eem'd pertinent to o difficult and uncultivated a Subject, as That they belong to. The Reader is farther to be advertis'd, That of the Three Preliminary Dicoures, which the Authour intended for Introductory Ones to What he deign'd to ay more particularly about the Mechanical Origine or
Production of Occult Qualities, One was concerning the Relations betwixt the Pores of Bodies and the Figures of Corpucles: but that the great Intrieacy and Difficulty He found in this copious Subject, made Him conent, That the Dicoure of Local Motion, which hould have accompany'd it to the Pres, hould be printed long before it. And thoe Papers about Pores and Figures having been for a great while out
of the Authour's Power, He now to gratify the Stationer with omething that may in Their tead make up the formerly printed Eay a Book of a convenient Bulk, has put into his Hands what now comes forth, about ome Unheeded Caues of the Healthfulnes and Inalubrity of the Air: which being chiefly attributed to Subterraneal Steams, Subtile and for the mot part Inviible, are as near of kin to the other Effluviums treated of in the Introductory
Dicoure, as is requiite to keep the mention that is made of them in this Book, from appearing very incongruous.

body.head: AN ESSAY Of the Great EFFECTS Of Even Languid and nheeded LOCAL MOTION.

div.head: CHAP. I.
div.p:
HOW uperficially oever the Local Motion of Bodies is wont to be treated of by the Schools, who admit of divers other Motions, and acribe almot all trange things in Phyicks to Subtantial Forms and Real Qualities; yet it will become Us, who endeavour to reolve the Phaenomena of Nature into Matter
and Local motion, (guided, at the beginning of things, immediately, and ince regulated, according to ettled Laws, by the Great and Wie Author of the Univere,) to take a heedfull notice of its kinds and operations, as the true Caues of many abtrue Effects. And though the indutry of divers late Mathematicians and Philoophers have been very laudably and happily exercied on the nature and general Laws of this Motion; yet I look upon the Subject in its full extent to be of uch importance, and o comprehenive, that it can never be too much cultivated, and that it compries ome parts that are yet carce cultivated at all. And therefore I am not orry to find my elf obliged, by the deign of thee Notes, (written, as you know, to facilitate the explicating of Occult Qualities) to endeavour to improve ome neglected Corners of this vat field, and to conider, Whether, beides thoe effects of Local motion which are more conpicuous, as being produced by the
manifet triking of one body againt another, where the bulk, &c. of the Agent, together with its Celerity, have the chief Interet; there may not be divers effects, wont to be attributed to Occult Qualities, that yet are really produced by faint or unheeded Local motions of bodies againt one another, and that oftentimes at a ditance.

But, before I enter upon particulars, this I mut premie in general, (which I have elewhere had occaion to note to other purpoes,) that we are not to look upon the bodies we are converant with, as o many Lumps of Matter, that differ onely in bulk and hape, or that act upon one another merely by their own ditinct and particular powers; but rather as bodies of peculiar and differing internal Textures, as well as external Figures: on the account of which tructures, many of them mut be conidered as a kind of Engines, that are both o framed and o placed among other bodies, that ometimes Agents, otherwie invalid,
may have notable operations upon them, becaue thoe operations being furthered by the Mechanim of the body wrought on, and the relation which other bodies and Phyiical Caues have to it, a great part of the effect is due, not preciely to the external Agent, that 'tis wont to be acribed to, but in great meaure to the action of one part of the body it elf (that is wrought on) upon another, and aited by the concurring action of the neighbouring bodies, and perhaps of ome of the more Catholick Agents of Nature. This Notion or Conideration being in other Papers particularly confirmed, I hall not now init upon it, truting that you will not forget it, when there hall be occaion to apply it in the following Notes.

There may be more Accounts than we have yet thought of, upon which Local motions may perform coniderable things, either without being much heeded, or without eeming other then faint, at leat in relation to
the coniderablenes of the Effects produced by them. And therefore I would not be undertood in an excluive ene, when in the following Dicoure I take notice but of a few of the above-mentioned Accounts; thee eeming ufficient, whereto, as to Heads, may be conveniently enough referred the Intances I allot to this Tract.

And concerning each of thee Accounts, I hold it requiite to intimate in this place, that I mention it onely, as that whereon uch effects of Local motion, as I refer to it, do principally depend: for, otherwie, I am o far from denying, that I aert, that in divers caes there are more Caues than one, or perhaps than two of thoe here treated of apart, that may notably concur to Phaenomena directly referred to but one or other of them.

To come then cloer to our ubject; I hall take notice, That among the everall things, upon whoe account men are wont to overlook or undervalue
the efficacy of Local motions, that are either Unheeded or thought Languid, the chief, or at leat thoe that eem to me fittet to be treated of in this Paper, are thoe that are referable to the following Obervations.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Obervat. I. Men are not uually aware of the great efficacy of Celerity, even in mall Bodies, and epecially if they move but through a mall pace.

div.p:
WHat a rapid Motion may enable a Body to doe, may be judged by the powerfull and detructive Effects of Bullets hot out of Cannons, in comparion of the Battering Engines of the Ancients, which, though I know not how many times bigger then the Bullets of whole Cannon, were not able to batter down Walls and Towers like Bullets, whoe bulk compared with theirs is inconiderable. Other examples
of a like nature might be without impertinency alledged on this occaion; but, becaue the latter part of our Propoition contains that which I chiefly aim at, I hall proceed to Intances fit to prove That.

I have ometimes caued a skilfull Turner to turn for me an oblong piece of Iron or Steel, and placing my naked hand at a convenient ditance to receive the little fragments, perhaps for the mot part leer then mall pins heads, as they flew off from the rod, they were, as I expected, o intenely heated by the quick action of the Tool upon them, that they eemed almot like o many parks of fire; o that I could not endure to continue my hand there. And I remember, that once asking an expert workman, whether he (as I had ometimes done) did not find a troubleome heat in the little fragments of Bras that were thrown off when that metall was turning? He told me, that heat was ometimes very offenive to his eyes and eye-lids. And
when I asked, whether it was not rather as Dut cat into them, than from their Heat; he replied, that beides the troke, he could enibly feel a troubleome heat, which would make even his Eye-lids ore: And that ometimes, when he employed a rough Tool, that took off omewhat greater Chips, he had found the heat o vehement, that not onely 'twould corch his tender Eye-lids, but the thick and hard skin of his hands: for proof whereof he hewed me in one of his hands a little bliter, that had been o raied, and was not yet quite gone off.

And inquiring about thee matters of a famous Artit, imployed about the finihing up of cat Ordnance, he confes'd to me, That, when with a trong as well as peculiar Engine he and his aociates turned great Guns very wiftly, to bring the urface to a competent moothnes, the tools would ometimes throw off bits of metal of a coniderable bignes, which, by reaon of their bulk and their rapid motion, would be o heated as to burn
the fingers of the Country-people that came to gaze on his work, when he, for merriment ake, deired them to take up ome of thoe pieces of metall from the ground. Which I thought the more remarkable, becaue by the Contact and Coldnes of the ground I could not but uppoe their Heat to have been much allayed. Not to mention, that I learnt from an experienced Artificer, that in turning of Bras the little fragments of that metall acquire an intener Heat than thoe of Iron.

I remember alo, that, to vary the Experiment mentioned jut before this lat, by making it with a bodie far les olid and heavy than Bras or Iron, I caued an Artificer to turn very nimbly a piece of ordinary wood, and holding my hand not far off, the powder, that flew about upon the operation, truck my hand in many places with that brisknes, that I could but uneaily endure the Heat which they produced where they hit. Which Heat whether it were communicated
from the little, but much heated, fragments to my hands, or produced there by the brisk percuion on my hand, or were the joint effect of both thoe Caues; it will however be a good Intance of the power of Celerity even in very mall bodies, and that move but a very little way.

'Tis coniderable to our preent purpoe, that by an almot momentany percuion, and that made with no great force, the parts, even of a vegetable, may be not onely intenely heated, but brought to an actuall Ignition; as we have everall times tried, by triking a good Cane (of that ort which is fit for uch Experiments) with a teel, or even with the back of a knife. For, upon this Colliion, it would end forth parks of fire like a flint.

To the ame purpoe may be alledged, that, by but dextrouly craping good loaf-ugar with a knife, there will be made o brisk an agitation of the parts, that tore of parks
will be produced. But that is more coniderable, which happens upon the colliion of a flint and a teel: For, though Vitrification be by Chymits eteemed the ultimate action of the fire, and though, to turn and or tones, though very finely poudered, into glas, 'tis uually required that it be kept for divers hours in the intene fire of a glas-houe; and though, latly, the glas-men complain, that they cannot bring flints or and to fuion without the help of a good proportion of Borillia or ome other fixed alt: yet both actuall Ignition and Vitrification are brought to pas almot in a moment by the bare vehemence of that motion that is excited in the parts of a flint when it is truck with a teel: For thoe parks that then fly out, (as an Ingenious peronMr. Hooke has oberved, and as I have often een with a good Microcope,) are uually real and permanent parcels (for the mot part globulous) oftone vitrified and ignited by the vehemence of the motion. And that
this vitrification may be of the tone itelf, though teel be a metal of a far more fuible nature then a flint, I am induced to think, becaue I have tried, that not only flints with teel, but flints with flints, and more eaily pieces of Rock Crytal between themelves, will by colliion trike fire. And the like effect of colliion I have found my elf in ome precious tones, harder than Crytall. And afterwards inquiring of an ingenious Artificer that cuts Diamonds, Whether he had not oberved the like, when Diamonds were grated on by the rapid motion of his mill? He replied, that he oberved Diamonds to trike fire almot like Flints; which afterwards was confirmed to me by another experienced cutter of Gems; and yet having made divers trials on Diamonds with fire, he would not allow that fire itelf can bring them to fuion.

Nor are fluid Bodies, though but of mall Dimenions, to be altogether excluded from the power of making coniderable impreions on olid
bodies, if their celerity be great.

Whether the Sun-beams conit, according to the Atomical Doctrine, of very minute Corpucles, that, continually iuing out of the body of the Sun, wiftly thrut on one another in Phyically-traight Lines; or whether, as the Carteians would have it, thoe beams be made by the brisk action of the Luminary upon the contiguous fluid, and propagated every way in traight lines through ome Ethereal matter harboured in the pores of the Air; it will be agreeable to either Hypotheis, that the Sunbeams, refracted or reflected by a burning-glas to a focus, do there, by their concoure, compoe a mall portion of fluid matter; and yet the Celerity, wherewith the oft and yielding ubtance is agitated, enables o few of them as can be circumcribed by a Circle, not a quarter of an inch in Diameter, to et afire green wood in lee than a minute, and (perhaps in as little time as that) to melt not onely Tinn and Lead thinly
beaten, but, as I have tried, foliated Silver and Gold.

The operation of mall portions of fluid matter on olid bodies will be farther exemplified in the IV. Chapter, by the effects of the blown flame of a Lamp on glas and metalls; o that I hall here need but to point in general at the wonderfull effects that Lightning has produced, as well by the Celerity of its motion, as by the matter whereof it conits. Of which Effects, Hitories and the writings of Meteorologits afford good tore; and I have been an admiring oberver of ome of them, one of the lat of which was the melting of metal by the flame in its paage, which probably lated but the twinckling of an Eye.

And even a mall parcel of Air, if put into a ufficiently-brisk motion, may communicate a coniderable motion to a olid body; whereof a notable Intance (which depends chiefly upon the Celerity of the pringy corpucles of the Air) is afforded
by the violent motion communicated to a bullet hot out of a good wind-gun. For, when this Intrument is well charged, the trongly-compret Air being et at liberty, and forcibly endeavouring to expand it elf to its wonted laxity, its corpucles give a multitude of impules to the bullet, all the while that it continues moving along the barrel, and by this means put it into o rapid a motion, that I found by trial, the bullet would in a moment be flatted, almot into the figure of a Hemiphere, by being hot off againt a metalline plate.

And farther to hew, How wift that motion mut have been, and with what Celerity a vehement agitation may be communicated to the parts of a Solid body, I hall add here (though the Phaenomenon might be referred to the V. Chapter,) that, though the contact of the Bullet and the metalline plate lated probably but a phyical moment; yet the minute parts of the bullet were put into o various and brisk an agitation, that making hat
to take it up before it hould cool, I found it too hot to be with overmuch eae held between my fingers.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Obervat. II. We are too apt to think, that Fluid bodies, becaue of their oftnes, cannot have by their bare motion, epecially if inenible, any enible effect upon Solid ones; though the fluid moves and acts as an intire body.

div.p:
'TIS not my purpoe here to init on the efficacy of the motion of uch fluid bodies as may have their motions dicovered by the eye, like treaming water; or manifetly perceived by the touch, as are the winds that beat upon us: ince 'twere needles to give Intances of uch obvious things, as the great effects of overflowing waters and violent winds; the later of which, notwithtanding the great tenuity and
oftnes of the air and the Effluvia that wim in it, have been ometimes able to blow down not onely timbertrees, but houes and teeples, and other the firmet Structures. But the motions I intend to peak of in this Chapter are uch, as we do not immediately either ee or feel; and though thee be exceeding rare, yet the operation of Sounds, even upon olid bodies, and that at a ditance from the onorous ones, afford me ome Intances to my preent purpoe, which I hall now proceed to mention.

It has been frequently oberved, that, upon the dicharge of Ordnance and other great Guns, not onely the ound may be ditinctly heard a great way off; but that, to a good ditance, the tremulous motion of the Air that produces ound, without producing any enible wind, has been able enibly to hake, and ometimes violently to break, the glas-windows of houes and other buildings, epecially when the windows tand in the way
wherein the propagation of the ound is directly made. 'Tis true, that thee obervations are mot frequent, when the place, where the Artillery is placed, tands upon the ame piece of ground with the Houes whoe windows are haken; and o it may be upected, that the Shake is firt communicated by the Cannon to the earth or floor on which they play, and is afterwards by that propagated through the intermediate parts of the ground to the foundations of the houes, and o to the windows. And I readily grant, and may elewhere hew, that a violent impule upon the ground may reach to a greater ditance than men uually imagine: But in our preent Cae I ee no neceity of having recoure to any thing but the wave-like motion of the Air for the production of our Phaenomenon, ince the like may be produced by Local Motion tranmitted by Fluids, as may appear by the following Intances.

I was once invited by an Engineer,
to ee triall made of a trange Intrument he had to ink hips, though great ones, in a few minutes; and though an unlucky Accident kept me from arriving there 'till near a quarter of an hour after the triall had been made on an old fregat, with better uccee than my Philanthropy allowed me to wih; yet cauing my elf to be rowed to the place, where the great veell was newly unk, the odnes of the effect, which was performed upon the water by a mall Intrument outwardly applied, made me inquiitive, what noie and commotion had been made: And I was informed partly by the Engineer himelf, and partly by ome acquaintances of mine, who among a great number of Spectators tood aloof off in hips and other veels lying at anchor, to ee the event; that, upon the Engine's operating, the exploion was o great, that it made a kind of torm in the water round about, and did o rudely hake veels that lay at no inconiderable ditance, as to make
thoe that tood on them to tagger.

In the late great Sea-fight between the Englih Fleet commanded by his Royal Highnes the Duke of York, and the Dutch Admiral Opdam, (who therein lot the Victory and his Life,) though the Engagement were made very many Leagues from the Hague, yet the noie of the Guns not onely reached to that Place, but had a notable effect there; of which when I enquired of the Englih Embaadour that as yet reided there, he was pleaed to aure me, that it hook the windows of his Houe o violently, that not knowing what the Caue was, he was urprized and much allarmed, apprehending, that ome rude Fellows were about to break his windows to affront him. And if there be a greater dipoition in ome other bodies than there is in Glas-windows to receive trong impules from the Air agitated by Sounds, thee may be enibly, though not viibly, wrought upon, and that at a good ditance, by the noie of a ingle
piece of Ordnance; as may appear by that memorable Circumtance of an odd Cae about a Gangrene mentioned by the experienced Simon Pauli in his ingenious Tract de Febribus malignis, pag. 71. Atqui aeger ille Gallus brachio truncatus, octiduum quidem uperfuit, ed horrendis totius corporis convulionibus correptus; qui quoque, (ut & illa addam obervatione digniima,) dum in Domini ui aedibus ad plateam Kiodmoggerianam, Romanè Laniorum appellares, decumberet, ac, me ac aliis aliquandiu ad Lectum illius conidentibus quidem, ed nobis non attendentibus, exploderentur tormenta bellica ex Regiis ac Praetoriis navibus, initrâ truncum dextri brachii fovens ac complectens, toties quoties exploderentur ingula exclamabat, Au, au, me mierum! Jeu, Maria, contundor penitús: adeò permoleta & intolerabilis illi erat Tormentorum exploio, & quidem ex loco atis longinquo, terrâ non firmâ aut contiguâ, verùm uper alo aut mari Balthico, intituta. By this it appears, that the Guns, whoe dicharge produced
thee painfull motions in the Patient, reted upon a floating body. And I remember, that an illutrious Commander of a very great Man of war, being asked by me, whether of the many wounded men, he had in his hip in a very long Sea-fight, none of them were affected by that noie of the Enemy's Cannon dicharged in hips at a ditance? He anwered me, that ome, whoe bones were broken, would adly complain of the Torment they were put into by the hake they felt at the going off of the Enemy's Cannon, though they were too much accutomed to the report of great Guns, to be, as 'twas a bare noie, offended by it. If after all this ti be urmized, that thee motions were not conveyed by the air, but propagated by the water, (and, in ome caes, ome part of the hoar) from the hips, where the Guns were fired, to the Houes where the windows were haken, or the places where the wounded men lay: I anwer that, if this could be made probable,
it would accommodate me with very eminent Intances for the Chapter of the Propagable nature of Motion: And though it be very difficult to find uch examples of hakes excited by ounds as are not liable to the mentioned objection; becaue the onorous bodies here below do all either trike, or lean, upon uch gros and viible bodies as the Earth and Water; yet there is one kind of Sound, that mut be confeed to be propagated by the Air, as being made in it; and that is Thunder, whoe noie does ometimes o vehemently affect the Air, though without producing any enible wind, that both others and I have oberved it very enibly to hake great and trong Houes, notwithtanding the ditance of the clouds where the noies were firt produced. And I remember, that, having inquired of ome Sea-Captains, that in tout veels ailed to the Indies, whether they had nor in thoe hot Regions oberved their hips, though very much les tall then
houes, to be haken by vehement Thunders? I perceived, that ome of them had not much heeded any uch thing; but a couple of others told me, they had oberved it in their hips; and one of them told me, that once, when the claps of thunder were extraordinary great, ome of them hook his hip o rudely as to make the unwonted motions diorder his great Guns. All which I the les wonder at, when calling to mind, what I have mention'd in the foregoing Chapter and elewhere of the power of the Celerity of motion, I conider, that there is no Celerity that we know of here below, that is near o great, as that wherewith a Sound is propagated through the air. For, whereas the diligent Merennus oberves, that a bullet hot out of a Cannon or a Musket does not overpas two hundred and forty yards in a Second, or ixtieth part of a minute; I have more than once diligently oberved, that the motion of Sound paes above four hundred yards in the
ame time of a Second here in England; which I therefore add, becaue Merennus relates, that in France he oberved a Sound to move in that time many yards more; which may poibly proceed from the differing conitence of the Englih air and the French.

The great Loudnes of thee ounds, and the vehement percuion that the Air receives in their formation, will probably make it be eaily granted, that 'twas onely the Impetuoity of the motion of the Medium, that gave the hake to the windows and other olid bodies that I have been mentioning to have been made to tremble by the report of Cannon or Thunder: But yet I will not on this occaion conceal, that perhaps it may without aburdity be upected, that Some of thoe tremulous motions of olid bodies might either depend upon, or at leat be promoted by, ome peculiar dipoition, that Glae (which is endued with pringines,) and ome other bodies that perhaps are not quite devoid of that Quality,
may have to be moved by certain congruous Sounds (if I may o call them) more than they would by others, though perchance more loud. But though this urmize hould be admitted; yet it would not render the lately-recited Intances improper for the deign of this Dicoure, but onely would make ome of them fit to be referred to another Chapter; to which I hall advance, as oon as I hall have annexed an odd Obervation of the experienced Platerus, which argues, that, where there is a peculiar Dipoition, even in a firm body, it may receive coniderable impreions from o languid a motion (though in likelihood not peculiarly modified) of the air as is not enible to other bodies of the ame kind.

Foemina quaedam (ays he)Plater. Oberv. Lib. 1. p. 185. in ubitaneum incidit morbum, viribus ubitò protratis, e uffocari indeinenter clamitans, eti neo tertoris nec tuis aliqua eent indicia; maximè verò de aura quadam adveniente, i vel leviter aliquis adtantium e
moveret, quae illam opprimeret, conquerebatur, éque uffocari, i quis propiùs accederet, clamitabat: vixdum biduum in ea anxietate pereverans, expiravit. To which he adds: Vidi & alios aegros, de imili aura, quae eos, i quis illis appropinquaret, in uffocationis periculum induceret, conquerentes; quod emper peimum ee ignum deprehendi.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: Obervat. III. Men undervalue the motions of bodies too mall to be viible or enible, notwithtanding their Numerounes, which inables them to act in Swarms.

div.p:
MOt men, when they think at all of the effluvia of bodies and their motions, are wont to think of them as if they were but much finer orts of Dut, (whoe grains, by reaon of their malnes, are inviible,) which, by the various agitation of the Air, are
as 'twere by ome faint wind blown againt the urfaces of the bodies they chance to meet in their way, and that they are topped in their progres without penetrating into the interior parts of the bodies they invade. And according to this Notion, 'tis no wonder, that men hould not fancy, that uch minute bodies paing, as they uppoe, no further than the urfaces of thoe on which they operate, hould have but faint operations upon them.

But we may have other thoughts, if we well conider, that the Corpucles we peak of, are, by their minutenes, aited, and oftentimes by their figure inabled, to pierce into the innermot recees of the body they invade, and ditribute themelves to all, or at leat to multitudes of the minute parts, whereof that body conits. For this being granted, though we uppoe each ingle effluvium or particle to be very minute; yet, ince we may uppoe, even olid bodies to be made up of particles that are o too, and the number of invading particles
to be not much inferior to that of the invaded ones, or at leat to be exceedingly great, it need not eem incredible, that a multitude of little Corpucles in motion (whoe motion, may, for ought we know, be very wift) hould be able to have a coniderable operation upon particles either quiecent, or that have a motion too low to be perceptible by ene. Which may perhaps be the better conceived by the help of this gros example:

If you turn an Ant-hill well tocked with Ants-eggs, upide down, you may ometimes ee uch a heap of eggs mingled with the looe earth, as a few of thoe Inects, if they were yoaked together, would not be able at once to draw after them; but if good numbers of them dipere themelves and range up and down, and each lay hold of her own egge, and hurry it away, 'tis omewhat urprizing to ee (as I have with pleaure done) how quickly the heap of eggs will be diplaced, when almot every little egge has
one of thoe little Inects to deal with it.

And in thoe caes, wherein the invading Fluid does not quite disjoin and carry off any great number of the parts of the body it invades, its operation may be illutrated by that of the wind upon a tree in Autumn: for, it finds or makes it elf multitudes of paages, for the mot part crooked, not onely between the branches and twigs, but the leaves and fruits, and in its paing from the one ide to the other of the tree, it does not onely variouly bend the more flexible boughs and twigs, and perhaps make them grate upon one another, but it breaks off ome of the talks of the fruit, and makes them fall to the ground, and withall carries off divers of the leaves, that grew the leat firmly on, and in its paage does by its differing parts act upon a multitude of leaves all at once, and variouly alters their ituation.

But to come to cloer Intances:
uppoe we cat two lumps, the one of Sugar, the other of Amber, into a glas of beer or water, they will both fall preently to the bottom. And though perhaps the Amber may be lighter than the Sugar, (for, I have found a notable difference in the pecific gravity of pieces of Amber,) yet the aqueous particles are far from being able to diplace the Amber or any enible part of it, or exercie any viible operation upon it: But the ame minute particles of the liquor being of a figure that fits them to ininuate themelves every way into the pores of the Sugar, though the lump conited of very numerous Saccharine Corpucles, yet the multitude of the aqueous particles, to which they are acceible, is able in no long time to dipere them all, and carrying them along with themelves, make the whole lump of Sugar in a hort time quite diappear.

The point above dicoured of, may be more nimbly exemplified in ome Chymical operations, and particularly
in this. If, by a due degree of fire, you abtract from running Mercury four or five times its weight of good Oil of Vitriol, there will remain at the bottom a dry and brittle ubtance exceeding white; and, if upon this Heap of Mercurial and Saline bodies, which ometimes may be coherent enough, you pour a good quantity of limpid water, and hake them together, you may ee in a trice the multitude of little white grains, that make up the mae, pervaded, and manifetly altered, by the dipered Corpucles of the water; as will plainly appear by the change of the Calx or Precipitate from a white mae into one of a fine Limon-colour.

But to give intances in Fluid bodies, (which I uppoe you will think far the more difficult part of my task,) though you will eaily grant, that the flame of Spirit of wine, that will burn all away is but a viible aggregate of uch E •• luvia wiftly agitated, as without •• y enible Heat
would of themelves inviibly exhale away; yet, if you be pleaed to hold the blade of a knife, or a thin plate of Copper, but for a very few minutes, in the flame of pure Spirit of wine, you will quickly be able to dicern by the great Heat, that is, the various and vehement agitation of the minute Corpucles of the metal, what a number of them mut have been fiercely agitated by the pervaion of the igneous particles, if we uppoe, (what is highly probable,) that they did materially penetrate into the innermot parts of the metall; and whether we uppoe this or no, it will, by our experiment, appear, that o fluid and yielding a body, as the flame of Spirit of wine, is able, almot in a trice, to act very powerfully upon the hardet metalls.

The power of extreamly-minute parts of a fluid body, even when but in a moderate number they are determined to conpire to the ame operation, may be etimated by the
motions of Animals, epecially of the larger and more bulky orts, as Hores, Bulls, Rhinocerots and Elephants. For, though the animal pirits be minute enough to be inviible, and to flow through uch tender paages, that prying Anatomits have not been able in diected Nerves to dicern o much as the channels through which they pas; yet thoe Inviible Spirits, conveyed (or impelled) from the Brain to the Nerves, erve to move in various manners the Lims, and even the unwieldy bodies themelves of the greatet Animals, and to carry them on in a progreive motion for many hours together, and perhaps enable them to pring into the Air, and move through it by leaping; though divers of thee Animals weigh many hundred, and others everal thouand of pounds.

I will not here conider, whether the following Experiment may at all illutrate Motions that are produced by the fluid parts of Animals in ome
of the conitent ones: But I preume, it may confirm the Obervation maintained in this Chapter, if I add, what I have tried of the coniderable force of a number of aqueous particles, as flexible and as languid as they are thought to be, ininuating themelves into the pores or Intervals of a rope that was not thick. For in moit weather I ometimes oberved, that the aqueous and other humid particles, wimming in the air, entering the pores of the hemp in great numbers, were able to make it hrink, though a weight of fifty, ixty, or even more pounds of lead were tied at the end to hinder its contraction, as appeared by the weights viibly being raied in wet weather above the place it reted at in dry.

But to return to what I was formerly peaking of the Determination of the motion of Fluids; I hall, on this occaion, oberve, that, though the wind or breath, that is blown out at a mall crooked pipe of metal or glas, uch as Tradesmen for its
ue call a Blow-pipe, eems not to have any great celerity, epecially in comparion of that of the parts of flame; and is it elf of little force; yet, when by this wind the flame of a Lamp or Candle is directed o as to beat with its point upon a body held at a convenient ditance from the ide of the flame, the burning fluid, determined, and perhaps excited by this wind, acquires o great a force, that, as we have often tried, it may be made, in a few minutes, to melt not onely the more fuible Metals, but ilver, or even copper it elf; which yet may be kept for many hours unmelted in a Crucible kept red-hot, or even in the flame of the Lamp or Candle, unaited by the blat.

And if we can o contrive it, that a flame does not come to invade onely the urface that invets a body, but comes to be intermingled with the maller (though not the mallet) parts it conits of, as with its filings or its powder; the flame will then have a far more quick and powerfull
operation than the body expoed to it. This I exemplify (in other Papers) and in this place it may uffice to oberve, that, whereas a pound or two of Tartar may cot you ome hours to calcine it to whitenes, if the flame have immediate acces onely to the outward parts; you may calcine it in a very mall part of that time, if, mixing with its gros powder an equal weight of good Salt-peter, you fire the mixture, and keep it tirring, that the parts of the kindled Nitre may have acces at once to very many parts of the Tartar, and have opportunity to calcine them. And by omewhat a like artifice, I elewhere teach, how Nitre it elf may without Tartar be peedily reduced to a Calcinatum, not unlike that newly mentioned. But it may be aid, that ome of the foregoing Intances (for it cannot be truly aid of all) may indeed illutrate what we are dicouring of, but will not reach home to our purpoe.

I hall therefore conider the
Load-tone, which you acknowledge to act by the emiion of Inenible particles. For, though Iron and Steel be olid and ponderous bodies, and Magnetical effluvia be corpucles o very minute, that they readily get in at the pores of all kind of bodies, and even of Glas it elf; yet thee Magnetical effluvia, entring the teel in warms, do in a trice pervade it, and a multitude even of Them, acting upon the Corpucles of the metal, do operate o violently on them, that, if the Load-tone be vigorous enough, and well capped, it will attract a notable proportion of teel, and urmount the gravity of that olid metal, which I have found to exceed, when the tone has been very good and little, above fifty times the weight of the Magnet by whoe effluvia it was upported: For, to thee I rather acribe Magnetical attraction and utentation, than to the impule or preure of the ambient air, to which many Corpucularians have recoure; becaue I have found by trial (which
I elewhere relate) that the preure of the ambient air is not abolutely neceary to Magnetical operations.

I remember, that, to help ome friends to conceive, how uch extreamly-minute particles as Magnetical effluvia, may, by pervading a hard and olid body, uch as Iron, put its inenible Corpucles into motion, and thereby range them in a new manner, I took filings of Steel or Iron frehly made, that the Magnetical virtue might not be diminihed by any rut, and having laid them in a little heap upon a piece of paper held level, I applied to the lower ide of the paper, jut beneath the Heap, the pole of a vigorous Load-tone, whoe Emiions travering the paper, and diffuing themelves through the incumbent metall, did in a trice manifetly alter the appearance of the Heap; and, though each of the filings might probably contain a multitude of uch mall Martiall Corpucles as Steel may be divided into by Oil of Vitriol or Spirit of Salt; yet the Magnetical
effluvia, immediately pervading our metalline heap, did o remove a good part of the filings that compoed it, as to produce many erected aggregates, each of which conited of everal filings placed one above another, and appearing like little needles, or rather like the ends of needles broken off at ome ditance from the point. And as thee little temporary needles tood all of them erected (though more or les, according to their ditance from the Pole of the Magnet) upon the flat paper; o they would, without loing their figure or connexion, be made as it were to run to and fro upon the paper, according as the Load-tone, that was held underneath it, was moved this way and that way; and as oon as that was taken quite away, all this little tand of pikes (if I may o call it) would (almot in the twinkling of an eye) relape into a confued heap of filings.

There are two ways of explicating the turning of Water into Ice; one
or other of which is approved almot by all the Corpucularian Philoophers. The firt is that of the Carteians, who give an account of Glaciation by the recee of the les ubtile particles of the Etherial matter, without which the finer parts were too mall and feeble to keep the Eellike particles of water flexible, and in the form of a liquour. The Atomits on the other ide acribe the freezing of water to the ingres of multitudes of frigorifick Corpucles, as they call them, which, entering the water in warms, and dipering themelves through it, crowd into the pores, and hinder the wonted motion of its parts, wedging themelves (if I may o peak) together with them into a compact body. But which oever of thee two Hypothees be pitched upon, the Phaenomenon it elf will afford me a notable Intance to my preent purpoe. For, the Particles of water, and much more the Corpucles of cold, are confeed to be ingly too mall to be
viible, and their motions are not aid to be wift, but may rather be judged to be low enough; and yet thoe minute aqueous, or more minute frigorifick particles, becaue of their number, produce in the glaciation of the liquour o forcible a motion outwards, as to make it break bottles, not onely of glas and earth trongly baked, but, as I have everal times tried, of metal it elf, that being full of the liquour were firmly topped before the upervening of the Cold. And the expanive endeavour of freezing water is not onely capable of doing this, but of performing o much greater things, which I elewhere relate, that my trials have made me ometimes doubt, whether we know any thing in nature, except kindled Gunpowder, that bulk for bulk moves more forcibly, though the motion eems to be very low.

div.head: CHAP. V. (Of the Propagable Nature of Motion.)

argument.p: Obervat. IV. Men are not ufficiently aware, how propagable Local Motion is, even through differing Mediums, and Solid bodies.

div.p: THere are four principal Occaions on which I have oberved, that men are wont to think the Communicating of Motion much more difficult than indeed it is.

And firt, there are many, that oberving how uually thoe bodies that hit againt hard ones rebound from them, eaily perwade themelves, that Motion can carce be tranmitted or diffued through Solid bodies. But though it be true, that oftentimes in uch caes the progreive motion of the body or the
Solid, that is truck or impelled, be either inconiderable, or, perhaps, not o much as enible; yet the impule may make a coniderable impreion, and may be communicated to a great hare of the particles of that matter, whereof the olid mas conits; as we ee in the triking of a timber-beam at one end, the motion, though perhaps it were not trong at the firt, may become enible at the other. Though Bell-metal be o hard a body, that it is reckoned harder than iron it-elf, inomuch that oftentimes it reits even files of Steel, which readily work on Iron; yet this olidity hinders not but that, as I have found, conveniently haped veels of Bellmetal, though thick, will be enibly affected by a motion that neither is trong, nor touches them in more than a hort line, or perhaps than a Phyical point. The truth of this I have found by trial on more than one uch veels and particularly on one that was hemiphaerical, which being placed or held in a convenient
poture, if I did but gently pas the point of a pin for a little way along the brim of it, it would enibly reound, and that (to a very attentive ear) o long, and in uch a ringing manner, as made it highly probable, that the parts, immediately touched (and not o much as cratched) by the point of a pin, were not onely put into a vibrating motion themelves, but were enabled to communicate it to thoe that were next them, and they to thoe that were contiguous to them; and o the tremulous motion was propagated quite round the bell, and made divers ucceive Circulations before it quite ceaed to be audible. And if, in tead of drawing a Line on the brim of the veel, I truck it, though but faintly, with the point of a pin, though the part immediately touched would be but a phyical point, yet the motion would be, like the former, propagated everal times quite round; as was argued by the ringing and duration of the produced ound, though this
metalline veel were even inches in Diameter, and of a coniderable thicknes. Nor was a olidity like that of Bras requiite to produce thee effects. For I found them to inue much after the ame manner, when I employed onely a hort and lender thread of Glas, which though little, if at all, thicker than a pin, was yet hollow quite through. Now if it be true, as 'tis highly probable, that Sound, as it belongs to the air, conits in an undulating motion of the Air, and o in our cae requires a vibrating motion in the onorous body to impart that motion to the Air; we mut grant in our Intances a wonderfull propagablenes of motion, even when 'tis not violent, in Solid bodies themelves; ince the point of a pin, gently triking a part, no bigger than it elf, of a mas of very olid metal, could thereby communicate a enible motion, and that everal times circulated, to millions of parts equall to it in bulk, and much exceeding it in hardnes. And ince
the effect was more coniderable, when the trial was made in a much greater, than in a maller veel; 'tis probable, that, if I had had the opportunity of experimenting on a large and well-hung Bell, the Phaenomenon would have been more notable; as it alo eemed to be on our veel, if, in tead of triking it with the point of a pin, we cat, though but faintly, againt the lower part of it a grain of hot, les than a mall pins-head, or let a little grain fall, from about one foot high, upon the inide of the inverted Hemiphere. And to hew, that even oft and yielding bodies, and but faintly moved, are not to be excluded from a power of putting uch hard ones into motion; I hall add, that I found almot the like effects to thoe above mentioned, by paing the pulp of my finger a little way along the lower part of the veel. Nay, that fluid bodies themelves may communicate uch an intetine and propagable motion, to harden olid ones, I may have hereafter
an occaion to hew by the effects of a mall Flame, and the Sun-beams on glas and teel. And I hall here on this occaion add this word about the Propagation of Motion produced in olid bodies by heat, that it much depends upon the particular Textures of the bodies. For I found, that when I heated a piece of glas or of a fire-tone, I could without inconvenience hold my naked hand upon parts that were very near (uppoe within an inch off) the ignited portions of them. But, if we take a rod of Iron, for intance, and heat one end red-hot, the heat of that end will be o propagated towards the other, that it will offend one's hand at everal times the ditance, at which one might conveniently hold the rod, if it were of glas.

In many buildings it may be oberved, (and is thought a ign of the firm Coheion of their parts,) that a tamp of one's foot, nay or bare treading, or ome uch other lee brisk impule, made in one room,
will have a enible effect in all or mot of the others. And it often happens, that, by the haty hutting of a door, the whole houe is made to tremble; whence we may argue, that, even among olid bodies, motion made in one place may be readily propagated to many others: And if, as to the latter of the Intances, the udden impule and compreion of the Air, made by the door uppoed to be hatily hut, have any coniderable hare in the effect, the Phaenomenon will erve to hew the efficacy even of uch a motion of a fluid body, as we cannot directly feel upon divers large and firmly connected olid bodies.

In Earthquakes the tremulous motion ometimes extends o very far, that, though it eems highly probable, that the hake that is given to one part of the Earth by the firing and exploion of ubterraneal exhalations, (if that be the true and onely caue of Earthquakes) is not capable of reaching near o far as divers
Earthquakes have done, but that the fire paes through ome little ubterraneal clefts, or channels, or hidden conveyances, from one great Cavity or Mine to another; yet 'tis not improbable but that the vehemently tremulous motion does oftentimes reach a very great way beyond the places where the exploions were made. Since, though Seneca would confine the extent ofNatur. Quaet. Lib. VI. Cap. 25. Earthquakes to two hundred miles, yet obervations made in this and the lat Century warrant us to allow them a far greater pread. The LearnedLib. III. Cap. 26. Joephus Acota affirms, that in the Kingdom of Peru in the year 1586 an Earthquake reached along the hoar of the Pacifick ea 160 Leagues; and adds, that ometimes it has in thoe parts run on from South to North 300 Leagues. And in the beginning of this our age (Anno Dom. 1601) good writers relate a much larger Earthquake to have happened, ince it reached from
Aia to that Sea that wahes the French Shoars, and, beides ome Aiatick Regions, hook Hungary, Germany, Italy and France, and conequently a great part of Europe. And if that part of the Narrative be certain, which relates, that this lated not much above a quarter of an hour, it will be the more likely, that this Earthquake hook great Tracts of Land beyond thoe places, to which the fired matter, paing from one cavity to another, could reach in o hort a time: As you will the more eaily guee, if you try, as I have done, that in trains of Gunpowder it elf the fire does not run on near o wiftly as one would imagine. But though I have been in more Earthquakes then one; yet, ince they were too udden and too hort to afford me any coniderable obervation, I hall ay no more of them; but proceed to take notice, that oftentimes the motion of a Coach or Cart, that paed at a good ditance from the place that I was in, has made the
buildings o enibly hake, that I could not but wonder, that o great a portion of o firm and luggih a body, as the Earth, could, by a caue that eemed very diproportionate to uch an effect, be made to tremble it elf, and manifetly to hake firm buildings that were founded on it. And this obervation made me the more inclinable to give credit to their Relations, who tell us, that in a calm night, the march of a troup of hore may be felt, by attentive Scouts watching at a great ditance off, by the hake that the ground receives from the trampling of the hores; though I formerly upected much, and do yet a little, that the impule of the air conveyed along the reiting urface of the ground, might mainly contribute to the effect that is acribed onely to the motion of the oil.

Before I advance to the Second Member of this Chapter, it may not be impertinent to note, that in peculiarly dipoed bodies, and epecially in Organical ones, a very languid
motion may have a far greater effect, than it could produce by a bare propagation of it elf. For it may o determine the motion of the Spirits or other active parts of the body it works on, as to make multitudes of them act as if they conpired to perform the ame motions. As when a ticklih man, by having the pulp of one's finger paed gently along the ole of his foot or the palm of his hand, has divers mucles and other parts of his body and face put into preternatural or unuual motions. And mot men by being lightly tickled with the end of a feather or traw, within their Notrils, have their heads and many parts of their bodies put into that violent Commotion, wherein Sneezing conits. And I remember, that having for ome time been, by a ditemper, (from which God was graciouly pleaed a while after to free me,) quite deprived of the ue of my hands; it more than once hapned to me, that itting alone in a Coach, if the wind chanced to
blow a ingle hair upon my face in the Summer-time, the tickling or itching, that it produced, was o uneay to me, 'till by calling out to a footman I could get it removed, that, though I could well bear it as long as I was wont to do, when, having the ue of my hands, I could relieve my elf at pleaure; yet if I were forced to endure the itching too long, before any came to uccour me, the uneaines was o great, as to make me apprehend falling preently either into Convulions or a Swoon. But 'tis time to proceed to the econd Member of this Chapter.

2. Others there are, that cannot believe, that Local motion, epecially if it be languid, can be propagated through differing Mediums, each of which, ave that wherein the Motion is begun, mut, they think, either repell, or check and dead it. To thee I hall recommend the Conideration of an Experiment, I remember I made before ome Learned men in our Pneumatick Engine. For, having
caued a large and thick glas Receiver to be o blown, that it had a glas button in the inide of that part which upon the Engine was to be placed upwards; I caued a Watch to be upended by a little Silverchain fatned to that button by as lender and oft a body, as I thought would be trong enough to upport my watch; and then, the Glas being cemented on cloe to the Receiver, to prevent a Commerce between the Cavity of it and the Air, the watch, that hung freely near the middle of the Cavity of the Receiver, made it elf to be heard by thoe attentive Litners, that would hold their ears directly over the upended watch, whoe motions were thereby argued to have been propagated, either through the included air, or along the tring to the concave part of the Glas, and through the whole thicknes of the Glas to the convex part, and thence, through the interpoed air to the Ear. And this mention of watches minds me of what I often oberved
in a mall triking watch, that I have worn in my pocket. For, when it truck the Hours, and in ome potures when the balance did but move, I could plainly feel the brisker motions of the Bell, and enibly the languid ones of the balance, through the everal linings of my Breeches, and ome other interpoed oft and yielding bodies; and this, though the watch (as I aid) was mall, and the balance included in a double cae, and though the outwardmot were of (what they call) Chagrine, and the innermot of Gold; which I therefore mention, becaue that cloet of metals is oberved more to dead ounds and motions than harder metals, as Silver, Copper, and Iron.

That Motion may be propagated through differing Mediums, may eem the more probable by the hakings that are often felt by men lying on beds that tand in rooms cloe hut, when loud claps of thunder are produced (perhaps at a great ditance off) in the clouds. And whether it
will be fit to add to this Intance that which you have lately met with in the III. Chapter of a wounded Frenchman at Copenhagen, I leave you to conider.

I know not whether it will be very proper to take notice on this occaion of an odd Phaenomenon recited by the experienced Agricola De nat. eorum quae effi. è Terra Lib. IV. Cap. 7. in thee words. Si animal dejicitur in antrum Viburgene, quod et in Carelia, Regione Scandiae, erumpit, ut perhibent, onus intolerabilis magno cum flatu: Si leve pondus in pecum Dalmatiae, quamvis, inquit Plinius, tranquillo die, turbini imilis emicat procella.

3. As thoe of whom I took notice at the beginning of this Chapter, are backward to allow, that Motion may be coniderably propagated through olid bodies; o on the contrary, there are others that are indipoed to think, that 'tis near o propagable as indeed it is through fluid bodies; becaue they preume, that the eay ceion of the parts of fluids
will dead the impule received by thoe of them that are firt acted on by the impelling body. And

4. There is yet another ort of Naturalits, who, though they may be brought to grant, that Motion may by propagated even through a oft and yielding Medium, cannot believe, that it hould through uch a Medium be propagated to any coniderable ditance; being perhaps induced to this opinion by oberving, that, though a body omewhat broad as well as olid, as the Palm of one's hand or a battledore, be moved through the Air wiftly enough to make a wind; yet that wind will not be trong enough to be felt any more than a very little way off. Wherefore, becaue the Intances, to which I aign the remaining part of this Chapter, may be for the mot part applicable to the removal of both thee prejudices; It may for brevity ake be expedient to conider them both together.

If Luminous bodies act on our
Eyes, not by a ubtantial diffuion of extreamly minute particles, as the Atomits would have it, but by a propagated Pulion of ome Subtile matter contiguous to the hining body, (as the Carteians and many other Philoophers maintain;) 'twill be manifet, that a body les than a mall pin's head may give a brisk motion to a portion of fluid matter many millions of times greater than it elf; ince in a dark night a ingle park of fire may be een in differing places, whoe ditance from it exceeds many thouand times the park's Diameter. Not to mention the great remove, at which the flame of a mall taper may not onely be een, but appear greater than near at hand. And if we compare the Diameter of that bright Planet Venus, which yet hines but with a borrowed and reflected Light, with its ditance from the Earth, we may eaily conclude, that the fixed Stars, which probably are o many Suns that hine by their own native Light, mut impell a tupendious
proportion of Etherial matter, to be able at that immene ditance to make uch vivid Impreions, as they do, upon our Eyes. But to decend to Intances les remote and diputable, I hall, in order to the removal of the two lately mentioned prejudices, proceed to conider; that, though it be true, that Fluid bodies do eaily yield to Solid ones that impell them, and thereby oftentimes quickly dead the motion of thoe Solids; yet the motion, being lot onely in regard of the olid body, is not lot, but tranmitted and diffued in reference to the fluid. As when a log of wood, or any uch body pecifically lighter than water, is let fall in the middle of a pond, though its progres downwards be checkt, and it be brought to ret quietly on the urface of the water; yet its motion is not lot, but communicated to the parts of the water it firt trikes againt, and by thoe to others, 'till at length the curls or waves produced on the urface of the water
pread themelves, till they arrive at the brinks, and would perhaps be farther expanded, if thee did not hinder their progres. From which intance we may learn, that, though the nature of fluid bodies, as uch, requires, that their parts be actually ditinct and eparately moved; yet the particular Corpucles that compoe them, being (at leat here below) touched by divers others, the new motion that is produced in ome of them by an impellent Solid, mut needs make them impell the contiguous Corpucles, and thee thoe that chance to lie next to them, and o the impule may be propagated to a ditance; which you will the more eaily believe may be great, if you conider with me, both that in a fluid body the Corpucles, being already in the various motion requiite to fluidity, yield more eaily to the impellent, and alo that being fully, or very near it, counterpoied by others of the ame fluid, a carce imaginably little force may uffice to impell
them; inomuch that, though the bras Scale of a balance, of divers inches in Diameter, may well be uppoed to outweigh many myriads of uch particles as compoe water, wine, &c. yet, (as I elewhere more fully relate) when uch a cale was duly counterpoied with another like it, I could eaily put it into various motions onely with the inviible Effluvia of no great piece of Amber. And if we conider that obvious Intance of the welling Circles made by cating a tone into a Pond or other tagnant water, we hall be the more eaily perwaded, that, even in a heavy fluid, a motion may reach a far greater way, than men are uually aware of, beyond the parts on which it was firt impret.

On this occaion I mut not omit a trange Obervation given me by a very experienced Navigator, that much frequents the Coat of Groenland, and other Arctick Regions, to fih for whales. For this peron being dicoured with by me about the effects
of the breaking of thoe vat piles of Ice, that are to be met with in thoe parts, aured me, that not onely he had often heard the Ice make in breaking terribler noie than the loudet claps of thunder with us, but that ometimes, when the Sea-water had, as it were, undermined the foundation of the mountainous piece of Ice, he has known it at length uddenly fall into the ubjacent Sea with o much violence as to make a torm at a great ditance off; inomuch that once, when he lay two Leagues off of the place where this tupendious mas of Ice fell, it made the waves goe o high as to wah clear over the tern of the hip, with danger enough to ome of his men, and to ink everal of his hallops that were riding by, though carce any mall veels in the world ue to be o fitted for rough Seas as thoe about Groenland.

And whereas, though the Air be a much thinner fluid, we are apt to think it indipoed to propagate motion
far, give me leave to tell you, that we may take wrong meaures, if we think, that, (for intance) the undulating motion, into which the Air is put by the action of onorous bodies, reaches but a little way, as we are apt to preume it does, becaue we judge of it by the effect it has on our ears when the ound is made in diadvantageous places. For one, that, for intance, hears a Lute or a Viol plaid on in a room furnihed with hangings, will be apt to think the ound faint and languid in comparion of what it would appear to him, if the ame Intrument were plaid on after the ame manner in an arched room without hangings; thee oft and yielding bodies being apt to dead the ound, which the figure and hardnes of the Vaulted room would reflect. And o, when a man peaks aloud in the free Air, we are not wont to take any notice of a progres made by the motion of the Air beyond the place we are in, when our ears receive the ound; but if the place happen
to be furnihed with an Echo, though at many times that ditance from the peaker, we may then eaily take notice, that the motion of the Air was carried on, and that with good vigour, to a far greater ditance than ele we hould have oberved. And I have often thought, that, even by the better ort of our Echoing places, we are not informed, to near how great a phere the motion, which the Air is put into by Sounds, may extend it elf, where its diffuion and vigour are not hindred nor weakned by bodies either placed too near, or indipoed to promote its operation.

What has been lately aid of the great diffuion of Sounds, if themelves be loud and great, will appear highly probable, by what is related by the Learned Fromundus, From. Meteor, Lib. II. Art. 9. who being Profeour of Philoophy at Lovain, in the Year 1627, had opportunity enough to know the Truth of what he relates; namely that, at the famous Siege of Otend in Flanders, the
thunder of the great Ordnance was heard at above thirty Dutch Leagues, which, according to the vulgar reckoning, amounts to a hundred and twenty of our Englih miles. And that is yet, as he truly oberves, more trange, and makes more for our preent purpoe, which he adds concerning the diffuion of the ound of a Drum, which, he ays, was, upon a time, heard at Sea twelve Leagues off.

But to return to what I was aying of Echo's, to confirm my conjecture about them, I hall think it needlee to offer you any other Argument, than that which you will draw your elf from the Notable Relation I met with in the Learned Varenius Geograph. general. Lib. I. Cap. XIX. of an Obervation made by David Fraelichius, who, in the Company of a couple of Students, had the curioity (in the month of June) to viit the mountain Carpathus, eteemed the highet of all the Hungarian Hills, and aid to be much more teep and difficulty acceible
than any of the Alps themelves. Fraelichius then (in my Authour) having related with what difficulty he and his Companions acended above that Region of the Air, where they met with clouds and vehement winds, adds this memorable Obervation, for whoe ake I mention the tory: Exploi (aies he) in ea ummitate clopetum, quod non majorem onitum primò prae e tulit, quàm i tigillum vel bacillum confregiem; pot intervallum autem temporis murmur prolixum invaluit, inferioréque montis partes, convalles, & ylvas opplevit. Decendendo per nives annoas intra convalles, cùm iterum clopetum exonerarem, major & horribilior fragor quàm ex tormento capaciimo inde exoriebatur: hinc verebar, nè totus mons concuus mecum corrueret; duravitque hic onus per emiquadrantem horae, uque dum abtruiimas cavernas penetraet, ad quas Aer undique multiplicatus reiliit. Et talia quidem objecta concava in ummitate e non illico offerebant, idcirco ferè inenibiliter
primùm onus repercutiebatur, donec decendendo antris & convallibus vicinior factus, ad eas fortiùs impegit.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Obervat. V. Men uually think not what the modification of the inviible motion of Fluids may perform on the dipoed bodies of Animals.

div.p: IN this Obervation I exprely mention the dipoed bodies of Animals, to intimate, that there is a peculiar aptitude required in thoe Animals, or ome particular parts of them that are to be enibly affected by uch motions as we are treating of, which would otherwie be too languid to have any enible operation on them.

It eems the les trange to me, that continuing Sounds, and other omewhat durable Impules of the Air or other Fluids, hould have a manifet operation upon Solid bodies, when I conider
the multitude of trokes that may in a very hort and perhaps carce obervable time, be uppoed to be given by the parts of the fluid to the Conitent body. For, though each of thee ingle would perhaps be too languid to have any enible effect at all; it being opportunely and frequently repeated by the ucceive parts of the fluid, as by o many little wimming hammers or flying bullets, they may well have a notable effect upon the parts of a body expoed to their action: As may be argued from the great wing that may be given to Pendulums by a very languid force, if it ucceively trike the winging body, when having finihed its excurion, 'tis ready to return towards the Perpendicular; as alo from the tremulous motion that is imparted even to the metalline tring of a Muical Intrument, by the congruous motion the Air is put into by another trembling tring, (as there may be hereafter occaion to declare.)

I remember, Scaliger tells a pleaant
tory of a Knight of Gacony, whom the ound of a Bagpipe would force preently to make water; adding, that a Peron diobliged by this man, and reolving to be merrily revenged on him, watched a time when he ate at a Feat o as he could not well get out, and brought a Bagpiper to play unawares behind him; which he did o unluckily, that the Muick had preently its wonted effect upon the poor Knight, to his great Confuion and the laughter of the Company. On which occaion I hall add, that I know a very Ingenious Gentleman, who has confeed to me, that the noie of a running Tap is wont to have almot the like operation upon Him.

'Tis a common Obervation, that the noie that an ungreaed cartwheel makes in grating againt the axel-tree, and the craping of a knife upon a plate of ilver or pewter, and ome other uch brisk and acute Sounds, do o affect divers parts of the Head, as to produce that effect
that is commonly called etting the Teeth on edge; which whether it proceed from any commerce between the Auditory Nerves, and thoe that are inervient to the motion we have mentioned, I leave Anatomits to conider. But thee effects of acute ounds are much les coniderable than that which I elewhere relate of an Ingenious Dometick of mine, who everal times complained, that the tearing of brown paper made his Gums bleed: which argued that the ound had an operation not onely upon the nervous and membranous parts, but the bloud and Humours themelves.

Sir Henry Blunt, in his voiage to the Levant, giving an account of what he oberved in Egypt, has, among other remarkable things, this paage: Many rarities of Living creatures I aw in Gran Cairo, but the mot ingenious was a net of four-legged Serpents of two foot long, black and ugly, kept by a Frenchman, who when he came to handle them, they would not endure him, but ran and hid
in their hole; then would he take his Cittern and play upon it: They, hearing his Muick, came all crawling to his feet, and began to climbe up him, till he gave over playing, then away they ran.

This recalls to my mind, what ome men of repute, and particularly the Learned Kircherus, relate concerning a great Fih, in or about the Streights that ever Sicily from Italy, which is aid to be much affected with a peculiar kind of Tune, (harh enough to Humane ears) by which the Mariners are wont to allure it to follow their veels. And it may much trengthen the Concluion maintained in this Chapter, if there be any certainty in the famous tradition, that the Lion is terrified and made to run away by the crowing of a Cock: I ay, if, becaue though I doubt not but ome peculiar kinds of Sounds, as well as of other enible objects, may be particularly and exceedingly ungratefull to the Senories of this or that peculiar kind of Animals, and conequently
to the ears of Lions; yet a late French Traveller into the Levant gives me caue much to quetion the matter of fact, affirming, that rowing along the brink of Tigris or Euphrates, (for I do not punctually remember which,) they were, for many hours in the night, terrified by Lions that attended them along the brink of the River, and would not at all be frighted by the frequent crowing of the Cocks that chanced to be in the paengers Boat. Of which unconcernednes of the Lions, our oberving traveller took much more notice than the Lions appeared to do of the crowing of the Cocks. I might on this occaion ay omething of the received Tradition, that many leeping perons will be more eaily waked by being called upon by their own uual names, than by other names, though uttered with a louder voice. But this it may uffice to have mentioned; nor will I here init on that more certain example of the operation of a Sound, which is afforded
by the tarting of men or greater Animals, upon a urprizing, though not vehement, noie; though this oftentimes puts o many of the Spirits and Mucles into motion, that the whole bulk of the Animal is uddenly raied from the ground, which perhaps it could not be by the bare counterpoie of ome hundreds of pounds: This, I ay, I will not in this place init on, becaue the Phaenomenon eems to depend rather upon the loudnes or acutenes of the ound, than upon any determinate modification of it, particularly relating to the Animal it elf.

But the eminentet Intance of the efficacy of peculiarly modified Sounds upon dipoed bodies, is afforded by what happens to thoe which are bit by a Tarantula. For though the bitten peron will calmly hear divers other tunes, yet when a peculiarly congruous one comes to be plaid, it will et him a dancing with o much vigour as the pectators cannot but wonder at, and the dancing will
ometimes continue many hours, if the Muick do o, and not otherwie. I know there are ome that quetion the truth of the things related of thee Tarantati, (as the Italians call them,) and I eaily grant, that ome Fictions may have been uffered to pas under the countenance of o trange a Truth. But beides the affirmations of ome Learned men, (as well Phyicians as others) my Doubts have been much removed by the Accounts I have received from an Ingenious Acquaintance of mine own, who at Tarentum it elf, whence the Inect takes its name, and elewhere, aw many bitten perons in their dances, ome in publick and ome in private places, and amongt the ret a Phyician, on whom the tune that fitted his ditemper had the ame operation as on the other Patients. And the Learned Epiphanius Ferdinandus, who practied Phyick in Apulia and Calabria for many years, not onely delivers upon his own peronal obervation, everal Narratives of the
effects of Muick upon the Tarantati, but invites any that may doubt of the truth of uch Narratives to repair to him at a fit eaon, undertaking to convince them by ocular Demontration.

I know a very honet and ober Muician, who has divers times affirmed to me, that he could at pleaure, by playing a certain Tune, (which he acquainted me with, and which did not much move others) make a peron (whom he named to me) weep, whether he would or no. And I might add, that when I have been taking Phyick, or am any thing feverih, the repetition of two veres of Lucan eldom fails (as I have often tried) of producing in me a chilnes, almot like that, but fainter, that begins the fit of an ague. But on this Intance I look not as a trong proof of the Phyical efficacy of Sounds; becaue thoe two veres having been emphatically read, when divers years agoe I lay ick of a low fever, and could not ret, they made
o trong an impreion on me, that whenever I am under a Dicompoure any thing near like that, that then troubled me, thoe veres revive, as 'twere, in my brain and ome other parts that dipoition, or rather indipoition, with which my firt hearing of thoe veres was accompanied.

It may be the les admired, that the vibrating motion of the Air, that produces ounds, hould have uch effects upon dipoed Organical bodies, ince Light it elf, which either conits of briskly moving effluvia far more ubtile than aerial corpucles, or is propagated by the pule of a far more ubtile body than Air, may have a notable operation upon dipoed bodies. For we commonly oberve, that the Sunbeams, by beating upon the face or eyes of ome that come uddenly out of a haded place into the Light, preently make them neeze; which you know is not done without a vehement motion of divers parts of
the body. And though Colour be but a modification of Light; yet, beides that 'twas anciently a practice, as the Hitory of the Macchabees informs us, to hew red objects to Elephants, to make them more fierce, 'tis a familiar obervation, that red cloaths do offend and irritate Turky-cocks. And that is more remarkable, which is related by the very Learned Phyician Valeius, of a peron that he knew, who, if he looked upon red objects, would not onely have his Eyes offended, but was ubject to an effuion of Humours in the neighboring parts.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Obervat. VI. Men upect not what efficacy the Inviible motions of Fluids may have, even upon inorganical bodies, upon the core of ome determinate Congruity or relation betwixt a peculiar Texture of the one, and the peculiar modification of the others motion.

div.p:
THough the Experiments delivered in the foregoing Chapter have, I preume, ufficiently manifeted, that the modification given to the motions of the Air by onorous bodies may have coniderable effects upon Animals, in whoe organized bodies the curiouly contrived parts have an admirable connexion with, and relation to, one another, and to the whole Symmetrical fabrick they make up; yet, I fear, it will carce eem credible, that onorous motions of the Air, not very loud, hould find, even in
bodies Inanimate and Inorganicall, uch congruous Textures and other Dipoitions to admit their action, that even more languid Sounds, peculiarly modified, may enibly operate upon them, and much more than ounds that are louder and more vehement, but not o happily modified. To make this good by particular Experiments, I hall begin with that, which, though the effect may eem inferiour to that of mot of the others, I judge fittet to manifet, that the produced motion depends upon the determinate modification of that of the impellent Fluid.

That a certain impule of Air, made by one of the Union-trings of a Muical Intrument, may uffice to produce a viible motion in another, is now become a known experiment; of the Caue and ome unoberved Phaenomena of which I elewhere more fully dicoure. But, that it may not be upected in this cae, that the hake of the untouched tring is communicated to it by the
propagated motion of the Intrument it elf, to which the tring, that is truck, is alo fatned; I hall add, that, according to what I elewhere relate, I found by trial purpoely made, that a tring of Wire, (which you will grant to be a more olid body than an ordinary Gut-tring,) may be without another tring brought to tremble by a determinate Sound made at a ditance, which produced but uch an impule of the Air, as could neither be een nor felt by the By-tanders, nor would communicate any enible motion to the neighbouring trings. 'Tis true, that in this cae the tring, in which the trembling was produced, was a ingle, long, lender and pringy body, fatned at both ends to a table one; and therefore it may eem altogether groundles to expect, that any thing like this effect hould be by the ame caue produced in bodies that do not appear o qualified. But, as we elewhere hew, that a certain degree or meaure of tenion is in order
to this Phaenomenon the principal Qualification, without which all the other would be unavailable; perhaps 'twill not be aburd to enquire, whether, in bodies of a very differing appearance from trings, the various Textures, Connexions, and Complications, that Nature or Art, or both, may make of the parts, may not bring them to a tate equivalent to the Tenions of the trings of Muical Intruments, whereby divers of the mentioned parts may be tretched in the manner requiite to dipoe them to receive a vibrating motion from ome peculiar Sounds: And whether thee trembling parts may not be numerous enough to affect their neighbours, and make, in the body they belong to, a tremulous motion dicernible, though not by the Eye, yet by ome other ene. This conjecture or inquiry you will, I hope, have the les unfavourable thoughts of, when you hall have conidered the following Experiments.

I remember, that many years agoe
I found by trial, that, if a omewhat large and almot hemipherical Glae, though not very thin, were conveniently placed, a determinate ound, made at a convenient ditance from the concave urface of the Glae, would make it enibly ring, as a Bell does a while after it has been truck. But this noie was the effect of a determinate ound; for, though the voice were raied to a higher tone, or if the ound were made louder, the ame effect would not inue. I remember alo, th •• , ome years after, I oberved, that large empty drinkingglaes of fine white metal had each of them its determinate Tenion, or ome dipoition that was equivalent as to our purpoe. For, cauing the trings of a Muical Intrument to be variouly crewed up, and let down, and briskly truck, we found, as I expected, that the motion of one tring, when 'twas tretched to a certain note or tone, would make one of the Glaes ring, and not the other; nor would the ound of the
ame tring, tuned to another note, enibly affect the firt Glae, though perhaps it might have its operation upon another. And this Circumtance is not, on this occaion, to be omitted, that, after we had found the tone proper to one of the Glaes, and o tuned the tring, that, (I ay) when that was truck, the Glae would reound. Having afterwards broken off a part of the foot of the glas, yet not o much but that it continued to tand upright, the ame ound of the tring would no longer be anwered by the Veel, but we were obliged to alter the tenion of the tring, to produce the former effect. The Learned Kircherus, as I have been informed, omewhere mentions a correpondence between ome liquours and ome determinate ounds; which I uppoe may be true, though the triall did not ucceed with me, perhaps for want of uch accommodations for o nice an Experiment as I could have wihed, but could not procure: But if you can, you will oblige
me to make the trials o as to atisfie your elf and me, whether the agitation of the liquour be caued immediately by the motion of the Air, or be communicated by the intervention of the tremblings of the Veel.

An Artit famous for his skill in making Organs, anwered me, that, at ome tops of the Organs, ome eats in the Church would tremble. But, becaue I upected by his Relation, that the greatnes of the ound chiefly effected it, becaue, when that Pipe, which they call the open Diapaon, ounds, the chair or eat, on which the Organit its, and perhaps the neighbouring part of the Organ trembles; I hall add, that I have divers times oberved certain ounds of an excellent Organ to make not onely the eat, I ate on in the Church, tremble under me, but produce an odd tremulous motion in the upper part of my Hat, that I could plainly feel with my hands. And that, which makes me apt to believe that this effect depends upon the determinate
tone, rather than upon the loudnes of the ound, is, that I have oftentimes felt, and diligently oberved uch a kind of motion in the upper part of my Hat, upon the pronouncing of ome words in ordinary dicoure; in which cae the effect could not with probability be referred to the greatnes of the Sound, but its peculiar fitnes to communicate uch a motion to a body o dipoed.
