Nor is it onely in uch mall and yielding bodies, as Hats and Strings, that Sounds that are not boiterous may produce enible effects, for, if they be congruous to the Texture of the body they are to work on, they may excite motions in it, though it be either olid or very bulky: of which I hall here ubjoyn a couple of intances.

An ancient Muician affirmed to me, that, playing on a Bae-viol in the chamber of one of his Scholars, when he came to trike a certain Note on a particular tring, he heard an odd kind of jarring Noie, which he
thought at firt had either been caual, or proceeded from ome fault in the tring; but, having afterwards frequent occaion to play in that ame room, he plainly found, that the Noie, he marvelled at, was made by the tremulous motion of a Caement of a window, which would be made to tremble by a determinate ound of a particular tring, and not by other Notes, whether higher or lower.

To this firt Intance I hall add the econd, which, I confee, I was not forward to believe, till trial had convinced me of the Truth; and I crupled it the rather, becaue, if the reflexion of determinate Sounds hould appear to proceed from the peculiar kind of tremulous motion into which the parts of the reonant body are put, it may incline men to o great a Paradox, as to think, that uch a motion of the Air as our Bodies do not feel, may produce a trembling in o olid a body as a Stone-wall of a great thicknes. The Experiment or Obervation it elf I hall give you
in the ame words I et it down ome hours after I made it, which were thee.

Yeterday I went to atisfy my elf of the truth of what had been told me by an ancient Muician, to whom I had been relating what I had oberved of the effects of ome determinate Sounds even upon Solid bodies, and of whom I enquired, if he had met with any thing of the like nature: taking him along with me, I found, that though the place be but an Arch, yet it would not anwer to all notes indifferently, when we tood in a certain place, but to a determinate Note, (which he afterwards told me was Ce fa ut a little flatted,) to which note it anwered very reonantly, and not enibly to others, which we made trial of, whether higher or lower than it; and, (which added to the trangenes,) when I made him raie his voice to an Eighth, as cononant as thoe two Sounds are wont to be in all other caes, the vaulted Arch did not appear
to us affected with the Note. The Muician added, that he had tried in mot Arches all about the City, and could not find uch a peculiarity in them, as being to be made reonant by all Notes or Sounds indifferently that were trong enough; and alo, that as this Arch for this hundred years has been oberved to have this property, o an ancient and experienced Builder informed him, that any Vault that were exquiitely built, would peculiarly anwer to ome determinate Note or other.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: Obervat. VII. Men look upon divers Bodies as having their parts in a tate of abolute Ret, when indeed they are in a Forced tate, as of Tenion, Compreion, &c.

div.p:
THis Obervation will probably eem paradoxicall. For, when an intire Body, epecially if it be of a olid Conitence, and eem to be of an homogeneous or uniform matter, appears to be movelee, we are wont to take it for granted, that the parts, which that body is made up of, are perfectly at Ret alo. But yet this will carce be thought a reaonable uppoition, if we do but rightly conider ome obvious Phaenomena, which may teach us, that, whilt a whole Body, or the uperficies that includes it, retains its figure, dimenions and ditance from other table Bodies that are near it, the Corpucles that compoe it may have
various and brisk motions and endeavours among themelves. As, when a bar of iron or ilver, having been well hammered, is newly taken off of the Anvill; though the Eye can dicern no motion in it, yet the touch will readily perceive it to be very hot, and, if you pit upon it, the brisk agitation of the inenible parts will become viible in that which they will produce in the liquour. Beides, when the Lath of a Cros-bow tands bent, though a man do neither by the Eye nor the Touch perceive any motion in the pringy parts, yet if the tring be cut or broken, the udden and vehement motion of the Lath, tending to retore it to the figure it had before it was bent, dicovers a pringines; whence we conclude it was before in a tate of violent Compreion. And, though the tring of a bent Bow do likewie appear to be in a tate of Ret; yet, if you cut it aunder, the newly made extreams will fly from one another uddenly and forcibly enough
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
to manifet, that they were before in a violent tate of Tenion. And on this occaion I could add divers Intances taken not onely from the works of Art, but thoe of Nature too, if they did not belong to another paper: But, one ort of Obervations 'twill be proper to et down in this place; becaue in thoe already mentioned, the bow and tring were brought into a violent tate by the meer and immediate force of man. I hall therefore add, that there are divers bodies, in which, though no uch kind of force appears to have antecedently acted on them, we may yet take notice of a tate of violent Compreion or Extenion, and a trong endeavour or tendency of the parts, that to the Eye or the Touch eem at ret, to hrink or to fly out; and this endeavour may in ome Caes be more lating and more forcible than one would eaily upect or believe. But examples of this kind you mut not expect that I hould give you out of Claick Authours,
ince in them 'tis like you have not met with either an Intance or a Conjecture to this purpoe; but ome few things that I tried my elf, and ome others that I learnt by Inquiry from ome Trademen, whom I judged likeliet to inform me, I hall briefly acquaint you with.

I have ometimes oberved my elf, and have had the Obervation confirmed to me by the ingeniouer Traders in Glas; That a Glas, that eemed to have been well baked, or nealed, (as they call it) would ometimes, many days or weeks, or perhaps months, after it is taken from the fire, crack of its own accord; which eems for the mot part to happen upon the core of the trong, but unequall, hrinking of the parts of the Glae. And the Glas-men will tell you, that, if they take their Glaes too hatily from the fire, not allowing them leiure to cool by degrees, they will be very apt to crack. But I remember, that, to atisfy ome Ingenious
men, I devied a way of exhibiting a much more quick and remarkable Phaenomenon of that kind. Having made then, by a way I elewhere teach, a flat Lump of metalline Glas, two or three or four times as thick as an ordinary Drinkingglas, I oberved, as I expected, that, though it had been melted in a very gentle fire, its very fuible nature needing no other, and though it were removed but very little from the fire, it was o dipoed to hrink upon a mall degree of Refrigeration, or rather abatement of Heat, that, before it was enibly cold, it would crack with a noie in o vehement a manner, that, notwithtanding the ponderounes of the matter; which had been purpoely laid upon a Levell, parts of a coniderable bulk, weighing perhaps ome Drams, would fly, to a not inconiderable ditance from one another. And this Experiment I took pleaure to make more than once. And if you will be content with an Intance
which, though otherwie much inferiour, may not be unwelcome, for its being eaily and readily made; I hall offer you one that I have often repeated. Take a piece of Copper, (if the Plate be thick, 'tis o much the better,) and, having throughly brought it to a red or white Heat among kindled Coals, take it from the fire, and when it begins to cool a little, hold it over a heet or two of white Paper, and you will perceive good tore of flakes to fly off, not without ome little noie, one after the other, and ometimes perhaps as far as the farthermot edges of the paper; which flakes or cales eem by their brittlenes and colour, to be but parts of the urface of the metal vitrified by the vehement action of the fire, and afterwards by a too haty refrigeration hrinking o violently, as to crack and leap from one another, like the contiguous parts of the tring of a Viol or other Muical Intrument, that breaks by the moiture of the Air. And on
this occaion I hall add, that, having afterwards inquired of an expert Artificer, that made metalline Concaves, about the hrinking of his mixtures of metalls, he confeed to me, that he uually oberved them to hrink upon Refrigeration. And the like I my elf have oberved in Iron of a great thicknes, and purpoely fitted to a hollow body of metall, which it would not enter when it was ignited, though it would when 'twas cold. But to hew you by a notable Intance or two, both that Metals may hrink, and that they may doe o with a very coniderable force, I hall add, that I found by inquiry, that the lately mentioned Artificer, after he had made ome large Concaves of an unfit mixture of metals, and having removed them from the fire, had been very carefull to keep the cold Air from them, let they hould cool too hatily, oberved yet to his great los, that, when they came to be further refrigerated, they would (perhaps after three hours) crack with a great noie,
though this metalline mixture were perchance harder than Iron, and three or four times as thick as common Looking-glaes. But the mifortune of another Trademan afforded me a yet more coniderable Phaenomenon. For this excellent Artificer, whom I often employ, and with whom I was a while ince dicouring of thee matters, complain'd to me, that, having lately cat a kind of Bell-metall upon a very trong olid Intrument of Iron of a coniderable uperficial Area, though the metal were uffer'd in a warm room to cool, from about eight a clock on Saturday night till about ten or twelve on Monday morning, and were then (which is to be noted) coniderably hot to the touch; yet it cool'd o far, that, hrinking from the Iron that would not hrink with it, the Bell-metall cracked in divers places with noies loud as the Report of a Pitoll, though the metall, he affirm'd to me, was an inch and half, or two inches thick. And the ame
peron hewed me a large Cylinder of Iron, about which, for a certain purpoe, a Coat of Bell-metall had been cat ome days before, on which (Bell-metall) there was a crack near one end made by the coldnes of the Iron, though the thicknes of the Bell-metall, as near as I could meaure it, exceeded an inch, and (as the Workman affirmed) an inch and a quarter.

Nor is it onely in uch mixtures as Bell-metall, which, though very hard, may be very brittle, but even in a metal that is malleable when cold, that the like Phaenomenon may be met with, as I have been aured by another ingenious Artificer, of whom I inquired, whether he had taken notice of the hrinking of metalls; who affirm'd to me, that, having had occaion to cat about a Cylinder of Iron a ring or hoop of Bras, he found to his trouble, that, when the metall began to cool, the parts hrunk from one another o as to leave a gaping crack, which he was fain to
fill up with oulder quite croe the breadth of the ring, though this were above an inch thick.

I hould not, Pyrophilus, have in this Chapter entertained you with more Experiments of others than of my own, if I had the conveniency of living near Founders of metalls, as the Trademen had whoe Obervations I have rectied, and whoe incerity in them I had no caue to quetion. And both their Experiments and mine eem to teach, that a body may be brought into a tate of Tenion, as well by being expanded and tretch'd by the action of the fire upon the minute parts, as by the action of an external Agent upon the intire body. And, to peak more generally, the tate of violent Contraction and Compreion may not unfitly be illutrated by a Bow that is bent. For, as the Bow it elf is brought to a tate of Compreion by the force of the Archer, that bent it; o by the Elatical force of the bent Bow, the tring is brought into a violent tate
of Tenion, as may be made evident by the cutting off the tring in the middle; for then both the Bow will fly uddenly outwards, and the parts of the tring will wiftly and violently hrink from one another. And according to this Doctrine, the effect of other bodies upon uch as are thus brought into, what men call, a Preternatural tate, is not to be judg'd barely according to uual meaures, but with repect to this latent Dipoition of the Patient: as, for intance, though the tring of a Viol not crewed up, will not be hardned by the vapours that imbue the Air in moit weather; yet a neighbouring tring of the ame Intrument, though perhaps much tronger, being crew'd up, and thereby tretched, will be o affected with thoe vapours, as to break with noie and violence. And o when one part of a piece of Glas is made as hot as can be, without appearing dicolour'd to the Eye, though a drop or two of cold water have no effect upon the other part of
the ame Glae, yet if it touch the heated part, whoe wonted extenion (as I have elewhere proved) is alter'd by the fire that vehemently agitates the component particles, the cracking of the Glas will almot always preently enue.

If againt thee Intances it be alledged, that it is poible to aign another caue of the eemingly pontaneous breaking of the bodies mention'd in this Chapter, than that which I have propos'd, it will not much concern this Dicoure to examine the Allegation; for, whatever the latent Caue of the Phaenomena may be, the manifet Circumtances of them uffice to hew, that bodies, which, as to ene, are in a natural tate of Ret, may be in a violent one, as of Tenion, and may have, either upon the core of the contexture of the parts among themelves, or upon that of ome interfluent ubtile matter, or ome other Phyical Agent, a trong endeavour to fly off or recede from one another; and that,
in divers bodies, the caue of this endeavour may act more vigorouly than one would eaily believe: and this uffices to erve the turn of this Dicoure. For I preume that a peron of your Principles will allow, that Local Motion mut be produc'd by Local Motion, and conequently, that, without a very trong, though inviible and unheeded one, uch hard and olid bodies as thick pieces of metall could not be made to crack.

I know not whether I may on this occaion acquaint you with an odd Relation I had from a very honet and credible, as well as experienced, Artit, whom I, for thoe reaons, have everal times made choice to deal with about precious Stones, and other things belonging to the Jewellers and Goldmiths trades. For, conidering with him one day a large lump of matter, which contained everal Stones that he took for coure Agats, and which were joyned together by a Cement, that in mot places was harder than mot ordinary
Stones, I perceived that there remained divers pretty large cavities in this Cement, which eemed to have contained uch Stones as thoe that yet made parts of the lump. Upon which occaion he affirmed to me, that everal of the Stones grew whilt they were lodg'd in thoe cavities. And when I told him, that, though I had been long of an opinion, that Stones may receive an increment after their firt formation, yet I did not ee how any uch thing appeared by thoe we were looking upon: He gave me in many words an account of his Aertion, which I reduced to this, that the Stones he poke of, did, after they were firt formed, really tend to expand themelves by virtue of ome Principle of growth, which he could not intelligibly decribe; but that thee Stones being lodg'd in a Cement extreamly hard, and therefore not capable of being forced to give way, their expanive endeavour was rendered ineffectual, but not detroyed: o that when afterwards thee
Stones came to be taken out of the Cement wherein they were bedded, and to whoe ides 'tis like they were not exquiitely congruous, the compret Stones, having their ides now no longer wedged in by the harder Cement, quickly expanded themelves, as if 'twere by an internal and violently compret pring, and would preently burt aunder, ome into two, and ome into more pieces: of which he preented many to his friends, but yet had reerved ome, whereof he preented me one, that I have yet by me, together with ome of the mas, whoe Cement I find to bear a better polih than marble, and to be very much harder than it. And, in anwer to ome quetions of mine, he told me, that he had taken up thee Stones himelf, naming the place to me, which was not very far off, and that he oberved all that he told me himelf, and more than once or twice, and that I needed not upect, as I eemed to doe, that 'twas the trokes employed to force the
Stones out of their Beds, that made them break. For, beides that many of them, which (it eems) were not compret enough, did not break, everal of thoe, that did, were taken out, without offering them any uch violence, as that their burting could with any probability be imputed to it.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: Obervat. VIII. One main caue why uch Motions as we peak of are overlook'd, is, That we are carce wont to take notice but of thoe motions of Solid bodies, wherein one whole Body drives away another, or at leat knocks viibly againt it, whereas many effects proceed from the intetine motions produced by the external Agent, in, and among, the parts of the ame body.

div.p: THis Obervation is like to be much more readily undertood than granted, and therefore I hall offer by way of proof the following Experiments.

We caued in a large bras Stopcock the movable part to be nimbly turned to and fro in the contiguous cavity of that part that was made to receive it, in that part of the Intrument that is wont to be kept fixt. And though this motion of the Key
were made onely by the bare hand, yet in a hort time the mutual attrition of the contiguous parts of the Intrument made o brisk an agitation in the other parts, that the incalecence made the metal it elf to well, inomuch that the Key could no more be turned, but remained fixt, as if it had been wedged in, o that, to make it work as before, it was neceary by cooling it to make it hrink a little, and o take off the mutual preure of the Key, and the other part of the Stop-cock. Nor is this to be looked on as a caual Experiment; for, beides that it was made more than once, and is very analogous to ome other trials of mine; I found, that a maker of uch Intruments complained to me, that he was everal times forced to intermit his work, and plunge his Intrument in cold water, before he could, by grinding, adjut the Key to the cavity it ought to fit.

I preume I need not take notice to you, that this Experiment confirms
what I elewhere mention of the dilatation of metals themelves by Heat, and therefore I proceed to the next Intance.

This is afforded by the known Experiment of paing one's wetted finger upon the orifice of a Drinkingglas almot fill'd with water. For, though the Eye does not immediately dicern any motion, that, by reaon of the preure of the finger, is made by one part of the glas upon another; yet, That a vibrating motion is thereby produced, may be argued by the dancing of the water, epecially that which is contiguous to the pret ides of the glas, by which 'tis oftentimes o agitated, that numerous drops are made to leap quite over, and others are toed up to a good height into the Air. And that there may be coniderable motions in the ides of the glas, whilt it does not break in pieces, we may probably gues by this, that, in Drinking-glaes artificially cut by a piral line, both I, and others, have
often found by trial, that, a glas being dextrouly inverted and haken, the parts will vibrate up and down o manifetly, as ometimes to lengthen the glas, by my etimate, a quarter of an inch or more, and yet, the glas being et again upon its foot, it appeared that it had not been hereby at all injured.

That two pieces of Iron or Steel, by being trongly rubbed againt one another, will at length acquire a temporary Heat, is not hard to be believed: but that an edg'd Tool of hardened Steel hould, by having its edge rubbed againt, have a manifet and permanent change made in its Texture, you did not perhaps upect; and yet, having had the Curioity to caue ome metals, and particularly Iron and Steel, to be turned by an excellent Artificer, I learned partly by his experience, and partly by my own, that the edge of the Steel-tool, with which he by degrees haved off the protuberant parts of the metal, would be o heated and agitated,
that, in no long time, if care were not taken to prevent it, the tool would be brought to look of blewih and yellowih colours, and, permanently loing its former temper, would become o oft, as to be uelee for its former work, unlee it were again artificially hardened: and therefore, to prevent the trouble of tempering his tools again, this Artit, from time to time, dipt it, when it began to grow too hot, into a certain liquour, which he affirms, upon much experience to have a peculiar fitnes for that purpoe.

Nor is it always neceary that the body, that makes the parts of an inanimate body work coniderably on one another, hould be either very hard, or impetuouly moved. For, I remember, that, having once by me ome hort bars of fine Tin, I reolved to try whether, meerly with my naked hands, (which you know are none of the tronget or hardet,) I could not procure a coniderable internal Commotion among the parts;
and accordingly, laying hold on the two ends of the bar with my two hands, I lowly bent the bar towards me and from me two or three times, and having by this means broke or cracked it in the midt, I perceived, as I expected, that the middle parts had coniderably heated each other.

What ue may be made of this Experiment in the earch of the hidden caue of Elaticity, would be les properly conidered in this place than in another. But ince I have named that Quality, I hall take this rie to intimate, that if the retitution of a pringy body, orcibly bent, proceed onely (as ome Learned Moderns would have it) from the endeavour of the compret parts themelves to recover their former tate, one may not impertinently take notice of the Elaticity that Iron, Silver and Bras acquire by hammering, among the Intances that hew what in ome caes may be done by a motion wherein the parts of the ame body are, by
an almot unheeded force, put to act upon one another. But if Springines depend chiefly upon the pervaion of a ubtile matter, as the Carteians would have it, then the Intances will properly belong to another Subject.

§ The foregoing Examples may alo uffice to make out (what I am unwilling to refer to another Head) this ubordinate Obervation, That men are more uually than jutly prepoeed with an opinion, that nothing coniderable is to be expected from the motion of a body againt another, unles the former do make a manifet percuion or truion of the latter. But, becaue this prepoeion epecially prevails in caes where the body that is by friction or attrition to affect the other, is it elf oft or yielding, I hall on this occaion add a few Intances to remove this Prejudice.

An Artit, eminent for grinding of Optical glaes, confeed to me, that ometimes when he went about
to polih his broader glaes, though but upon a piece of Leather prinkled with Puttee, that friction did o heat or otherwie agitate the parts of the glas, as, to his great los, <> make it crack from the edge to the middle; which eemed the more trange, becaue we fee, what intene degrees of Heat glaes will endure without cracking, if the fire be but gradually applied, as this Artit's glaes mu • have been gradually heated.

But I think it worth inquiry, whether in this cae the whole work be performed by meer Heat, and whether there intervene not a peculiar kind of motion, into which ome bodies are dipoed to be put by a peculiar kind of friction, which eems fitted to produce in manifetly pringy bodies, and perhaps in ome others, (of which divers may be pringy that are not commonly taken to be o,) uch a vibrating or reciprocal motion, as may have ome notable effects, that are not wont to be produced by
moderate Heats, nor always by intene ones themelves. The trembling of the parts of a Drinking-glas, and the viible vibration of the long and great trings of a Bae-viol, upon peculiar ounds, may give ome countenance to this conjecture. And that in ome bodies there may be uch a tremulous motion produced, by rubbing them upon o oft a thing as Wool, or upon a piece of Cloath, I tried by this Experiment:

We cat into a hollow Veel, very mooth within, and of an almot Hemipherical figure, everall ounces of good melted Brimtone, and having uffered it to cool, and taken it out, the Convex urface, as had been deired, came off well polihed; then this conveniently haped lump, which had (if I well remember) four or five inches in Diameter, being briskly rubbed in the ame line forwards and backwards, upon a Cuhion or ome uch woollen thing, in a place free from other noies, I could, by holding my ear to it, and attentively litening,
plainly hear a crackling noie made by the agitated parts, which continued a brisk, and, as I uppoed, a vibrating motion for ome time after the friction was ended.

That there may be a coniderable Commotion produced among the internal parts of bodies, by rubbing them even againt oft bodies, I have divers times oberved, by the ulphureous teams that I could mell, if, after having a little rubbed a lump of good Sulphur upon my Cloaths, I preently held it to my noe. Which brings into my mind, that I have had the like effect from much harder and cloer bodies than Sulphur, when they were rubbed upon bodies that were o too. For having purpoely taken hard Stones cut out of mens Bladders, and rubbed a couple of them a little againt one another, they quickly afforded, as I expected, a rank mell of tale Urin.

That Diamonds themelves will, by rubbing upon woollen cloaths, be made Electrical, eems to argue, that
even Their parts are et a moving: And that the Commotion reaches to the internal parts, I am the more apt to think, becaue I have a Diamond, that, if I rub it well and luckily againt my Cloaths, will, for a little while, hine or glimmer in the dark; which is the ame Phaenomenon that I elewhere relate my elf to have produced in the King's larger Diamond, by giving it one brisk troke with the point of a bodkin, where the Light that preently appeared in the Gem, eemed not referrable to any thing o likely as the udden Commotion made in the internal parts of that peculiarly contituted Stone.

What a peculiar modification of motion, ditinct from its degrees of Impetus, may doe in Fluid bodies, we have formerly in this Eay taken notice of. But perhaps it may be worth while to enquire, what kinds there are of it, and what effects they may have in the parts of Solid bodies themelves. For I have oberved,
that though thoe Stones that the Italian Glas-men ue are very hard, and, if I miremember not, have everal times afforded me parks of fire by Colliion; yet, by rubbing them a little one againt another, I found, that uch an agitation was made in their parts, as to make them throw out tore of foetid exhalations: And 'tis poibly to the tony Ingredient that Glas owes the Quality I have oberved in it, and elewhere mentioned, of emitting offenive teams. And 'tis remarkable to our preent purpoe, that, though o vehement an agitation of the parts, as is given to Glas by Heat, when 'tis made almot red-hot in the fire, does not make it enibly emit odours; yet barely by dextrouly rubbing two olid pieces of Glas againt one another, one may, in a minute of an hour, make thoe fixed bodies emit uch copious teams as I found, not onely enibly, but rankly, foetid; though one would think thoe tinking exhalations very indipoed to be forced off, ince they
were not expelled by the vehement fire, that the Glas long endured in the furnace where 'twas kept melted.

There are few things that hew better, both how the parts of Inorganical bodies communicate their vibrating motions to one another, and how brisk thoe motions are, than that which happens upon the triking of a large Bell with a Clapper or a Hammer. For though the troak be immediately made but upon one part; yet the motion, thereby produced, is propagated to the oppoite, and the ucceive vibrations of the mall parts do, even in o olid and cloe a body as Bell-metal, run many times round; as may appear by the durablenes of the ringing noie, which eems plainly to proceed from the circularly ucceive vibrations of the parts, which, unles they briskly tremble themelves, can carcely be conceived to be fitted to give the Air that tremulous motion, whoe effect on the Ear, when the firt and
loud noie, made by the percuion, is pat, we call Ringing. And this motion of the parts of the ounding Bell may be further argued by this, that, if the finger, or ome other oft body, be laid upon it, the ound will be checked or deaded, and much more, if a broad tring, though of a oft ubtance, be tied about it. And not onely an attentive Ear may often make us gues, that the ringing ound is produced by a motion propagated circularly in the Bell, but this vibrating motion may ometimes be alo felt by the tremulous motion communicated by the trembling parts of the Bell to the finger, that is warily applied to it. That this motion paes in a round, from one ide of the Bell to the other, eems manifet by the great difference of ound, epecially in regard of ringing, that may be oberved in a ound Bell, and in a crack'd one; where yet all the matter and the former figure are preerved, onely the intirenes or continuity, which is neceary to the circulation
(if I may o call it) of the tremulous motion, is at the Crack topt or hindred. And that the motion of the parts is very brisk, may be gueed partly by what has been aid already; but much more if that be true, which, not onely is traditionally reported by many, but has been affirmed to me by everal Artificers that deal in Bells, who averred, as an experienced thing, That if a conveniently ized Bell were bound about, any thing hard, with a broad tring, and then truck with the uual force, that it would otherwie bear very well; that percuion would break it, giving a diorderly check to the brisk motion of the parts of the Bell, whereof ome happening to be much more (and otherwie) agitated than others, the force of their motion urmounts that of their Coheion, and o produces a Crack.

But, in regard great Bells are not eaie to be procured, nor to be managed when one has accee to them, I hall add, that I took the Bell of a
large Watch, or very mall Clock made of fine Bell-metall, which had no handle or other thing put to it, ave a little Bodkin or skiver of wood, whoe point we thrut into the hole that is uually left in the middle of the Bais; and this harp piece of wood erving for a handle to keep the Bell teady enough, we placed in the cavity of it, near the edges, (for that Circumtance mut not be omitted,) ome black mineral Sand, or, in want of that, ome mall filings of Steel or Copper, or ome other uch minute and olid Powder, which yet mut not be too mall, and then triking moderately with the Key againt the ide of the Bell, we oberved, (as we expected) that, whilt it continued briskly ringing, it made many of the filings to dance up and down, and ometimes to leap up, almot like the drops of Water, formerly mentioned to skip, when the brim of the Glas was circularly pret by the wetted finger. Which prompts me to add, that, having put a middleized
drop of water (for in this cae the quantity is a coniderable Circumtance) near the lower edge of the Bell, 'twas eaie to make it viibly tremble, and be as it were covered over with little waves, by a omewhat brisk troke of the Key on the oppoite ide. And this effect was more conpicuous, when a very large drop of water was placed near the edge, on the convex ide of a hand-Bell, whoe Clapper was kept from any where touching the inide of it. And to obviate their jealouie, that, not having een the manner of the above-mentioned motion of the Sand, might upect that 'twas produced by the impule which the Bell, as an intire body, received from the percuion made by the Key, we everal times forbare putting-in the filings, till after the troke had been given; which atisfied the Spectatours, that the dancing and leaping of the minute bodies proceeded from the ame drisk vibrations of the mall parts of the Bell, which, at the ame time
triking alo the Air, produced a ringing ound, which might very well, as it did, out-lat the skipping of the filings; the exceedingly minute particles of the Air being much more eaily agitable, than the comparatively gros and heavy Corpucles of the Powder. And this ucces our Experiment had in a Bell, that little exceeded an inch and half in Diameter.

And here, Pyroph. I hall put an end to this Rhapody of Obervations, hoping, that, among o many of them, ome or other will be able to engage you, if not to conclude, yet at leat to upect, that uch Local motions, as are wont either to be pat-by unoberved, or be thought not worth the oberving, may have a notable operation, though not upon the generality of bodies, yet upon uch as are peculiarly dipoed to admit it, and o may have a coniderable hare in the production of divers difficult Phaenomena of nature, that are wont to be referred to les genuine, as well as les intelligible, Caues.
AN Experimental Dicoure Of ome UNHEEDED CAUSES OF THE Inalubrity and Salubrity OF THE AIR, Being a Part of an intended Natural Hitory of AIR.
LONDON, Printed by M. Fleher, for Richard Davis, Bookeller in Oxford. 1685.

div.head: THE Preface.
div.p:
HAving heretofore had occaion to draw together under certain Heads, divers unpublih'd Obervations and Experiments of my own, and ome of other men, by way of Memorials for a Natural Hitory of the Air; I thought fit by more largely treating of two or three of the Subjects ditinctly mention'd in my Scheme of Titles, to give a Semplar or Specimen of what may be done upon the other Heads of the deigned Hitory. pon this account
I treated omewhat largely of the Salubrity and Inalubrity of the Air, as a Subject, which for the importance of it to Mens healths and lives, I thought deerv'd to be attentively conider'd, and have its Caues diligently inquir'd into. And having oberv'd that among the ix principal Caues of the healthfulnes or inalubrity of the Air, namely the Climate, the Soil, the Situation of the Place, the Seaons of the Year, the raigning winds and Contingencies (whether more or les frequent) and epecially Subterraneal Steams, having I ay oberv'd that among thee Caues there was one, viz. the lat nam'd, about which, I thought I could offer omething, that I had not met with in the Books of Phyicians that treat of it; I was thereby invited to et down my Thoughts and Obervations by way of Conjectures, which I was made to believe would appear uncommon, and
would not prove ueles. Thee Obervations and Reflexions I referr'd for clearnes and ditinctions ake to four Propoitions. But when I had gone thorough the three firt, and made ome progres in the fourth, being hinder'd by divers Avocations to make an end of it, I laid by the whole Dicoure in a place which I thought a afe one, but when afterwards I had ome opportunity to dipatch what remain'd, I found all the diligence I us'd to retrieve the entire Manucript unuccesfull. At this urprizing Accident I confes I was omewhat troubled; becaue whatever may be thought of the dicurive part of thoe Papers, the Hitorical part contain'd divers matters of Fact, that I did not meet with in Books, nor can now ditinctly remember, and will not perhaps be lighted on by even Phyicians, or uch Naturalits as derive their knowledge onely
from them. 'Tis upon this conideration, that having afterwards met with many Papers that belong'd to mot parts of the unhappy dicoure, I thought fit to put them together in the bet order I could, that I might not looe what might give ome light to o important a Subject as the Theory of Dieaes. And this coure I the rather pitch'd upon, becaue before the Papers about the Salubrity of the Air, I mis'd two other of my Manucripts, whereof the former contain'd a Cellection of Medicinal things, and the econd a defence of the Mechanical way of Philoophizing about Natural Things, as it repects Religion. And I remember'd that having formerly lot a Manucript I was much concern'd for, I purpoely made a noie of it, whence I uppos'd the Plagiary would conclude himelf unable to make it pas for his. And in effect
the Book was in a while after privately brought back, o that I found it laid in a By-place, where I had before as fruitlely as carefully ought it.

div.head: AN Experimental Dicoure Of ome Unheeded CAUSES OF THE Inalubrity and Salubrity OF THE AIR, &c.
div.p:
THE ixth and lat thing upon which the Salubrity and Inalubrity of the Air depends, is the impregnation it receives from Subterraneal Effluvia. And, though this be a caue not wont to be much heeded by Phyicians themelves; yet I take it to be oftentimes one of
the mot coniderable in its effects.

The Effluvia that pas into the Air, may be ditinguih'd into everal orts, according to their repective Natures, as has been elewhere hewn; wherefore I hall now only take notice of the differences that may be taken from place and time; upon which account we may conider, that ome of them arie from the Crut (if I may o call it) or more uperficial parts of the Earth; and others have a deeper Original, acending out of the lower parts, and as it were Bowels, of the Terraqueous Globe. And to this difference taken from place, I mut add another, perhaps no les coniderable, afforded by Time; which difference relates chiefly to the econd ort of Steams newly mentioned.

Of the Subterraneal Effluvia, ome are almot contantly or daily ent up into the Air, and thoe I therefore call Ordinary Emiions; and others acend into the Air but at times, which are not eldom ditant
enough from one another, and thoe I call Extraordinary Emiions; whether they come at tated times, and o deerve the title of Periodical, or ele uncertainly, ometimes with far greater, ometimes with far maller intervals, and o may be called fortuitous or irregular. But, though I thought it might render what I am about to ay more clear, if I made and premied the two foregoing ditinctions, yet becaue in many caes, Nature does not appear olicitous to oberve them, but at the ame time imbues the Air with Steams referable to divers Members of thee ditinctions, I hall everal times, though not always, take the liberty to imitate her, and conider the Effluvia of the Terraqueous Globe, in the more general Notion, that they are o.

I know 'tis frequently oberved, and uually granted, that Marrih Grounds, and wet Soils are wont to be unhealthfull, becaue of the moit and crude vapours, that the tagnating
waters end up too copiouly into the Air. And on the other ide, dry Soils are, becaue of their being uch, generally lookt upon as healthy. Nor do I deny, that thee Obervations do mot commonly hold true; but yet I think, that beides what can be jutly acribed to the moit vapours, or dry Exhalations, we have been peaking of; in many places the healthfulnes and inalubrity of the Air may be acribed to other orts of Effluvia from the Soil, than thoe that act merely, or perhaps principally, as thee are either moit or dry.

div.head: PROPOSITION I.
div.p:
TO deliver my Thoughts about this matter omewhat more ditinctly, I hall lay them down in the four enuing Obervations or Propoitions, whereof the firt hall be this: It eems probable that in divers places, the Salubrity or Inalubrity of the Air conidered in the general, may
be in good part due to ubterraneal Expirations, epecially to thoe that I lately call'd Ordinary Emiions. For in ome places the Air is oberv'd to be much more healthy, than the manifet qualities of it would make one expect: and in divers of thee Caes I ee no Caue to which uch a happy Contitution, may more probably be acrib'd, than to friendly Effluvia ent up from the Soil into the Air; which Particles either by promoting tranpiration (that great intrument of health and recovery;) or by hindering the production, or checking the Activity, of Morbifick ferments; or by mortifying and diabling ome noxious Particles, that would otherwie infet the Air, or by other ways, that I hall not now tay to enumerate; may not a little contribute to keep the Bodies of thoe that live in that Air, in that regular and deirable tate, we call Health. I know indeed that 'tis generally thought, and often true, that Mineral Bodies do
end up Exhalations, hurtfull not only to Plants, but to Men; but when we mean Subterraneal things indefinitely, though (Men are wont to look upon them but lightly under a general confued Notion) we employ a word more comprehenive than mot men are aware of, there being a great variety, as well as multitude of Bodies, that Nature has lodg'd in her dark Store-houes under the urface of the Earth. And of thee differing orts of Bodies, though 'tis probable that the greatet part are uch whoe Effluvia are unhealthfull to Men, yet there may be others whoe Emanations may be friendly to him; I have known it oberv'd that over ome Tin Mines in the Wetern parts of England, not only Trees, but far more tender Plants, as Gras, are wont to proper and flourih, and (if I much miremember not) I have een verdent Trees growing jut over a vein of another ort of Mineral, that lay near the urface of the Earth: And 'tis
likewie obervable about thoe that contantly dig in thoe Tin-Mines, that they do not lead a hort and ickly life as in many others, but arrive at a great and vigorous Age. And an Ancient Poeor of ome of thee Mines being askt by me, whether amongt the otherwie differing Exhalations that acended into the Air, he did not find a difference as to mell bad or good; he anwer'd, that though mot of thoe viible fumes had a mell that participated enough of Sulphur or Bitumen to be offenive, yet ome others were o far from being ungratefull, that they were well cented. And on this occaion I remember, that not long ince, a Friend of mine, and another Virtuoo, being Partners in a chargeable Attempt to dicover a Mine, in digging deep for it, they accidentally broke into a vat Subterraneal Cavern, into which, becaue the Diggers would not venture to decend, one of thee curious Gentlemen caued himelf to be
let down, and there found the Air very temperate and refrehing, and that he long breath'd it with delight, and on the floor, or Soil (which reach'd farther than he could dicover) he found many and various Minerals mot of them embryonated, or imperfectly form'd, and tore of a kind of Mineral Earth, whoe mell was fragrant and very pleaant both in his Judgment, and that of ome Ladies. And though, when ome of thoe Minerals were brought to me, a mall lump of this Earth that was among them, had been kept o long in the Air, as to pend mot of its Odoriferous Particles, yet the mell it till retain'd, was, though but faint, yet pleaing.

That from Foiles that lye hid under the urface of the Earth, and have a coniderably large Spread, there may acend tore of wholome Effluvia into the Air, eem'd to me the more probable by what I noted at my lat being in Ireland, where, being invited by a Brother of mine
to pas ome time in a Countrey houe of his, to which there belong'd a very large Sheep-walk that produc'd hort, but excellent Gras; I learn'd (and was eaily perwaded by ome things I took notice of) that this place was jutly reputed very healthfull, and this Salubrity of the Air, together with the weetnes of the Gras, ome circumtances invited me to acribe to this; That the Soil was utain'd by a large tract of Limetone, which I uppos'd to emit continual exhalations into the Air; which conjecture will perhaps with the les cruple be aented to, if I add that it has been long and generally oberv'd, that as far as the Limetone extends, that tract of ground makes the Snow that falls on it thaw, or melt much ooner, than it does on the Neighbouring Lands.

After I had made this Obervation, I mention'd it in dicoure to an inquiitive Peron, that had een and been employed about everal Mines; and I asked him whether he had met
with any thing of this kind; to which he anwer'd me, that in Derbyhire, at a place which he nam'd to me, he and others had oberv'd, that a large tract of Limetone land was o warm (as they peak) as to diolve the Snow that fell on it, very much ooner than another great cope of Land, which was divided from it but by a glin, where the Soil did not cover Limetone, but Freetone.

Afterwards, dicouring of this Subject with an ingenious Peron, that had viited the Hungarian, and Bohemian Mines; he told me, that during his tay among the former, he often walked abroad with the Overeer of them, a famous and experienc'd Mineralit, who delighted to breathe the freh morning Air upon ome Hills abounding with Minerals; that his Guide made him oberve, that when they were over a tract of Land that afforded much of that noble Oar (which by a German Name he called Rot-gulden ertz) he
found the mell to be pleaing, and the Air refrehing. And whereas, in paing over ome other Mines, he found himelf moleted by offenive fumes; he felt no uch effect, when he was upon that cope of ground under which there lay veins of Cinnabar, or, if you pleae, a Mine of Quick-ilver Our: And his ancient Guide told him, that next the Rotgulden ertz before mentioned, the Soil containing thee Cinnabarine veins, was that whoe incumbent Air was the mot eligible for pleaantnes and Salubrity. And I the les wonder, that in ome places the ubjacent Foiles hould impregnate the Air with wholome Effluvia, becaue I remember I had the Curioity to ride many Miles, (though in the depth of Winter,) to ee a cope of ground that was famous for a good Pottery; where, beides many other Mineral Earths that I took notice of, there was a Pit or Groove, that reach'd, if I mitake not, fifteen or twenty foot beneath the urface of the
ground; whence they dug up a kind of white Clay, o richly impregnated with ubtile and noble parts, that it afforded a Chymit or two of my Acquaintance (for I had my elf no opportunity to ditill it) good tore of a Subtile Spirit, of a Volatile and Saline Nature, which upon trial they highly extoll'd for it's Cordial, and other Virtues in Phyick; and which, by ome peculiar Mechanical trials I made with it, I concluded to abound with a Volatile Salt, not unlike that of Urine or Harthorn. And ince by this intance we ee, that ome unupected Foiles may be enrich'd with Medicinal and Fugitive Salts and Spirits; it may reaonably be uppos'd, that thee acending into the incumbent Air, may highly conduce to the Salubrity of it. And the Curioity I have had to examine Chymically ome Boles, and other Bodies, which are wont to be unregardedly compriz'd under the confus'd notion of Earths, makes me upect,
that there may be far more Species of Salubrious Foiles than many have yet taken notice of.

But peradventure you will much the more eaily admit in general, that Subterraneal Tracts of great extent may for a very long time end up into the Air copious Expirations, not dicernable by any of ourenes, nor commonly upected to be found in that Body, if you pleae to conider with me (what I do not remember to have been taken notice of to this purpoe) that the common Air we live in, and breathe, does always abound, and for many Ages has been impregnated, with the Copious Magnetical Effluvia of the Earth; which our indutrious Gilbert, and after him ome learned Jeuits and others, have proved to be a great, though faint Magnet; and whoe emanations, as they contantly tream through the Air, I have elewhere by particular Experiments hewn to be capable of paing through the Pores of Glas it elf, and acting almot intantaneouly,
and yet manifetly, upon Bodies hermetically eal'd up in it. But, though from what has been aid it may be inferr'd, that 'tis not improbable the Salubrity of the Air in ome places may be chiefly, or at leat in part, due to the wholome Expirations of Subterraneal Bodies; yet, generally peaking, the Air is deprav'd, in far more places than it is improv'd, by being impregnated with Mineral Expirations. And indeed, beides that, among the Minerals known unto us, there are many more that are noxious, than that are wholome; the power of the former to doe michief is wont to be far more efficacious, than that of the latter to doe good; as we may gues by the mall benefit men receive in point of health by the Effluvia of any Mineral, or other Foile, known unto us, in comparion of the great and udden michief that is often done by the Expirations of Orpiment, Sandarach, and white Arenick; for, though that old in Shops
is factitious, being made of Orpiment ublim'd with Salt, yet it is found Natural in ome Hungarian, and other Mines. On which occaion, I remember that the ingenious Peron lately mention'd to have with his Guide taken the Air upon the Hills of that Mineral Countrey, anwer'd me, that, when his Guide and he walk'd over ome veins of thee noxious Minerals, he met with everal Odorous Steams, which, though differing from one another, agreed in this, that they were all offenive to him; and particularly, ome of them by their unwelcome harpnes, and others by giving him a troubleome difficulty of repiration. I will not here urge thoe ulphureous teams, that o uddenly deprive Dogs of ene and motion, in the Neapolitan Grotta de Cani; becaue there the Exhalations are too much included, and as it were pent up: But it is very proper to allege for my preent purpoe the Aorni or Averni, which are mention'd
by good Authours to be found, ome in Hungary, and ome in other Countries; for in thee places there acend out of the Earth uch noxious and plentifull exhalations, as kill thoe Animals that draw in the Air they infect; and ome of them are able to precipitate, even the Birds that fly over the Caverns that emit them. But there are a multitude of Places, where 'tis not o manifet that hurtfull exhalations acend into the Air, and yet they really do o: There being in many places whole tracts of Land, that near the urface of the Earth abound with Marchaitical Minerals, as thee do with a harp vitriolate Salt, which, together with the ill condition'd Sulphur that they alo plentifully contain, acend into the Air, and render it corroive. On which occaion I remember, that for Curioities ake I took ome Englih hining Marchaite; and caus'd a pound of it to be ditill'd in an Earthen Veel with a good fire, by which means, notwithtanding it's
drynes, I obtain'd two or three poonfuls of a Limpid Liquor, that mell'd very trongly, like that which the Helmontians call Gas Sulphuris; and which appear'd manifetly to be of an acid Nature, both by the tate, and by it's readily corroding, and diolving unbeaten Coral, even in the cold, to mention here no other Tryals that I made with it. And the Mineral afforded me, together with this Liquor, about an ounce and three quarters of inflammable Sulphur, part whereof acending (as may be gues'd) in the form of very agile Corpucles, thee faten themelves all about to the inide of the Receiver, and there compos'd divers thin Coats, or Films, as 'twere, of Sulphureous matter ticking to one another; which at their firt taking off, and for ome time after, might be bent or folded like leaves of paper, but afterwards harden in the Air. Mineralits, and ome other good Authours, mention divers Places as abounding with Marchasitical
Foiles, but I am apt to think, they are far more common than is vulgarly taken notice of; for I have met with them where one would little expect them. And, though in England all our Vitriol (which is now plentifully vended into Foreign parts) be made of Vitriolate Stones, or Bodies that pas for tones; yet that is not true which our Mineralits are wont thence to conclude, that there is no other Vitriolate or Marchaitical matter in England: for a famous dealer in Foiles, having found a Mine, which he knew not what to make of, and therefore carefully conceal'd, addres'd himelf to me, becaue, he aid, he knew I would not betray or upplant him: and having at his deire taken a private view of what he had dicover'd, I preently found it to be a vein, that lay at ome depth under ground, and ran along (how far I know not) like a vein of Metalline Oar, (and for uch upon that account he mitook it) coniting of
a black and heavy tuff, which upon a few eaie trials I quickly found to be of a Vitriolate Nature; inomuch that, omewhat to my wonder, I was able to make it yield in few hours tore of pure Vitriol, without any troubleome or artificial preparation.

div.head: PROPOSITION II.

argument.p: It is probable that in divers places ome Endemical Dieaes do mainly, or at leat in part depend upon Subterraneal Steams.

div.p:
UNder the name of Endemical Dieaes, I do not comprie thoe onely that are very peculiar to this or that Countrey; as the Plica is aid to be to Poland, (whence it receives its name of Polonica;) or an odd kind of Colique in one part of France, (from which 'tis called la Colique de Poictou;) but alo thoe that are more rie in ome Countries
than in mot others; uch as Agues in Kent, and in that part of Eex they call the Hundreds; the Conumption (though that be an ambiguous name) in England, whence Foreign Phyicians call it the Tabes Anglica; and Fluxes of the Belly in Ireland, where they are o rie as commonly to pas under the name of the Countrey Dieae.

That thee Endemical, or (if we may o call them) Topical Ditempers, do in many places proceed from ome exceive Heat, Moiture, or other manifet quality of the Air; from bad Diet, vulgar Intemperance, and other Caues that have little or no connexion with Subterraneal Reeks, I readily grant. But, that in ome places the Endemical Dieae may either be principally caus'd, or much fomented, by noxious Effluvia, I am enclin'd to upect upon the following grounds.

list.item:
1. There are ome places, in which the Endemical Dieae cannot be probably imputed to any manifet
Caue; as he may perceive that hall conider how often it happens, that the Caues which are aign'd of uch Dieaes, if they were the true ones, mut produce the like Ditempers in many other places, where yet it is notorious that they are not Endemical.
2. That Subterraneal Bodies may end up copious Steams, of different kinds, into the Air, has been already made out.

3. It has been alo hewn, that the Matters that end up thee Effluvia, may be of a large extent. And I remember on this occaion that I have ometimes oberv'd, and that in more Countries than one, a whole tract of Land that abounded with Minerals of one kind; and within no great ditance, as perhaps a Mile or a League, another large tract of Land, whoe Subterraneal part abounded with Minerals of a very differing ort.

4. We have alo above declar'd, and 'tis highly probable from the
nature of the thing it elf, that thoe copious teams (Saline, Sulphureous, Arenical, Antimonial, &c.) that impregnate the Air, may very much conduce to make it hurtfull to a humane body, in the way requiite to produce this or that determinate Dieae: as I not long ince related from the Chymit that viited the Hungarian Mines, that in ome places he found the Reeks acending from them into the Air (though in an elevated place, and expos'd to the Winds) make him as it were Athmatical, and give him a troubleome difficulty of Repiration. And here let me add an Obervation, which perhaps will not be thought fit to be lighted by Phyicians: namely, that ome parts of the ubtance of the Air (for I peak not of its Heat, Coldnes, or other uch Qualities) do not onely affect humane bodies, or at leat many Individuals among them, as they are taken in by Repiration, but as they outwardly touch the Skin: and the
Skin being (as I have elewhere hewn) full of Pores, and thoe perhaps of different izes and figures, thoe Corpucles that get in at them may have their operation, even upon the mot inward parts of the body. To make this more clear and probable, becaue 'tis a thing of importance, I deire thee things may be oberv'd.

div.p:
1. That when I peak of the Air, I do not in this place undertand that Air, which I elewhere teach to be more trictly and properly o call'd, and to conit of pringy Particles; but the Air in its more vulgar and laxe ignification, as it ignifies the Atmophere, which abounds with vapours, and exhalations, and in a word with Corpucles of all orts, except the larger ort of pringy ones; and many of them may be o mall, and o olid, or o conveniently hap'd, as to get entrance at ome of the numerous Orifices of the minute or miliary Glandules of the Skin, or at other Pores of it.
Thus, though paper be not pervious to the uncompres'd elatical parts of the Air, yet it may be eaily penetrated by other Corpucles of the Atmophere: for I remember, I have for Curioities ake prepar'd a dry body, out of a ubtance belonging to the Animal Kingdom, which being lapt up in paper, would, without wetting or dicolouring, or any way enibly altering it, pas in a trice through the Pores of it in uch plenty, as to have not onely a viible, but a manifet operation on bodies plac'd at ome ditance from it. And though a bladder almot full of Air, having its neck well tyed, be held near the fire in various potures, the elatical Air, though rarefied, or attenuated by the heat, will rather burt the bladder, (as I have more than once found) than get out at the Pores, yet we have often made a certain ubtance, belonging to the Mineral Kingdom, that, if a bladder were wet or moit, (as the Skins of living Men are wont to be) would readily
pervade it, and have a enible operation, even upon olid bodies plac'd within it. This Experiment (that I can repeat when I will) is therefore the more coniderable to our preent purpoe, becaue in the bladder of a dead Animal, the Poroity may be well uppos'd to be much les than it was in the Animal when alive; in which tate the parts of the humane body are much more perpirable than one would eaily believe, partly becaue of the heat that is continually diffus'd from the heart, and partly becaue of the copious teams that are in perpetual motion, and keep the parts warm, moit and upple: And it is not to be pretermitted in our preent intance, that the bladder of Urine conits not of a ingle Membrane, and is probably of a tronger texture, by reaon of the ubtile alt liquor it is intituted to contain, than many another Membranes of the body, or the Epidermis. And this is the firt thing I would have noted.

The next is, that, whereas in the Intances newly recited, and ome others that are by and by to be mention'd, the effects were produc'd when the ambient Air, impregnated with Mineral Corpucles, had but a very hort time (perhaps not many minutes) to work upon the bodies expos'd to it: In thoe Countries that are very ubject to Endemical Dieaes, the Inhabitants are wont to live all the year long, and perhaps during their whole life, expos'd to the action of the vitiated Air: and how much a far horter time will erve, to make the Corpucles that rove in the Air, penetrate into bodies of no very cloe contexture, may be gues'd by the breaking even of the bigger trings of Lutes and Vials, by the numerous (though inviible) vapours, that get into them in rainy weather; and much more by the effects of uch vapours, when ininuating themelves in warms into the Pores of a Rope, they horten it o forcibly, as to enable it, by hrinking
it elf to lift up and keep upended coniderable weights, as I have elewhere hewn by tryals purpoely made. Thee things may render it probable, that, though in a mall compas of time the noxious Effluvia that rove in the Air, may be too thinly dipers'd in it, to ininuate themelves in any coniderable number at the Pores of the Skin; yet, by reaon of the continual contact of the Air, (epecially as to the Face, Hands, and ome other parts) which may lat day and night for many months, or perhaps years, there may be opportunity for a coniderable number of morbifick Particles, to ininuate themelves into the cutaneous Pores.

3. And thus having once got entrance, they may by the capillary Veels that reach to, or terminate at the Skin, pas on to omewhat larger Veels; and o may get into the mas of bloud, and by its Circulation be carried to all the parts of the body; and o be enabl'd both to
deprave the bloud, and other juices themelves, and to gain acces to any determinate part of the body, which their peculiar hapes, figures, &c. qualifies them to produce ome particular Ditemper in. This whole Doctrine may be made more probable, by what experience hews of the virtues of certain Platers, epecially Mercurial ones, in Ditempers that are not at all, or at leat are not chiefly Cutaneous; and (which comes more home to our Argument) of the efficacy of Periaptae, and Appena, uch as Piony-root, Bloud-tone, Lapis Nephriticus, Quick-ilver in a Quill, a dry'd Toad in a Cenet Bag, &c, whereof, though many anwer not the Characters that are wont to be given of them, yet ome of them, experience has convinc'd me to be of greater efficacy than I expected: And much more activity may be preum'd to be, in divers noxious Effluvia from Subterraneal Bodies; as may be gather'd from the effects of the Mercurial Girdles, that ome unwary
perons wear to cure the Itch; and from what I elewhere relate of the fits of the Colicque, often produc'd in a Friend of mine by the Effluvia of maes of Loadtone. And this lat example may erve for a proof of another part of our Hypotheis, by hewing that Mineral Effluvia, may not onely be noxious in a general way, but may produce this or that determinate Dieae. That Arenical Appena, though much extoll'd by divers Phyicians themelves, and old dear by Empyricks, as (if worn near the Heart) wonderfull Amulets againt the Plague, have (epecially in ome perons and circumtances) produc'd ome of the noxious effects of Arenical Poyons, and particularly caus'd in ome great faintnes and dipiritednes, I find by the Tetimony of divers eminent Phyicians. To which I hall add a remarkable one, which may probably be referr'd partly to this third Obervation, as well as to what I lately deliver'd about the bad effects
of Mineral Exhalations, breath'd in with the Air they vitiated: and I the rather mention this Cae, becaue 'tis not onely an odd one, but is a coniderable Argument to hew, that noxious Mineral Expirations may manifetly produce a determinate Ditemper in unlikely parts of the body. The Obervation is this; I knew, and on ome occaions employ'd, a Chymical Laborant that fani'd that he could make a rare Medicine out of red Arenick, (as ome call what others tyle Sandarach,) which is thought to differ little from common Orpiment, aving its being much higher colour'd: this Laborant then working long and aiduouly upon this Mineral, and rubbing it frequently in a Mortar, came divers times to me; and complain'd of a diaffection he thence contracted in the Organs of Repiration; for which I gave him omething that happen'd to relieve him; which encourag'd him to complain to me of another Ditemper, that, though
not o dangerous, did often very much molet him: which was, that when he was very aiduous in the preparation of his Sandarach, it would give him great Pains, and (if I miremember not) ome Tumours too, in his Teticles: And this, for ought I know, happen'd to him as long as he was earnet about that Proces; for the Medicines that had reliev'd him in his other Ditemper, did not remove this: and I having occaion to go for a while into the Countrey, found him gone at my return. It may trengthen the Conjecture lately propos'd, of the poible ininuation of Effluvia that rove in the Air, at the Pores of the Skin, if I add that I have had the Curioity to enquire of more than one Traveller, that had viited the famous Pico of Tenarif (at whoe upper part there are found catter'd parcels of Sulphur, and divers manifet tokens of a Vulcan) whether the Sulphureous Steams (that I uppos'd to be copious near the top of the
Mountain) did not work upon the ilver Money they had in their Pockets, and dicolour it: to which he anwer'd that 'twas no uncommon Obervation, to find at mens return from viiting the top of the Hill, that the Money they carried about them was blackn'd, and that he himelf had particularly oberv'd it to be o: which might eaily gain credit with me, who have divers times made a preparation of Sulphur, which, even in the cold, ends out exhalations o penetrant, that, having for tryals ake put ome pieces of Coyn (which ought not to be Golden) into a Leather Pure; they were able, and that in not very many minutes, to dicolour manifetly the Money, in pite of the interpoition of the Pure that contain'd it. But I had a more coniderable intance of the efficacy of the Sulphureous Expirations of the Pico of Tenarif, by a ober Peron that is one of the chief Directours of the famous Eat-India-Company of London; who,
being quetion'd by me about ome circumtances of his Journey to viit the top of that tupendious Mountain, anwer'd me, that among other effects the Sulphureous Air had upon him, (who is of a very fine complexion) he found at his return to the bottom, that his light-colour'd Hair had manifetly changed colour, and was in many places grown forked at the ends. Thee Obervations may make it probable, that Mineral Exhalations may not only affect humane Bodies, as they are drawn into the Lungs with the Air they wim in, but as they ininuate themelves into the Pores of the Skin.

One coniderable Objection I foreee may be made, againt the Propoition I have been all this while endeavouring to render probable; namely, that 'tis carce conceivable, that in o many Ages as Endemical Dieaes have afflicted ome Countries, the Subterraneal Matter, to which I do in great part impute ome of them, hould not be
wated and pent. I might perhaps on this occaion move a doubt, whether we have had uch continued accounts of the temperature of the Air, of all the Countries where Dieaes are now Endemical, as to know that they have been always o; and that ome of thoe Dieaes have not been worn out here or there, and ome others have not of later Ages begun to appear in this or that place. But contenting my elf at preent to have hinted this Quetion, I hall not tay to dicus it; but proceed to offer three things, by way of direct anwer to the Objection.

1. And firt, I think it very poible, that divers Subterraneal Bodies that emit Effluvia, may have in them a kind of propagative or elf multiplying power: I will not here examine, whether this proceed from ome eminal Principle, which many Chymits and others acribe to Metals, and even to tones, or (which is perhaps more likely) to omething analagous to a Firment, uch as in
Vegetables enables a little our dough to extend it elf through the whole Mas; or uch, as when an Apple or Pear is bruis'd in one part, makes the putrify'd part by degrees to tranmute the ound into it's own likenes; or ele ome maturative power, whereby an inanimate Body may gradually admit of uch a change, or acquire uch Qualities, as may be in Mens etimate perfective of it, and perhaps give it a new denomination; as Anana's in the Indies, and Medlars, and ome other fruits here in Europe, do after they are gathered, acquire (as it were, pontaneouly) in proces of time, a conitence and weetnes, and ometimes Colour and Odour, and in hort uch a tate as by one word we call maturity or ripenes: and o ome Metalline Ores, and ome Mineral Earths themelves, have been oberv'd by Mineralogits, to acquire in tract of time uch a change, as to afford ome Metal or other Body, which either it did not afford before, or at leat did not afford
o copiouly, or o well qualify'd. This I have purpoely made out in another Paper: and the Obervation particularly holds as to Niter, which is thought to be the mot Catholick Foile we have; and to be at leat one of thoe Foiles, that do the mot plentifully emit Effluvia into the Air.

2. When I conider, that even in thoe Mines that are accounted deep ones, the Spades of Men are not wont to reach to the ten thouandth part of the thicknes of the Earth, between its Surface, and its Centre, which yet is but its Semi-diametre; I cannot but confes, that we know very little of the Nature or Contitution of the lower part of the Terretrial Globe; ince we know little or nothing experimentally, of what lyes beneath that Comparatively very thin Crut or Scurf, (if I may o call it) that Humane Indutry has been hitherto confin'd to. And upon this account I do not think it aburd to upect, that from the lower Subterraneal
Regions there may be, either continually, or periodically, emitted into the Region of Mines (if I may o call it) great tore, and variety of Mineral Exhalations, which may continually repair the los of thoe, that from time to time acend out of the Foile Region (as I may alo call that of Mines) into the Atmophere. But the things I could alledge to Countenance this Conjecture, mut not be inited on in this place. Therefore I proceed to conider.

3. That Bodies o heavy, and conequently o abundant in parts of olid matter crouded together, as Minerals, and other Foiles are wont to be, may well be uppos'd capable, without detructively wating themelves to emit tore of uch minute Particles as Effluvia, for an exceeding long time. This will be eaily granted by him that hall conider the particulars laid together in a mall Tract, that I purpoely writ, about the admirable Subtilty
of Effluvia. And 'twill be the more eaily believ'd, if it be conider'd how long ome Load-tones, ever'd from their Mine, have been kept in the Air without any notable, or perhaps o much as enible diminution of their Virtue. And this brings into my mind what an eminent Phyician, who was skill'd in Perfumes, affirm'd to me about the durablenes of an Effluviating power, that was not natural to a Metal, but adventitious, and introduc'd by Art: for he aur'd me that he had a Silver Watch-cae, that had been o well perfum'd, that though he uually wore the Watch in his Pocket, it continued to be well cented ixteen years. The ame Peron had a way of perfuming factitious Marble quite thorough, whoe grateful Scent he affirm'd would lat exceedingly; and of this perfum'd Marble he preented me a Ball, which having been ome months after gotten from me by a great Lady, I was diabled from oberving the durablenes of the fragrancy.

I might perhaps be thought wanting to my Caue, if, before I dimis the Propoition I have been all this while dicouring of, I hould not oberve, that Subterraneal Effluvia may contribute to Endemical Dieaes, not only as they vitiate the Air, that Men breathe in, or are immediately touch'd by; but as they may impregnate or deprave the Aliments that men feed upon. For firt, they do mingle themelves with the water, which either men drink it elf alone, (as is the Cutome with many Nations, and of ome men in mot Nations; or make of it their Bear, Ale, or other factitious drinks, prepar'd of Water and Barley, Oats, Rice, &c. That divers Springs, and other Waters are imbued with Mineral Corpucles, may be judg'd by ome of the Medicinal Springs: for, though divers Acidulae and Thermae afford good tore of palpable Sulphur or Salt, yet all do not; and having purpoely examin'd a famous one, I could with a pair of nice Scales
carce dicover any enible difference at all between the Medicinal Water, and the common Water that was to be met with thereabouts. And that which impregnated this, and which I found by tryal on my elf, and ome other Bodies, enabl'd it to work very manifetly like a Mineral Water, was a ort of Corpucles o minute and ubtile, that if the Bottles were not kept well topt, they would in a hort time vanih, and leave the Liquor dipirited. Experience has aur'd me, that there are ways of making common water violently and hurtfully operative upon Humane Bodies, though its enible qualities would not make one upect any change in it: but the ill ue that bad men may make of uch Liquors, makes me forbear to expres my elf more clearly: nor is it neceary that I hould add anything to confirm the propos'd conjecture, ave what may be inferr'd from thee two Particulars; the firt whereof is the carce at all enible
change that may be made in water, and ome other Liquors, that are made trongly Emetick by Crocus Metallorum, and by Antimony vitrify'd without addition: and the econd may be taken from thoe Averni, whence there continually acend uch pernicious Exhalations, as in ome places intoxicate or kill even the Birds that fly over thoe poyonous vents; for if uch Exhalations, or even far les deadly ones, hould (as they may be reaonably uppos'd, ometimes to do) meet with either running or tagnant Waters in their acent, there is little doubt to be made, but they will impregnate them, and make them noxious. And on this occaion we may pertinently recall to mind, what I have formerly deliver'd about a place upon the Borders of Lancahire, where the Water and Mud of a Ditch is o copiouly impregnated with Subterraneal Exhalations, (whether they be bituminous, ulphureous, or of ome
unknown kind) that they may eaily be fir'd at the urface of the Water, or Earth, and made to burn like a Candle, as an ingenious man did at my Requet uccesfully try.

But there is another account, upon which the Effluvia of the lower parts of the Earth may have a greater troke in producing of Endemical Dieaes; namely, as they mingle with the Water, and other Liquors that are neceary to the nutrition and growth of Plants; and, by depraving thoe juices, make the vegetables that are nourih'd by them unhealthy for the men that eat them, or make drinks of them: and thee noxious Exhalations may be uppos'd in many places to impregnate the juices of the Earth, much more copiouly than they do the running or tagnant Waters lately poken of: becaue the difficulty of pervading the Earth in their acent, may o long check them, as to make them very numerous in a mall pace, and perhaps make them convene into Bodies, o far of a Saline Nature as to
be dioluble either in common Water, or ome other Subterraneal Liquor; by whoe help, as by vehicles, they may ininuate themelves into the roots of Plants, and be thence conveyed to other parts. Divers things might be alledg'd to keep this conjecture from being improbable, if I had leiure to init on them: but I I hall now only mention two things that on this occaion come into my mind: the firt whereof is, that enquiring of a famous Chymit, who liv'd in a Countrey abounding with Mines of Vitriol, whether he did not oberve, that the Oaks growing over them were more olid, or heavy, than thoe Trees are elewhere wont to be; he anwer'd me, that he did, and that the difference was remarkable: The other is, that the parts of ome Minerals, (probably by reaon of the mallnes and olidity of the Corpucles they conit of) are capable of ininuating themelves very plentifully into the pores of growing Vegetables, without being really ubdu'd by what
Philoophers are pleas'd to call the Concocting Faculty of the Plant; and, intead of being aimilated by the Vegetable, they retain their own Mineral Nature, and upon the reces or evaporation of the juice that erv'd them for a vehicle, may ometimes dicover their being Mineral, even to an unaited Eye. For I remember I have een a piece of a Vine, that grew not far from Paris, which being broken, I perceiv'd a multitude of the internal Pores of the root, and, if I mitake not, part of the Trunk alo, to be tuff't with Corpucles of a Marchaitical Nature; as manifetly appear'd by their Colour, and their hining lutre, and alo by their weight.

There goes a Tradition among learned Men, that the leaves of Vines that grow in ome places of Hungary, whoe Mines afford Gold, are as it were gilt on the lower ide, by acending Exhalations of a Golden Nature: whether this be true or no, I hall not take upon me to determine: but I remember, that having made enquiry
about the truth of it, of a very ingenious Traveller, whoe Curioity led him to viit heedfully thoe famous Mines: he told me, that he did not remember he had oberv'd what is reported about the Leaves of the Vine: but he knew very well that at Tockay (a place that affords the famouet Wine of Hungary, and indeed the bet I have drunk) very many of the kernels of the Grapes would appear guilt over, as it were, with leaf gold. To what has been already dicours'd, may be added, that ince men are not wont to feed upon either Beats, or Birds of prey, as carnivorous Animals uually are, but upon uch as live upon Gras, or Seeds, or other vegetable ubtances, and drink nothing but fair water; the noxious exhalations that make vegetables, and water unwholome, may by their means have a very bad influence upon Sheep, Cows, Deer, Pigeons and other Animals that eed upon uch deprav'd vegetables, and drink uch noxious waters; and conequently may be very hurtfull to
thoe men that feed upon uch Animals, and may by the deprav'd aliment they afford, determine them to an Endemical Dieae, uch as that vitiated nutriment is fitted to produce.

Perhaps it will not eem improper to add on this occaion, that 'tis poible that in certain places the latent Minerals may be of uch a Nature, as that their Effluvia may, intead of promoting, hinder the Production of ome particular Dieae, whether Epidemical or Endemical in the Bodies of them that inhabit thoe Places. For as Phyicians oberve that the more manifet morbifick caues of ome icknees, are quite contrary to thoe of others, o I think it not improbable, that there may alo be a mutual contrariety, between thoe latent morbifick caues, that are ent up by ubterraneal Agents. And therefore it need to be no wonder, if ome of thee hould either diable thoe to which they are Hotile, or hould at leat work in Humane Bodies a great Indipoition to admit their hurtfull
Operations, which methinks thoe Phyicians and Chymits hould eaily grant, who with a boldnes that I do not applaud, precribe Amulets, wherein Arenick, or ome other poyonous Drug is employ'd, as preervatives from the Plague, againt which, I doubt the chief Succours they afford, proceeds from the Confidence or Fearlenes they give thoe that wear them. But to return to our ubterraneal Effluvia, ince there are divers whole Countries, or leer places, that are either altogether, or in great part, free from this or that particular Dieae; as in everal parts of Scotland from Agues, epecially if I mitake not Quartans, are very unfrequent, inomuch that a learned Phyician anwer'd me, that in divers years practice he met not with above three or four, and in everal large Regions of the Eat-Indies, notwithtanding the exceive heat of the Climate, the Plague is very rare: ince (I ay) thee things are o, it eems not altogether improbable that the ubterraneal
teaws may contribute to this advantage, by impregnating both the Air, the Earth, and the Water, with Corpucles endow'd with Qualities unfriendly to thee Dieaes, which eems to be omewhat the more credible, becaue it has been oberv'd that ome vat Tracts of Land will neither breed nor maintain venemous Creatures, as is undoubtedly believ'd of the whole Kingdom of Ireland, where I confes I neither did ee any alive, nor met with any other that did; for as to Spiders, though they breed in that Countrey, where I have een many of them, and ometimes even upon Irih Wood, yet they are unanimouly believ'd not to be poyonous there: And ome Writers tell us, how truly I know not, of ome other Countries, to which they affirm the like Privilege to belong. But there is one intance afforded us by Begninus, who travel'd much to viit Mines, which if it be trictly true, is very notable for my preent purpoe. Dignum admiratione et, ays he, quod quamvis in vicinia Hydriae
