Comitatus Gloricienis, ubi reperitur copiosè ingulis ferè annis Lues petifera graatur, illa tamen emper immunis ab hac manere oleat, idque viri provectae aetatis e obervae & à majoribus uis accepie, mihi anctè confirmârunt. To which I hould add the Tetimony of the Learned Michael Mayerus, who pronounces Mercury to be an Alexipharmacum againt divers Dieaes, and particularly the Plague, if I did not upect by his way of mentioning this lat Dieae, that he but borrowed his Encomium of Mercury from Begninus. But however; what has been related, has invited me to conider, whether there may not be ome virtue, as well as ome danger, in Amulets of Quickilver that are by many extoll'd againt the Plague. But this onley upon the bye.

div.head: PROPOSITION III.

argument.p: It is Likely, that divers Epidemical Dieaes are in great part produc'd by Subterraneal Effluvia.

div.p: I Am very well aware, that divers Dieaes that extraordinarily invade great numbers of people at the ame time; (and were therefore, by the Greeks called Epidemical) may be rationally refer'd to manifet Intemperatenees of the Air, in point of Heat, Cold, Moiture, or ome other Obvious Quality. And therefore the Propoition peaks but of ome Epidemical Dieaes, and imputes thoe it peaks of to Subterraneal Effluvia, not as total, but as partial, and ometimes as principal, Agents in the production of them.
In favour of the propos'd Conjecture thus explain'd, I hall offer two things to Conideration.

I. And firt, it eems not very improbable, that divers of thoe Morbifick Excees (epecially if they be udden) that are oberv'd in the Air, may proceed from the unuually copious acent of hurtfull Exhalations that mingle with the Air, and diffue themelves through it. We are greater Strangers than we commonly take notice of, to the Subterraneat part of the Globe we inhabit: and if I had leaure, and thought it neceary, I could hew, that there are a great many odd and urprizing things to be met with in the Structure and dipoition even of thoe parts of the Earth, that lie but a little way beneath the urface of it, and partly have been, and partly may eaily enough be, actually penetrated by the indutrious Labours of men. And as for the deeper Subterraneal Regions, we are o much more unacquainted with them, that we are carce fit o much as to conjecture, how far they extend, or
what kind of Materials they contain, and what is the gros, and (if I may o peak) the Mechanical Fabrick of the greater Maes, whether olid or fluid, they conit of: And leat of all can we determine what Motions, whether periodical, or others, thee Maes, or other Portions of deeply lodg'd Matter, may have.

On uch grounds as thee, I conceive it poible, that, among the many and various Effluviating Bodies, that the terretrial Globe may conceal in its Bowels, there may be ome, whoe reeks acending plentifully into the Air, may occaion in it an exces of Heat, Cold, Moiture, thicknes, or ome other manifet Quality. So that ometimes (not to ay many times) even thoe manifet Intemperatenees of the Air, to which an Epidemical Dieae is wont to be wholly imputed, (though perhaps not very jutly) may in part proceed from Subterraneal Bodies; for I elewhere hew, that thee by their Conflicts, or Mutual Actions on
one another, may excite great and udden Heats, and on that account end up uch copious Steams into the Atmophere, as may produce there udden and exceive Heats, Lightnings, Thunders, &c. And I hall now add (what perhaps will appear omewhat trange) that I think udden and uneaonable Refrigerations of the Air, may proceed from the action of Subterraneal Bodies upon one another: for Tryal purpoely made has inform'd me, that there are certain Minerals, whereof ome may be employed in their crude Simplicity, and the other requires but a light Preparation, uch as it may have in the Bowels of the Earth; which Minerals being put together, will produce by their Reaction an intene degree of Cold, not onely as to ene, but when examined by a eal'd Weather-glas.

The Changes of the Air that produce Epidemical Dieaes are ometimes o great and udden, that they cannot, in my Opinion, with
probability be imputed to the action of the Sun, or the Moon, (which are caues that act in too general, and too uniform a way, to have thoe particular and anomalous Effects attributed to Them;) as probably as they may be to Subterraneal Bodies, that often act with more uddennes and impetuoity, and without any regularity, at leat that is known to us. The difference we find in Seaons, that bear the ame name, and hould be alike in temperature • , is oftentimes very great, and ometimes alo very lating. It is proverbially aid in England, that a Peck of March Dut is worth a King's Ranom: So unfrequent is dry Weather during that Month, in our Climate. And yet in ome years, and particularly the lat, 'twas a rare thing to have a hower either in March, April, or May, ometimes in the Month lat named, there are Heats greater than in the Dog-days of that ame Year; though uually here in England, divers Mornings of that Month are
cold, and ome of them froty. And now and then I have oberv'd in the ame Months and Days, at no great ditance from one another, that the Weather has been ultry hot, and has alo produc'd a great Snow. We have een Summers like that which is remember'd for the Siege of Colcheter, that for almot the whole Seaon, where more dark and rainy, than everal Winters have been oberv'd to be. To which purpoe I remember, that when I was about to write the Hitory of Cold, I was fain to watch almot a whole Winter to find two or three froty days, to make an Experiment or two I had need of, that requir'd not a Cold that was either lating or very intene. But Intances of this kind are o obvious, to thoe that are at all heedfull Obervers, that I may afely pas them by, and inculcate that the Sun being in the ame Signs, at the ame Times of the Year, it does not appear, how He hould produce o great a diparity
of the temperature of the Air in Seaons of the ame denomination; (as the Winters or the Summers of differing, and yet perhaps immediately conecutive, Years.) And therefore I do not o much wonder, that many Learned Writers fly to Atrology for an account of thee irregular Phaenomena, and acribe them to the influences of certain Stars; notwithtanding what divers eminent Philoophers, and ome great Atronomers too, have aid to prove the vanity of Judiciary Atrology.

I hall not now tay to dicus the Quetion, whether the Stars have any influence ditinct from their Light and Heat: becaue, my Opinion about it being omewhat peculiar, I have dicoured of it in a Paper by it elf. But this I hall now ay, that the fixt Stars being but general, and (if I may o peak) indefinite Agents, almot unimaginably remote from us, 'tis nothing near o likely that uch Effects as (beides that they happen very uddenly and irregularly)
are oftentimes confin'd to a Town, or ome other narrow Compas, hould be produc'd by certain Stars: as that they hould be o by Subterraneal Bodies, which are near at hand, of very various natures, and ubject to many irregular and differing Motions, commixtures, reactions, and other alterations. I have known a great Cold in a day or two invade Multitudes in the ame City, with violent, and as to many Perons fatal Symptomes; when I could not judge, (as others alo did not) that the bare coldnes of the Air could o uddenly produce a Dieae o Epidemical and hurtfull: and it appear'd the more probable, that the caue came from under ground, by reaon that it began with a very troubleome Fog.

That there may be many Subterraneal Bodies, which by their commixtures may produce a udden Heat, will be eaily granted by thoe that know, (what I elewhere purpoely make out) that there are Subterraneal
Mentruums; and are acquainted with Chymical Operations, uch as the great effervecence made, when Oil of Vitriol is put upon filings of Iron, or Spirit of Niter upon Butter of Antimony; to which I might add many other of the like kind that I have tryed, as when Spirit of Niter is put upon filings, either of Iron, Copper, or Tin, or upon crude Quickilver; which I hall content my elf to have nam'd, becaue I have another Intance that comes cloer to our preent purpoe. For whereas I have hewn above, that there is in many places great tore of Marcaitical matter beneath the urface of the Earth, and ometimes very near it; I hall now add that I have purpoely tryed, that putting a little Spirit drawn from Niter, (with which Salt the Earth in many places abounds) or a litle Oil of Vitriol, upon powder'd Marcaites (which being hard Stones are more difficultly wrought upon, than many other Subterxaneous marcaitical Bodies
of a looer texture) there preently enued a trong reaction between the Liquid and the Solid Bodies, whereby was produc'd much heat, not without viible fumes, and Strongly Scented, though not viible, Exhalations. And uch kind of Odorous Effluvia were emitted, upon the putting a little Spirit of Salt upon our Powder'd Marcaites. And becaue Sulphur is a mineral that (either pure, or copiouly mix'd with others) is to be plentifully met with in the Bowels of the Earth, and in many places burns there, I hall add, that I have found acid Spirit of Sulphur (made the common way) to work enibly upon marcaitical matter, hard enough coagulated. An experienc'd German Chymit relates, that in ome parts of his Country he met with Vitriol Stones, or Marcaites, that, by the action of mere common Water reting a competent time upon them, will grow o hot as to enable the Liquor to retain a
enible Heat, when it had pas'd a pretty way from them. And, as I elewhere hew, that many Accidents may occaion the breaking out of Waters, or the change of their coure in Subterraneal Places; So, that common Water may produce in a very hort time coniderable degrees of Heat in Mineral Bodies, may appear by mixing with two or three pounds of fine Powder of common Brimtone a convenient quantity, (for now I remember not well how much I took) of filings of Iron, for this mixture being thoroughly drench'd with common Water, did in a hort time grow intenely hot, and end up uch a thick Smoke as good quicklime is wont to doe, whilt men Slake it with Water.

It is obervable to our preent purpoe, what account was given me by a Dometick of mine, that liv'd in the North part of England, of a certain Mineral Groove which he had often occaion to reort to: for,
when I ask'd whether the Damp that place was moleted with, did frequently recurr; he anwer'd me, that at the time he was there it would annoy the workmen, (if they did not take good care of themelves) more than once in one day. And by Enquiries that I made of others that were converant in Mines, I learn'd, that in divers places they were moleted with Damps, that came not at tated Periods, but irregularly; ometimes with much greater, and ometimes with far leer, Intervals between them: the times of their duration being alo not eldom unequal. So that, uppoing uch noxious Effluvia to be plentifully emitted from the lower parts of the Soil, it need be no wonder, that an Epidemical Dieae hould be rie in this or that particular Town or part of a Country, without preading much farther; and that it hould begin uddenly in places where it was not expected: for, beides that thee warms of Effluvia,
being produc'd by caual concoures of Circumtances, may oftentimes be excited, and invade this or that place, without giving the Inhabitants any warning, beides this, I ay, 'tis not always neceary that thee noxious Effluvia hould be generated jut under the places they molet, ince the motion of the Air, epecially when the Wind its favourably, may uffice to carry them to the Town or other place that feels their ill effects: and yet they may eem to be almot confin'd to thoe places; ometimes becaue the neighbouring places are not inhabited enough to make their ill qualities taken notice of; but more frequently becaue, by being diffus'd thorough a greater tract of Air, they are more and more dipert in their paage, and thereby o diluted (if I may o peak) and weakn'd, as not to be able to doe any notorious michief.

And here I Conider too, that 'tis not always neceary that the harm that is done by thee morbid
Contitutions of the Air, hould proceed onely or preciely from thee Subterraneal Exhalations we are peaking of, by virtue onely of their own qualities, which they bring with them from under ground. For 'tis very poible, that thee Effluvia may be in their own nature either innocent enough, or at leat not coniderably hurtfull, and yet may become very noxious, if they chance to find the Air already imbu'd with certain Corpucles fit to aociate with them: for, though thee orts of Particles were perhaps neither of them a-part coniderably hurtfull, yet there may from their Combinations reult Corpucles, of a new and very morbifick nature.

This may be omewhat illutrated by conidering, that the pirituous teams of Salt-peter are not wont enibly to work on Gold, nor yet the pirituous Parts that the Fire raies from Sal-armoniac; and yet when thee two orts of Particles convene, there reults from their Coalitions
certain Corpucles of a new nature, that compoe the Liquor Chymits call Aqua Regis; which by its fretting quality corrodes and diolves Gold. By Analogy to this we may conceive, that ometimes the Subterraneal Effluvia may find the Air already impregnated with uch Corpucles, that by aociating themelves therewith they may compoe Corpucles far more capable, than themelves were whilt apart, of having ill Effects upon the Mas of Bloud, or ome determinate Parts of Humane Bodies, and conequently of produceing Dieaes there.

And this Intance may appear the more appoite; becaue it may be aid, that as, though Silver and Gold, and Diamonds and Rubies, &c. be put together, and Aqua Regis be pour'd upon them, it will leave all the ret uncorroded, and fall onely upon the Gold; o the newly produc'd Corpucles that I have been peaking of, whether breathed in with the Air in Repiration,
or carried up and down by the Bloud, or other Liquors of the Body, may pas by other parts of it without doing them any enible harm, and attacking this or that determinate part, produce there ome Dieae uch as the fabrick and ituation of that part peculiarly dipoe it to be affected with.

And I hall add on this occaion, that in our Hypotheis we may render a probable reaon, why in ome Epidemical Dieaes, ome perons may ecape much better than other, that eem likely to be, at bet, as obnoxious to them, without a recoure to the peculiar Contitutions of the Bodies of differing Perons; for it may be conjectur'd, that the noxious Corpucles that infet the Air, may (epecially in windy weather) be very unequally diperc'd through the Air, and many fly in far greater or leer numbers within equal paces of Air; and conequently the Perons, that have the ill luck to be in the way of the more
numerous warms of morbifick Corpucles, may be much more prejudiced by them than others, though of weaker contitutions, who happen to be attaqu'd but by few of them.

On which occaion, I remember, that a great many Trees in ome Land that belongs to me, having been uddenly much endamag'd by a wind, that was not able to doe it by it's bare trength; I had the curioity to view omewhat heedfully a Tree that tood in the Garden, and perceiv'd that all the coniderable michief was done to that ide of the Tree, which repected the corner whence the hurtfull Wind blew, the Leaves of the other ide continuing freh and verdant, as being by the other part of the ame Tree fenc'd from the Wind: and it was farther oberv'd, that even the expos'd ide of the Tree was not every-where endamag'd; for there were divers parts, where the Leaves continued ound and green, though neighbouring Leaves were ome more, ome
les (for all that were prejudic'd were not totally) blated: the ound Leaves and the dicolour'd being o odly mingled, that I conjectur'd the caue of the michief to have been this; that ome Arenical or other corroive or poionous Exhalations, being uddenly emitted from the Subterraneal parts into the Air, were by the Wind they chance to meet with there, hurry'd along with it, and blown againt the Bodies that tood in it's way, moving in the Air, like Hail-hot dicharg'd out of a Gun, here in a cloer, and there in a more cattering order, o that as more or fewer of them happend to fall upon the ame Branch or Leafe, they left more, or les marks of their paage, by detroying the texture and colour in the Leaves or parts of them they chanc'd to beat upon. And this may poibly be the caue of ome of thoe udden and ometimes fatal Effects, that I have known in ome places the people talk much of, complaining, that uch a one had his
Eyes, or his Face, or onely one ide of it blated, by a malignant Wind, of which I thought I aw an Example in a Dometick of my own, whilt in uch a Wind he was riding after me, who (thanks be to God) had no uch michief done me.

But the Vulgar have entertain'd uch trange Conceits and Stories about thee Blatings, on which account ome of them ay that Men are Planet-truck that the fabulous things mingled with thoe that are poible, have made intelligent Perons reject them all.

One thing more I hall take notice of in favour of our Hypotheis, which is, that it well agrees with what has been oberved, not without ome wonder, of the very hort duration of ome Epidemical Dieaes, in certain Times and Places. For this may proceed from hence, either that all the Morbifick Expirations acended into the Air almot at once, or at leat within a hort time, and o were eaily pent, that is by diffuion or
diperion o weakned, as to be diabled from doing much michief: or ele the Subterraneal Commotion that produc'd them may pas on from one place to another, and o ceae to afford the Air incumbent on the firt place, the upplies neceary to keep it impregnated with noxious Exhalations. And it agrees well with this Conjecture, that ometimes we may oberve certain Epidemical Dieaes to have as it were a progreive Motion, and leaving one Town free pas on to another. Of which ome Obervations that I have made, encline me to think, that if Phyicians would heedfully mind it, they might take notice of everal Intances.

One thing more may be added, as cononant to our Hypotheis; namely, that ometimes an Epidemical Dieae ceaes in this or that place, almot as udden as it invaded, or at leat in a much horter time than Phyicians expected. For according to our Hypotheis it may well happen,
that after one ort of Exhalations, whoe peculiar Qualities make them Morbifick, have deprav'd the Air incumbent on a particular place; there may by a new or farther Commotion of Subterraneal Bodies, be ent up into the Air tore of Expirations of another kind, which meeting with thoe that formerly impregnated it, may either precipitate them, and o free the Air from them; or by other operations on them, and ometimes even by Coalitions with them, o alter their nature as to diable them from doing any farther michief.

This I hall illutrate, if not confirm, by that very remarkable Phaenomenon that is yearly oberv'd at Grand Cairo in Aegypt; for, (though I know not whether or no the Corpucles that produce it arie from under Ground, the affirmative part of the Quetion being not improbable) it appears, that by the intermixture of adventitious Corpucles, with the formerly Petilential Air, 'tis o alter'd and
corrected, that within one day or two, if not within a leer compas of time, there is a top put to the progres of the Plagues; that in that favourable time of year, namely about the middle of Summer, carce ever mies of raging in that populous City: and, which is more admirable, thee anative Corpucles (if I may o call them) operate o powerfully, that of thoe that are already eiz'd by that fatallet of Dieaes, the Plague, few or none die of it, after once thee Antidotal Particles have ufficiently impregnated the Air. I confes o great and udden a change is very wonderfull, and I hould carce think it credible, if I had not had the means and curioity to enquire about it of divers perons, ome of them very intelligent, that either curiouly viited, or alo made ome coniderable tay in, that great City; and found them agree in the main about the truth of the matter of fact; which is much confirm'd to me by o eminent a Tetimony as that of the
learned Proper Alpinus, who for everal years practis'd Phyick in Grand Cairo, and as an Eye-witnes delivers what he relates more authentically, as well as more particularly, than any I have met with. And, though he endeavours to give everal reaons of this trange and udden ceation of the malignity of the Plague, yet I doubt they are not ufficient for o wonderfull an effect; unles we take in ome new Exhalations, that then impregnate and correct the Air.

And we hall carce doubt of the great interet thee have in the effect produc'd, if we give credit to what the recentet Writer I have met with of Voyages into Egypt, has lately publih'd about the annual Petilence at Grand Cairo, a City he much frequented. This Authour, in the account he gives of the preent tate of Egypt, relates that a little after the middle of our June (and uually upon the very eventeenth day) there begin to fall towards the lat quarter of the night,
near the morning, certain drops of a kind of Dew, which caues the River to be fruitfull, and purifies the Air from all the Infection of Camims, by which I preume he means the Petilence: for after ome lines interpos'd he ubjoins, The Drops or Dew purifies the Air, for as oon as it falls the Plague ceaes to be mortal, none dies of it; the Air is wholeome, all Ditempers ceae, and if any peron grows ick, he never dies.

And then, he adds, This Dew gives life to every thing; and when it falls upon the Wheat, it caueth it to continue many years without corruption or Worms, and is far more nourihing than that Corn on which it never falls. For this caue they never houe the Corn of the Grand Seignior in the Barns, till this Dew is fallen upon it, that it might keep the longer without Worms.

As well this Conjecture, as ome other things deliver'd here and there in this Paper (about the Salubrity of the Air,) may probably gain the
more credit, if I here ubjoin what I learn'd by inquiry from a very ingenious Gentleman, who was owner of one or more of the Mines, that afford the Phaenomenon I am to mention. Which is this, That in the Tin-mine Countreys in Devonhire, it ometimes happens, (as perhaps I may have elewhere noted to another purpoe,) that upon a udden, a Spot of ground, and that not always narrow, will be as 'twere blated by the acending hurtfull Fumes; inomuch that not onely the Gras, Fern and other more tender Vegetables, will be turned black, and as it were burnt or corched up; but now and then Trees alo, without excepting Oaks themelves will be blated and poil'd by the powerfull Operation of thee ubtil and poionous Effluvia.

It will probably be here expected, that among the Epidemical Dieaes that our Hypotheis derives from Subterraneal Effluvia, I hould particularly treat of the caue of Petilential
Fevers, and the Plague it elf. But, though ome uch Fevers may not improbably be in great part imputed to the noxious Expirations of the Globe we inhabit; yet, as to the true Plague it elf, I freely confes I am at a los about it's Origine.

The acred Writings exprely teach, that ome Plagues, and particularly that which in David's time wept away in three days 70000 Perons, have been in an extraordinary manner inflicted by God. And to me it appears either carce poible, or far more difficult than thoe that have not attentively enough conidered the matter, are wont to think it; To deduce the abtruce Origine, trange Symtomes, and other odd Phaenomena of ome Plagues that are recorded in Hitory, from merely Corporeal Caues.

On the other ide, it eems unphiloophical, and perhaps rather eems than is very pious, to recur without an abolute neceity to Supernatural
Caues, for uch Effects as do not manifetly exceed the power of Natural ones: though the particular manner of their being produc'd, is perchance more than we are yet able clearly to explicate. And I think it the more quetionable, whether all Plagues are Supernatural Exertions of God's Power and Wrath againt the Wicked, becaue I oberve that Brutes (which are as well uncapable of moral Vice, as moral Vertue) are yet oftentimes ubject to Murrains, uch as may without incongruity be lookt upon as the Petilences of Beats. And 'tis the les likely, that thee weeping and contagious Maladies hould be always ent for the punihment of impious men, becaue I remember to have read in good Authours, that, as ome Plagues detroy'd both Men and Beats, o ome other did peculiarly detroy Brute Animals, of very little conideration or ue to Men, as Cats, &c.

Upon thee and the like Reaons I have ometimes upected, that in the Controverie about the Origine of the Plague, namely, Whether, it be Natural, or Supernatural; neither of the contending Parties is altogether in the right: ince 'tis very poible, that ome Petilences may not break forth, without an extraordinary, though perhaps not Immediate, interpoition of Almighty God, provok'd by the Sins of Men: and yet other Plagues may be produc'd by a Tragical concoure of merely Natural Caues.

But though the difficulties that incumber each of the oppoite Opinions, keep me both from Dogmatically aerting, that All Plagues have a Supernatural Origine; and from denying that Any have it: yet, to ay omething on uch an occaion, though I can peak but very heitantly, I hall venture to add, that, whether or no the true Plague be aid to decend to the Earth from a higher Sphere than that
of Nature; yet its Propagation and Effects are (at leat for the mot part) carry'd on mainly by a malignant dipoition in the Air; without which ome Plagues could never have been o catching as they were, nor o uddenly mortal; and that in divers Petilences this malignant Dipoition in the Air, may probably be in great part imputed to ome kinds of Subterraneal Expirations, I am prone to think; and that chiefly upon two Accounts.

The firt thing that induces me to this Conjecture, is, that not any of the everal Caues to which the Plague is wont to be imputed eems to me to be ufficient. Thoe that fetch it from the malevolent apects and influence of the Celetial lights, beides that they uppoe ome things very difficult to be prov'd, have recoure to Agents too remote, too general, and too indeterminate, to be acquiec'd in as the Caues of uch particular Symtomes and Phaenomena, as oftentimes accompany Petilences.
And as for thoe other Sects of Phyicians that confidently derive the Plague, ome from Internal Putrefaction, and others from exceive Heats, noiome Stinks, Corrupt aliments, and uch other Celebrated Caues; though each party alledges plauible Reaons for its own opinion, yet their objections againt their adveraries are much tronger than their arguments are for themelves. And the Learned Diemer-broeck, though his own Hypotheis eem to be more Theological than Philoophical, has much enervated the Arguments brought for the everal opinions lately nam'd, and by him diented from.

The Reaons he employs to refute all the receiv'd opinions about the Origine of the Plague, except his own, are divers of them worthy of o learned a man; to whom, though I had leiure to trancribe them, I hould refer the Curious: my preent deign being onely to deliver ome few things that eem more favourable
to my Conjectures, than to his Opinion, and were uggeted to me, partly by my own Thoughts, and partly by the informations, that, to examine thoe Thoughts, I procur'd by conulting ome uncommon Authours, and asking Quetions of great Travellers and Navigatours. By this means I came to learn, that divers great Countries are uually free from the Plague, that according to the vulgar Hypothees, ought to be as much ubject to it, if not more, than England, France, Italy, and thoe other parts of Europe and Aia, where that fatal Dieae rages from time to time in the parched Regions of Africk, to which the Exceive Heats would make one expect, that the Plagues hould make far more frequent viits than to our temperate European Countries; Leo Africanus informs us, that ome parts are o eldom afflicted with that dreadfull Dieae, that it uually pares the Inhabitants 29, or 30 years together. And he exprely records, that in Numidia
it elf, (if I much miremember not the Countrey's name, notwithtanding the raging heat of the Climate, the Plague is wont to be produc'd but once in a hundred years. Our Purchas's Philgrimage, lib. 6. cap. 13. Purchas informs us that in the Land of Negro's it is not known at all. And to omit what ome Travellers and Navigatours relate of Japan, as if it were eldom or never invaded by the Petilence; I do not remember that in New England, which contains a great extent of Land, though I have had both Curioity and opportunity to inquire after the Dieaes of that Countrey, I ever heard the Englih take any notice of the Plague, ince their etling there above threecore and ten years ago. And as for the Eat Indies, Sir Philibert Vernatti, a Virtuoo of great fame and authority at Batavia where he reides, in his ingenious Returns to the Queries ent him by the Royal Society (of Naturalits) anwers thus to the fifteenth.
[Petis morbus et Indiarum Incolis incognitus] The Plague is a Dieae unknown amongt the Indians. And of the Countries that lie yet more remote, as the great Empire of China, and the Kingdoms of Tunquin, and of Cochinchina, that great Traveller Alexander de Rhodes, who pent 30 years in thoe parts, affirms, that the Plague is not o much as poken of there. And yet the ame Jeuit does, upon grounds probable enough, etimate the number of the people of China alone to be two hundred and fifty millions; [a number I take to exceed by far that of all the Nations of Europe.] Now when I conider, how vat Tracts of Land are compriz'd in thoe Countries, ome of which the Plague does not at all, and others but exceeding unfrequently, invade; this Immunity eems to me very unfavourable to mot, if not all, the opinions receiv'd among Phyicians, as alo that of Diemerbroeck himelf who derives the Plague from a Supernatural Caue,
the wrath of God againt the ins of men. For in Regions of uch extent, and divers of them very populous, which are eated under very differing Climats, and which are ome of them inhabited by Nations, that make war with numerous Armies, fight bloudy battels, leave heaps of unbury'd Bodies expos'd to the putrefying heat of the Sun; are ometimes forc'd, as well as others to live upon very unwonted and unwholome foods; that worhip tocks and tones, and beats, and ome of them Devils, whom they know to be uch; that are at leat as guilty as Europeans, of Aainats, Poionings, Rapes, Oppreion, Sodomy, and other crying Sins: in thee Regions, I ay, 'tis not imaginable but that great Intemperatures of the Air, epecially, in point of Heat, Stench of dead Bodies kill'd in fights, unwholomnes of Aliments, malevolent apects of Celetial Bodies, high provocations of the divine Jutice, and in hort, all the Caues, to one or other of which the everal
parties of Phyicians are wont to refer the Plague, hould be wanting any more than in our Europe; and yet the Plague which is preum'd to be the Effect of one or other of thoe Caues, is not here oberved to be produc'd.

I know that it may be aid, that the Hitorical things I have been reciting, do not onely oppugn the everal receiv'd Opinions of Phyicians about the caue of the Plague, but disfavour my Conjectures too. But if this be aid, I deire it may alo be conider'd, that my Judgment about the Plague conits of two Parts; One, that 'tis exceeding difficult to aign the true and adequate Caue of the Origine of the Petilence; and the Other, that whatever be the Caue of its Firt Eruption, its Propagation and divers of its Symptomes, may be probably enough refer'd to the depravation of the Air by Subterraneal Steams, and their Effects. If this be duly conider'd the Hitorical Obervations
will appear not to overthrow the Firt member of our Hypotheis, but rather to confirm it: and 'tis upon this account that I have mention'd them in this place. And as to the Second member it may be aid, that ince in the Eat Indies and the other Countries, I have nam'd, as privileg'd from this raging Dieae, it is not oberv'd to break out: as it cannot be aid that Subterraneal Effluvia do in thoe Countries promote the Propagation of it; o it cannot be prov'd that they could not doe it, incae the Plague were begun by other Caues. But in regard I think it not improbable that ometimes the Plague is not onely fomented but begun by noxious Expirations of the Terretrial Globe, I hall add that this uppoition, though I confes it be omewhat disfavour'd by ome of the lately mention'd Obervations, yet is not abolutely inconitent with them. For Firt, it may be aid that ome of the Countries I peak of, may be detitute of
thoe noxious minerals to which we impute ome Plagues, it holding true in Minerals as well as in Plants. Non omnis fert omnia tellus, and to omit what I have not without ome wonders oberv'd, of the Limits of differing orts of Mines and Mineral Veins in very bordering parts of the ame tract of Land, I cannot but here take notice, that though Sulphur be in many Countries uually found, and that in plenty where there are other Metalline Veins, inomuch that Chymits make it one of the three Principles of all Metals, yet in the Mines of England more trictly o call'd, I do not remember I ever met with o much as an Ounce of Native Sulphur, and I could not find by divers Mineralits, of whom I purpoely ask'd the quetion that they had met with any among the various Mines they had frequented. It may alo happen that there may be hurtfull Minerals in a Countrey, and yet not capable of often producing or promoting Petilences
there, even upon moderate Earthquakes. For 'tis poible that thee Orpimental or other Noxious Minerals may have their Beds or Veins lying o deep in the Earth, that they are not ordinarily able to end up Effluvia, trong and copious enough to make a Petilential depravation of the Air, and even in leer Earthquakes the commotion or agitation of the ground, epecially if the Earth-quakes proceed (as one may upect that divers of them do) from the udden fall of ponderous Maes in the hollow parts of the Earth and the hakings of the ground thereby produc'd, and ometimes preading far, may not reach o far downwards as much to affect thee very deep Mines, and yet ome other more violent Earthquakes, may affect even thee; upon which ground one may give ome tolerable account why the Plague in ome parts of Africk has been oberv'd to rage but once in thirty or once in an hundred years; for there may be periodical
Paroxyms, if I may o call them, or grand and vehement Commotions in Subterraneal Parts, though men have not yet, for want of ufficient Longevity or Curioity oberv'd them. On which occaion, I remember that a late judicious French Hitorian recounts that in part of the lat age, and part of this, a very pernicious Dieae of the nature of a Colick raign'd in France every tenth year for a long tract of time. And the Experienc'd Lib. 2. P. M. 323. Platerus relates, that at Bail, where with great ucces he practis'd Phyick fifty ix years, the City was afflicted with furious Plagues once about every tenth year for eventy years together, of each of which Petilences he gives a particular account in his uefull obervation. It may alo farther be aid, that thoe Exhalations in the Eat Indies, &c. that would otherwie be petiferous, may be corrected by other Expirations that may be either of benign nature, or of uch a nature,
as though noxious in themelves, may fit them by combining with thoe that would be petiferous to diable them to be o, as I elewhere oberv'd out of Beguinus, that a Countrey abounding in veins and maes of Cinnabar, which is the Ore of Quickilver, was preerv'd from the Plague, when the neighbouring Regions were wated by it; and I hall illutrate this matter omewhat farther by taking notice, that though Corroive Sublimate be o michievous a Mineral Compoition, that a few grains may kill a man, yet the fumes of this combin'd with thoe of Crude, common Quickilver, which are themelves unwholeome enough, make Mercurius dulcis, which is a mixture o innocent, that being well prepar'd, and well adminitred, it is both afely and uefully given even to Children.

If what has been aid will not uffice, I hall propoe another poible way of accounting for the immunity of ome Countries from the
Plague. For one may conceive that in uch Regions the Soil, and other aiting Caues may contantly produce in the Air uch a Contitution as is found in the Air of Egypt, during the time of the increae, and overflowing of Nile, which uually lats every year for everal weeks, for during this time the Air is o antipetilential, that not only the Plague does not make a new Eruption; but is either wonderfully check'd or quite uppres'd in thoe houes that it has already invaded, o that its mortal infection reaches no farther, and that it may not be thought incredible that ome Countries may have, if I may o peak, an antidotal Nature, in reference to ome pernicious Evils, I hall repreent that there are ome whole Countries which are privileg'd from producing Vipers, Toads, and other venemous Creatures, as is vulgarly known concerning Ireland, where I could never ee any uch, nor find by Enquiry of either the Natives, or Englih Inhabitants,
that they had met with any in that Kingdom, where 'tis an uncontroll'd tradition, that if Poyonous Creatures have been carefully brought there from other Parts, they have died almot as oon as they came thither. There are ome other Ilands to which a like hotility to venemous Animals is acrib'd: and as it eems not inpoible that ome Countries hould have a Soil that o impregnats the Air as to make it uppres or quite enervate many differing orts of Poyons, o others may by their Contitution be qualify'd to mater or reit poionous Expirations or wandering Corpucles that elewhere are wont to produce the Plague. And this may uffice for the firt thing whereon we ground our Hypotheis.

The Second thing that invited me to the above propos'd Supicion or Conjecture, is, That it affords a not improbable account of ome coniderable things, relating to the
Production and Phaenomena of the Plague.

(1.) As Firt, 'tis oberv'd that ometimes the Plague breaks out, when there has not preceded any uch immoderate ditemper of the Air, or any caual Enormity capable of producing o great and anomalous an Effect. Nay, which is more, it has been oberv'd, that very great and unuual intemperatenees of the Air have everal times happen'd, and divers notable and threatning Apects of the Stars have been noted by good Writers without being follow'd by the Plague. The celebrated De abditis rerum cau. lib. 2. c. 13. Fernelius relates, that near the time he writ this Obervation, that Year, which of all thoe that had pas'd in the memory of Man, was all the World over the mot immoderately hot, and was yet mot healthfull. And the ame Authour reports the Plague to have begun in the midt of Winter, and to have gone off in Summer, and that everal
times ardent Summers have been altogether free from the Plague: which I alo have noted to be true. Johannes Morellus oberves, that in his Countrey after a dry Winter, and wherein the North Wind reign'd, though it were ucceeded by a mot temperate and healthfull Spring, yet this brought in the Plague, and that, when the North Wind was predominant and the Air pure and incere. Which I the les cruple to believe, becaue I oberv'd omething very like it in the Contitutions of the Air, that preceded and accompany'd the dreadfull London Plague that broke out in the year 1665. Which Phaenomena much disfavour their Opinion that impute the Plague to the excees of the manifet Qualities of the Air; but are agreeable to our Hypotheis, ince by what has been formerly deliver'd, we may gather that Noxious Subterraneal Fumes may be uddenly, and without any warning belch'd up into the Air, and, by depraving it, produce
fatal Dieaes in many of thoe that are contantly urrounded by it, and draw it in, almot every moment, with their breath.

Of the deadly Hurtfulnes of divers Subterraneal Expirations, at their firt Eruption, there are many Hitories extant in approv'd Authours: And we have oberv'd Intances of that ort, in the Times and Countries we live in. But, becaue all Poionous, and even mortal, Exhalations are not therefore truly Petiferous, but may, like many other Poions, kill the Perons they immediately invade, without qualifying them to infect others; I hall add a Paage out of that Excellent Hitorian Monieur de Mezeray who relates in the life of Philip de Valois, that the Plague that happened in France in the Year 1346. was o contageous and detructive, that carce a Village, or even a Houe, ecap'd uninfected by it. He adds, that this Petilence, than which none had been oberv'd more furious
and preading, began two years before in the Kingdom of Cathay, by a vapour that was mot horribly tinking, which brake out of the Earth like a kind of Subterraneal fire, conum'd and devour'd above 200 Leagues of that Countrey, even to the very Trees and Stones, and infected the Air in a wonderfull manner. From Cathay, ay's he, it pas'd into Aia and Greece, thence into Africk, afterwards into Europe, which it ranack'd throughout. Other Intances, of Petilences begun by noxious Subterraneal Fumes, I have met with in good Authours;See Diemerbroeck de Pete, lib. 1. cap. 8. but cannot now recall the Particulars to mind, and therefore hall pas on to the econd Obervation.

What thee Mineral Subtances are, whoe teams produce uch odd and dimal Symtomes, I think exceeding hard to determine. Yet, if I were to name one ort, I hould perhaps think the leat unlikely to be Orpiment. For, of the Poyonous Minerals we are acquainted with, I know not any of which there is greater quantity in the Bowels of the Earth; epecially taking that name, in the latitude allowed it, by thoe skilfull men, that make three orts of it, viz. Yellow, Red and White Orpiment, divers of whoe michievous Effects eem to agree well enough with the Symtomes of ome Plagues,
and may be gueed to have at leat a coniderable interet in the production of them. But yet, to peak candidly, I do not think that thee Minerals are the caues, even of all thoe Petilences whoe efficients may come from under the Ground: For everal reaons, and ome drawn from Experience, make me think that the Subterraneal Regions have many kinds of very michievous foiles, of which Phyicians, and even Chymits, have no knowledge, and for which they have not any ditinct names; and that the various aociations of thee, which Nature may by Fire and mentruums make under Ground, and perhaps in the Air it elf; may very much increae the number, and variety of hurtfull Matters, and alo heighten their hotility to Humane Bodies: as I think may be argued from the factitious White Arenick that is commonly old in Shops, which though uually made of Orpiment, by the addition of o innocent a Body as
common Salt, (which is found in great plenty under Ground,) is oberv'd to be far more poyonous than Orpiment it elf. And I remember that a skilfull Chymit, having in my preence tated ome prepar'd, and, as was thought, omewhat corrected Arcenick; was quickly invaded by uch Symtomes, as he thought would preently kill him. But, through God's bleing, I quickly put him out of danger, though not out of pain, by early precribing him tore of Oil of weet Almonds, and omething made of Lemmons, that I chanc'd to have by me: But to return to what I was aying; Sandarach eems to be, but Orpiment whoe yellow Colour is deepn'd to Rednes: and native Arenick, (for I have een uch a thing, though it rarely comes into England,) eems to be little other than pale or white Orpiment. And indeed in Hungary, all three may be found not far from one another in the ame Mine; As I learn'd by Inquiry from an oberving
Eye-witnes, by whoe means, and of another Chymit, divers Native Orpimental Minerals (to ay nothing of Realgar) becaue it is a Factitious combination of Orpiment and Sulphur, came to my hands. And as this ort of Foiles comprizes more numerous and various ones, than is vulgarly noted, o the very noxious effects of the Effluvia of Orpiment, are not unknown to divers Phyicians: and the Learned Sennertus gives a particularSenn. M. P. E. vi. p. 65. intance of it in a Painter, who upon opening a Box where Orpiment, which men of his Profeion ue as a Pigment, had been long kept, had his face all well'd, and was cat into fainting Fits. And as White Arenick is of a more piercing and corroive nature, o it were not difficult to hew out of the Writings of eminent Phyicians that its effects have divers times proved very hurtfull, and ometimes mortal. When but externally worn in Amulets, epecially if the Pores
of the Skin were open by exercie and weat; and the nature of the Symptomes produced eems to confirm our Hypotheis, ince the Perons that wore thee Arenical Amulets were affected, ome with great anxieties about the Heart, ome with inflammation, ome with burning Fevers, ome with exulceration of the Breats, o ome with Pusles like thoe of the Plague, and thee were ometimes black, as if made with a Cautick: mot Patients were affected with great weaknes and faintnes, &c. as if they had wallowed Poion; and of one young Man 'tis recorded, that having heated himelf in a Tennicourt with an Amulet upon his Breat, the virulence of its Corpucles made him fall down tark dead upon the Spot. And 'tis a coniderable Circumtance in thee Obervations, that everal Patients were cur'd of the Symptomes that eem'd to be Petilential ones by the ame Remedies that are Alexipharmacal
againt the Plague, whence it may alo be made probable, that the Plague it elf many times is a natural, though a dreadfull and anomalous Dieae, ince its Effects and Symptomes o much reemble thoe of acknowledg'd Poions, and have been cur'd by Antidotes effectual againt other Poions.

I have not time to mention what I have my elf try'd and oberv'd about the bad effects of Orpiment, and its kinds. But I remember, that enquiring of an ingenious Man, who ometimes viited a Mine which was known to abound with Orpimental Foils; he anwer'd me, that when he walked over the neighbouring Grounds, he found himelf much diorder'd, epecially in his Thorax by the Effluvia, and that the Mine-men and Diggers were ubject to a malignant anomalous and dangerous ort of Fevers, though he aid he was apt to impute, I know not how truly, ome part of their obnoxiounes
to it, to their drinking too much trong Wine. But though 'tis probable the Effluvia of Orpimental Bodies may have a great interet in everal Plagues, yet, I trongly upect that many others may proceed from the teams of uch Subterraneal Bodies as are not yet ditinctly known to us; and poibly have their Effluvia variouly combin'd, either beneath or above the urface of the Earth. I ay above; becaue I have everal times, and that without heat, combin'd eparately inviible fumes of differing kinds, into manifetly viible ones in the free and open Air.

And that the Subterraneal Effluvia may produce effects, and therefore probably be of natures, very uncommon, irregular, and if I may o peak, extravagant, may appear in thoe prodigious Croes that were een in our time, viz. in the Year 1660. in the Kingdom of Naples, after an eruption of the fiery Mountain Veuvius: of which Prodigies
the Learned Kircherus has given an account in a particular Diatribe. For thee Croes were een on Linen Garments, as Shirtleeves, Womens Aprons, that had lain open to the Air, and upon the expos'd parts of Sheets; which is the les to be admired, becaue as Kircher fairly guees, the mineral vapours were by the texture that belongs to Linen [which conits of threads croing one another for the mot part at or near right Angles] eaily determin'd to run along in almot treight lines, croing each other, and conequently to frame Spots reembling ome one, and ome another kind of Croes. Thee were extremely numerous in everal Parts of the Kingdom of Naples: inomuch that the Jeuit that ent the Relation to Kircher ays that he himelf found thirty in one Altarcloth, that fifteen were found upon the Smock leeve of a Woman, and that he reckoned eight in a Boy's Band: alo their colour and magnitude
were very unequal, and their figures dicrepant, as may appear in many Pictures of them drawn by the Relatour: they would not wah out with imple water, but requir'd Soap; their duration was alo unequal, ome lating ten or fifteen days, and others longer before they diappear'd. And thee Croes were found not onely upon Linen Garments expos'd to the Air, but upon ome of thoe (belonging to Altars) that were kept lock'd up in Chets (to which poibly they might have acces by the Key-holes, or ome unheeded chinck.) To which trange Phaenomena if I had the leiure to add ome others that I have met with in Agricola, and other approved Authours, whoe Relations my memory doth not now erve me particularly to cite; I preume it would appear yet more probable that Subterraneal Effluvia may now and then be of a very Anomalous nature, and produce trange effects, and among them
variety of Petiferous ones in the Air.

But, to add this upon the bye: though I fear Phyicians will not be able to dicover all the ubterraneal Bodies whoe Effluvia produce or contribute to the Plague: yet I do not think it impoible that by diligent obervations and trials, agacious Men may dicover divers of them; and perhaps Antidotes againt them.

And though the buines of this Paper be to treat of the Caues, not the Remedies of the Plague; yet I love Mankind too well, to uppres on this occaion an Obervation, that, by God's bleing, may in ome caes, ave the lives of many. In the late great Plague that wept away o many thouands at London, there taid in the City an Ingenious Phyician, that was bred by the Learned Diemerbroeck, (whoe Book De Pete, I prefer to any I have yet read of that Dieae.) This Doctour (whoe name I am
orry I have forgotten) hearing that I was deirous to receive an account of the Plague from ome intelligent Eye-witnes, and having oon after ome occaion to pas near the Place in the Countrey where I then reided, was pleas'd to give me a viit, and a rational account of the main things I deired to know; and when I inquired about his method of Cure, after he had told me that he had twice had the Plague himelf, whereof he hewed me ome effects; he added, that after many and various trials, he perceiv'd that abundance of his Patients died, after the Bubos, (Carbuncles) or Petilential Tumours appear'd; becaue upon a little refrigeration of the Body by the Air, and oftentimes by the very fear that diheartened the Patient, the Tumours would uddenly ubide, and the Petilential Matter recoiling upon the Vital Parts, would quickly dipatch the fatal work. Wherefore he bethought himelf of
a method, by means of which he aur'd me, he had not lot one Patient of very many he treated; if he could but, as he uually did, by good Alexipharmical, and Cordial Remedies, enable and excite Nature to expell the peccant Matter into a Tumour; for then he preently clapp'd on an appropriated drawing Plater, which would never uffer the Tumour to ubide; but break it, or make it fit for opening, and thereby give Nature a convenient vent, at which to dicharge the matter that oppres'd her. This Plater 'twill eaily be thought I was deirous to know; and he told me 'twas a Chymical one, and that 'twas no other than the Magnes Arenicalis of Angelus ala, whoe decription, becaue the Book wherein 'tis found, is in few hands, I have here annext. If this prove as uccesfull in other Plagues, as it did to thoe that us'd it in that of London; there will be jut caue to admire and praie the benignity of Divine
Providence, which in a poionous Mineral, that probably does oftentimes concur to produce the Plague, has laid up a remedy for it.

U.U: iii. Terebinthinae coctae, cerae virginis ana ivs. Magnetis Arenicalis ubtiliter pulveriati ii. radic' Aronis pulveriat' i. Gummi depurentur cum aceto cyllitico, & ad conitentiam Emplatri coquantur, & potea ponderentur, deinde cum rebus aliis fiat Emplatrum lege artis, hoc Emplatro Carbunculus obducatur, quod paucis horis venenum extrahit.

U.hi: Arenici Chrytallini, ulphuris vitri, antimonii crudi ana, haec tria in mortario ferreo pulverientur, in vae

fortiimo vitreo, ponantur ad ignem arenae donec vitrum optimè incalccat, & praedicta olvantur & liquentur intar picis, quod obervabitur quando filum quoddam immittitur in fundum quod extractum potea intar Terebinthinae trahetur ubi atis coctum erit, potea remove vitrum ab igne, & ubi refrigeratum et rumpe, & ubtiliter pulveria, & ad uum erva.

div.p:
By the ame motive (Philanthropy) I am induc'd to add on this occaion, that having had ome opportunity to oblige an ancient and very experienc'd Phyician, to whoe care was committed a great Pethoue, where the Contagion was o trong, that he lot three Phyicians that were to be Aitants to him, and three Chirurgeons of four that were to be ubervient to him; I diir'd to learn of him, if he counted it not too great a ecret, what Antidote he us'd to preerve himelf from o violent and fatal an Infection. This requet
he readily granted, but withall told me, that his method would not eem to me worth mentioning, if I were one that valu'd Medicines by their Pompounes, not their Utility. For, beides ardent Prayers to God, and a very regular Diet, his contant Antidote was onely, to take every Morning fating a little Sea-alt diolv'd in a few poonfulls of fair Water; which he made choice of, both becaue it kept his Body oluble without purging or weakning it, and for other Reaons which I mut not now tay to et down. I know this Medicine may appear a depicable one; but yet in my Opinion it ought not to be depis'd, after uch Experience as I have related has recommended it. For I think it deirable, that notice be taken of all Remedies, that have been found by good Trials, not bare Conjectures or uncertain Reports, available againt the Plague. For, ince Petilences, as we have lately noted, are exceeding various
in their kinds, 'tis very poible, and not unlikely, that their Appropriated Remedies may be o too. And therefore I would not eaily lay aide every Medicine, that this or that Learned Phyician may peak lightly of, or even may declare that he has found it unuccesfull againt the Plague; ince the ame Medicine may be available in a Petilence of another kind, in which perhaps the Remedies commended by the Phyician we peak of, will be found inefficacious.

This Conideration forbids me to pas by what happen'd to me in the great London Plague above-mention'd; namely, that a very Learned Phyician having once recommended to me an Herb little noted in England, as a mot effectual and experienced Antidote againt the Plague, I caus'd it to be cultivated in a Garden (as I till do every year;) and when the Petilence raged mot, having ome of it by me, made up with a little Sugar in the
form of a fine green Conerve, I ent it to two infected Perons, who, by the Divine Benediction on it, both of them recover'd. But having made but thoe two Trials, I dare not ground much upon them onely; though I uually keep the Plant growing in a Garden, partly becaue both the Tate and Colour; one or other of which in mot Antidotes is offenive, are in this pleaant; and partly becaue ome little Experience has invited me to believe the Commendations that I have found given of it, againt the Bitings of venomous Creatures: whereof I remember a notable Intance is recorded by Petrus Spehrerius of aIn Obervat. nobil. apud Schenkium, l. 7. Oberv. Med. Tit. de venenis ex animalibus. Roman, who having with his Staff pierc'd or cruh'd a Viper, that he took to be dead, had o trong a Venom tranmitted along the Staff, that the inuing Night he had a very great Inflammation in both his Lips, to
which uperven'd an exceeding Ardent Fever and trange Tortures; from all which Serianus Pacyonius, a noted Phyician that was call'd to him, free'd him as it were by Miracle, by the Juice of Goats-rue, or as others call it Galega, that grew copiouly in that Place. It may without digut be taken omewhat plentifully, (and o it ought to be) in its entire ubtance as a Salad; or ele one may give its Conerve, its Syrup, or, which is better, its Juice newly expres'd.

(3.) It likewie agrees with our Hypotheis; that ometimes the Plague ceaes, or at leat very notably abates of its Infectiounes and Malignity, in far les time than according to the wonted coure of that ravenous Dieae, Phyicians did, or rationally could expect. For ometimes it may happen, that, though the Temperature or Intemperatenes of the Air continues the ame, the matter that afforded the Petiferous Exhalations may be either
pent under ground, or o alter'd by combination with other ubterraneal Bodies, or by ome of thoe many Accidents that may happen, altogether unknown to us, in thoe deep and dark Recees. And if once the Fountain of thee noxious Effluvia be topt, o that thoe that are in the Air ceae to be recruited, the Wind and other caues may in a hort time diipate them, or at leat dilute them with innocent Air, o far, as to keep the Dieae they produc'd from being any thing near o michievous as before. And here I conider, that it may everal times happen, that, though the Minerals that emit the hurtfull Expirations, remain where they were under ground, and be not coniderably wated, yet their fatal Effects may not be lating, becaue the Effluvia were generated by the conflict of two or more of them, which vehemently agitated one another, and ent up fumes, which ceas'd to acend, at leat in great plenty, when
the Conflict and Agitation ceas'd. As, I have try'd that by putting good Spirit of Salt upon Filings of Steel or Iron in a conveniently hap'd Glas, there will be made a great conflict between them, and without the help of external Heat, there will be ent up into the Air tore of viible Fumes of a very Sulphureous Odour, and eaily inflammable, which copious elevation of Fumes will leen or ceae, as does the tumultuous agitation that produc'd them. And o likewie, if you pour Aqua fortis upon a convenient proportion of Salt of Tartar, there will be at firt a great ebullition produc'd, and, whilt that continues, tore of red and noiome Fumes will be elevated, but will not long outlat the commotion of the mixture, whoe active parts will in no long time combine into a kind of nitrous Salt, wherein the noxious parts of the Mentruum are as it were pinion'd, and hinder'd from evaporating or acending, though really
they retain much of their pritine nature, as I elewhere hew.

It may alo happen, that oon after that commotion of ubterraneal Matter, which ent forth petiferous Exhalations, a more intene degree of ubterraneal Heat, or perhaps the ame latent Fire, extending it elf farther and farther, may force up Fumes of another ort, that being of a contrary nature, may be, if I may o peak, antidotal againt the former; and by precipitating them, or combining with them, may diable them from acting o michievouly as otherwie they would. To countenance which I hall tell you, that I have ometimes purpoely made Ditillations, in which one part of the Matter being, after the operation ended, put to the other, there will enue a udden and manifet conflict between them, and ometimes an intene degree of Heat. And that mineral Exhalations, though otherwie not wholeome, may diable petiferous Effluvia,
may be gather'd from what I lately noted about a Countrey, which abounding with veins of Cinnabar, was, probably by their expirations, preerved from the Petilence. And our Hypotheis will perhaps appear omewhat the more probable, if we reflect on what I lately mention'd of the udden check, that is almot every Summer given to the Plague, which at that time is wont to reign at Grand Cairo. For ince 'tis generally oberv'd and complain'd of, that Morbifick Caues doe their work much more effectually than Sanative ones. It eems very probable that Exhalations acending from under-ground into the Atmophere, may be capable of producing petilential Fevers, and the Plague it elf, ince thoe Corpucles that impregnate the Egyptian Air upon the welling of the Nile, are able to put a peedy top, not onely to the contagiounes, but to the malignity of the Plague, even when 'tis aited by the Summer
Heat, which at Grand Cairo is wont to be exceive.

But having inited perhaps too long on this Egyptian Petilence, I hall onely add, by way of Illutration of the Conjecture that invited me to mention it, that the acceion even of Expirations that are not themelves wholome, may ometimes erve to correct the Air, and put a udden check to an Epidemical Dieae. For Corpucles of differing kinds may by their Coalitions acquire new Qualities, and each ort of them loe ome of thoe they had before: as, uppoe there wander'd in the Air a great many Effluvia, which by their determinate hape and bulk were apt to corrode or irritate the Lungs, or the Membranes of the Brain, &c. as thoe of Nitre are to corrode Silver; it may happen that another ort of Reeks, though in their own nature unwholome, may, by aociating themelves with the firt ort, and compoing with them Curpucles of
new qualities, abolih or much weaken the noxious ones they had before, in reference to this or that part of the Humane Body. Though the Spirits of Salt-peter will readily corrode Silver, yet if you add to them (as for ome purpoes I am wont to do) about half as much or les of the pirituous Particles of common Salt, (which yet are corroive enough, and will fret aunder the parts of Iron, Copper, Antimony, &c.) there will emerge a Body that will not at all corrode pure Silver.

div.head: PROPOSITION IV.

p.hi: Tis very probable, that mot of the Dieaes that even Phyicians call New ones, are caus'd either chiefly or concurrently by Subterraneal Steams.

div.p: THE Product of my firt Endeavours to bring credit to the foregoing Propoition, appearing to have micarry'd, when I came to end to the Pres the things I had written about it; that at leat what can be preerv'd of it may not be lot, I hall ubtitute in tead of it the following Account.

At the entrance of my Dicoure I oberv'd that the Term new Dieae was much abued by the Vulgar, who are wont to give that Title to almot every Fever, that, in Autumn epecially, varies a little in its Symptoms, or other Circumtances, from the Fevers of the foregoing
Year or Seaon. And therefore I declared, that by new Dieaes I meant onely uch, whoe Symptoms were o uncommon, that Phyicians themelves judged them to deerve that appellation; Such, for intance, as the Sudor Anglicus or Sweating Sicknes; that Dieae which the learned Wierus and others call in Dutch Die Varen; an unheard-of Dieae decrib'd by Roneius, that in the Year 1581 invaded and detroy'd many in the Dukedom of Lunenburg; to which many Phyicians add the Rickets, and others generally the Lues Venerea. Having clear'd the Terms, I next conider'd whether there were really any new Dieaes properly o call'd, and gave ome reaons to upect that ome Dieaes, which among Phyicians themelves have pas'd for New, were extant before in rerum natura, though not in the Countrey wherein even the learned judg'd them to be new. And I intimated, that to examine this Supicion throughly, 'tis not afe
to acquiece in the Books of Phyicians onely; but 'tis fit to conult the Writings of Geographers, whether ancient (among whom I particularly recommended Strabo) or Modern, together with the Relations of Hitorians, Navigators and other Travellers. And here I inquired, without determining any thing, whether the Lues Venerea be, as mot Phyicians are wont to uppoe a Dieae wholly new, or onely new to our European World, and brought hither from ome African or other remote Region, where it may be probably upected to have long been Endemical.

But taking it for granted, with the generality of Phyicians, that ome new Dieaes are to be admitted; I advanced to conider ome of the Caues, to which they may be imputed; And to give ome reaons, why I do'nt acquiece in their Opinion, though very general, that derive them onely or chiefly from the varying influences of the Heavenly
Bodies. For the mot powerfull of thoe, namely the Sun and Moon, act in too general and indeterminate a way, to afford a ufficient account of this affair. And as for the other Lights, the fixt Stars, beides their being univeral and indefinite agents, their carce meaurable remotenes makes it jutly quetionable, whether they have any enible Operation upon any part of our Bodies, ave our Eyes. And, though I deny not that great intemperatenes of the Air, as to the four firt Qualities, as Heat, Cold, Drines and Moiture, are wont (not over jutly) to be call'd, may dipoe mens Bodies to everal great Ditempers, and may alo be concurrent caues of thoe we are peaking of: yet neither can I acquiece in thee, when I conider how much more frequently they happen, than new Dieaes do; and that their action, though various, is too general and indeterminate to perwade me, that they can be the adequate caues of effects o rare and
anomalous as Dieaes odd enough to deerve the Title of new.

But now; the Subterranean Region of our Globe, beides that it is always near us, abounds with variety of noxious Minerals, and probably conceals great quantities of differing orts of them, that are yet unknown to us. AndA Dicoure of Subterraneal Steams as they affect the Air. ince we have elewhere proved, that there want not caues in the Bowels of the Earth, to make great and irregular, and Sometimes udden Confluxes, Conflicts, Diipations, and other coniderable Changes, amongt the Materials, that nature has plentifully treaured up in thoe her ecret Magazins. And ince, in making out the three former Propoitions, we have manifeted, that the Subterraneal parts of the Globe we inhabit, may plentifully end up Noxious Effluvia of everal kinds into the Air; it ought not to eem improbable that among this Emergent variety of Exotick and hurtfull
Steams, ome may be found capable to diaffect Humane Bodies, after a very uncommon way, and thereby to produce new Dieaes; whoe duration may be greater or maller, according to the latingnes of thoe Subterraneal caues, that produce them. On which account it need be no wonder, that ome new Dieaes have but a hort duration, and vanih not long after, there appearing the Source or Fomes of the Morbifick Effluvia, being oon detroy'd, or pent: whereas ome others may continue longer upon the Stage, as having under ground more ettled and durable caues to maintain them. Which lat part of the Obervation may be illutrated by what happen'd in Calabria; which Province, though it have been oberved to have acquired, within thee two or three ages, the faculty of producing Manna upon certain Trees C. Magnenus de Manna, cap. 9. Dic amabo, Altomari, cur ante trecentos annos nullum Manna fuit in Oenotria; jam certé aderant Pagi ibidem urbéque vicinae neque fefelliet curioam Incolarum olertiam. &c. 15. ante 240. annos nullum Mannae Calabreais in Autoribus vetigium et. ; yet this great change, though udden enough, had
it eems uch table caues, as well as of great extent, that it hath lated everal cores of years, and continues in that Countrey to this day.

I am not ignorant that the whole Doctrine propounded in the four Propoitions about the Inalubrity of the Air, is not at all comfortable either to Patients or Phyicians: But important Theories deerv'd to be inquir'd into, and, if true, to be deliver'd though we could wih they were untrue. And judicious men rather thank than blame thoe that have given us account of latent or unupected, though perhaps irremediable caues of Dieaes and of death; or have recorded the Hitories of ome Poyons, whereof the true Antidotes are yet unknown. Uncommon Notions about Dieaes may erve to inlarge the Phyicians mind and excite his attention and curioity: and, beides that they may keep
him from too obtinately periting in the ue of receiv'd Medicins, though unuccesfull, upon a Suppoition that the Dieae can have no other caues, than thoe wont to be aign'd it by Claick Authours: beides this, I ay; I do not depair, but that either the agacity or fortune of this inquiitive age, or at leat of Poterity, may by the bleing of God be happy enough to find proper Remedies, even for thoe Dieaes that proceed from Subterranean Effluvia, when once by proper Signs they hall be ditinctly dicover'd; (Of which power of appropriated Remedies) I have known ome Intances, as to the very bad Symptoms produc'd by Antimonial and ome other Mineral Fumes.

Some of the Points dicours'd of under the fourth Propoition, were of affinity enough to Paradoxes to have need of being illutrated or confirmed by Obervations and Experiments. And therefore having accidentally retriev'd ome of this
lat nam'd ort, I hall venture to ubjoin them as a Specimen, though without Tranitions or Applications, but jut as I found them thrown together, in one looe heet, wherein I lighted on them. But it is time to conclude with the recital of the promied Experiments. Which I would immediately do, but that I hold it fit to premie, by way of Introduction to them, that I hope the Things hitherto dicours'd will appear much the more probable, if we hall prove by Experiments, that which eems much les likely than any thing we have above deliver'd; namely, that Metals completely formed and malleable may be elevated into the Air, and that perhaps without any great violence of Fire, in the form of Exhalations and Vapours; the ingly inviible Corpucles till retaining their Metalline nature. This at leat, as to ome Metals, I have endeavour'd to prove in another Tract, [entitl'd a Paradox about the Fuel of Flames.] But becaue that
Dicoure was never publih'd I will here et down two or three Experiments, (not mention'd, that I remember in it.) Which I do, the more willingly, becaue it may be a Thing of no mall moment in Phyick, if it be hewn that Fixt and olid Bodies, uch as Metals are, may by art be reduc'd into uch minute Corpucles, that without looing their nature and all their Properties, they may become parts of Fumes, or perhaps of inviible Vapours, or even of Flame it elf.

div.head: Particulars belonging to the IVth Propoition.
EXPER. I.
div.p:
WE took three Parts or Pounds of Dantic Vitriol (which is blew and omewhat partakes of Copper) and two Parts or Pounds of good Sea-alt; thee being very well
powder'd and mix'd were ditill'd with a trong naked Fire, to force out all that could be driven over: and by this means we not onely obtain'd a Spirit of Salt of a manifetly blewih Colour, but there acended alo a coniderable quantity of Powder, which being haken with the Liquor, ettled at the bottom of it in the form of a Powder, which was judg'd to conit of Corpucles of a Cupreous nature, and perhaps alo of ome of a Martial nature. But I unhappily neglected the opportunity of examining this Powder, which came up in quantity enough to have erv'd for various Trials.

div.head: EXPER. II.
div.p:
By ubtituting Englih Vitriol (which is green, and is much more abundant in Iron than that of Dantic,) and proceeding in other repects as in the former Proces, we obtain'd a very yellow Spirit, with
a coniderable quantity of a yellowih Powder, that was gues'd to be a kind of Crocus Martis.

div.head: EXPER. III.
div.p:
We took very thin Plates of Copper, and cat them into a Retort, upon an equal or a double weight (for we did not always ue the ame) of good Mercury Sublimate; and luting on the Receiver, gave a Fire by degrees for everal hours: by which means we uually obtain'd ome running Mercury, (which eemed to be very well purifi'd and was perhaps alo impregnated) together with ome Sublimate that had not faten'd upon the Copper. And at the bottom of the Retort we had good tore of a ponderous and brittle ubtance, that did not look at all like a Metal, but rather like omething of a Gummous or Reinous nature, being alo fuible and inflammable almot like ealing Wax. This, having not opportunity to
proecute the Experiment at home, I put into the hands of an indutrious Phyician, that was earnet with me to impart to him the Proces, and let Him purue it for me. He according to my direction expos'd this Metalline Roin (if I may o call it) grosly beaten to the free Air, where it did, according to Expectation, in a hort time change Colour, and turn to a kind of Verdegreece: which being diolv'd in good Spirit of Salt gave a Solution of a very lovely green Colour. This being lowly ditill'd ad Siccitatem, yielded but a very weak and phlegmatick Liquour; and the Caput Mortuum was again diolv'd in freh Spirit, and the Mentruum abtracted as before. This was done everal times, till the matter was o impregnated, that the Mentruum being drawn off from it, came over as trong almot as when it was put on. This done, the thus impregnated Verdegreece was diligently mingl'd with Tripoly, or ome uch inipid and fixt additament,
and ditill'd with a trong Fire; by which means it afforded good tore of a Liquour Colourles like common Water: which made the Phyician uppoe the Experiment had micarry'd, till I having dropt into it a Colourles Liquor, namely Spirit of Hartshorn or of Sal-armoniac; He was much and delightfully urpriz'd, to find it preently dicloe a deep and lovely blew Colour. What afterwards became of this odd Spirit, I need not here declare; what has been aid being ufficient, to hew that Corpucles of Copper may be elevated in the form of Exhalations both transparent and Colourles. The next following Experiment though in part mention'd by ome Chymit is here ubjoin'd, becaue it's neceary and applied to a particular purpoe.

div.head: EXPER. IV.
div.p:
If from good Cornih Tin you warily ditill an equal or double weight of Venetian Sublimate, into a very large Receiver very well luted on to the Retort, you will obtain a pirituous Liquor, which as oon as the free Air comes to touch it, will end up abundance of white Exhalations in the form of a thick Smoak, which will continue to be emitted much longer than one would imagine. But that which I deire to have particularly oberv'd in this Experiment is, that though this Liquor be thus apt to emit Smoak, not onely plentifully, but as one would think with Violence, yet I found by Trial, that even when I put it into a Veel not trait mouth'd, if I did but lay a piece of a ingle leaf of Paper flatwie upon the Orifice of the Glas, o as to cover it all, the viible production of the Fumes would preently ceae; and the Liquor would lie
like common Water, as long as the Paper lay, though but lightly upon the Glas; though upon the Removal of that, the Liquor would end up plentifull Fumes as before, which eems to argue, that ome Metalline Subtances may, by the contact of the Air, have their Copious acenion into the Atmophere very much help'd and promoted, as if the Air had Saline or other ort of Particles in it, that are in reference to ome Mineral Bodies of a very volatilizing nature. The way by which I have divers times elevated the Fixedt of Metals, Gold it elf, I have deliver'd in another Paper, and hall not here repeat it. But I hall now et down an Experiment that when it is carefully made, is eaie to be perform'd, and yet affords a notable and enible Proof, that the Corpucles of a Metal may be made to acend, and that plentifully, even with a very moderate Heat, under the form of ordinary Fumes or Smoak.
To effect this I devis'd the following Experiment.

We took Copper and diolv'd it in good Aqua fortis, till the Mentruum was Satiated with it, in the trong Solution we teep'd a while ome brown or other porous Paper, that being fitter than the finer, to oak up the Mentruum; then lowly evaporating the uperfluous moiture, we put a quantity of this imperfectly dry'd Paper upon the Hearth, at uch a ditance from a Fire of actually flaming Wood that the Paper was not kindled, but yet was o corch'd, as to afford very plentifull Fumes: thee look'd like ordinary Smoak, whilt they mov'd through the Air, and would quetionles have mingl'd with it, and been dipers'd through it, if the Body that emitted them had not been purpoely plac'd for a future deign. But when the motion of the Air towards the Flame had carry'd thee Fumes
to it, the Metalline Smoak did, as I expected, dicloe its nature; for being actually kindled, it ting'd the Flame of a lovely Colour, for the mot part Blew, and ometimes Green, as it happen'd to be variouly mix'd with the Flame and Smoak of the Wood.

div.head: A Short Supplement TO THE ESSAY OF THE GREAT EFFECTS OF Even Languid and nheeded LOCAL MOTION.
div.p:
THAT I may not be altogether wanting to the Expectation that may have been rais'd, by a Paage in the Advertiement prefix'd to the foregoing Eay; I hall here ubjoin ome Particulars, which perhaps will not be unwelcome to the Readers, that occurr'd to my remembrance, whilt I was,
with a tranient Eye, reviewing the Heads of the pat Dicoure. But thee Paralipomena or Supplements will be but few, not onely becaue of my want of leaure to review the Tract they belong to deliberately, but alo becaue ome Intances, that might be here ubjoin'd, may be more opportunely brought in in other Papers.

div.head: To the IIId. Chapter.
To the Vth. Chapter.
div.p:
On a udden the fatal Famian. Strad. de Bello Belg. Dec. 2. lib. 6, vel 7. Ship burt, with uch a horrid crah, as if the very Sky had rent aunder, Heaven and Earth had charg'd one another, and the whole Machine of the Earth it elf had quaked. For the Storm of Stones, Chains and Bullets being cat out with Thunder and Lightning, there followed uch a Slaughter, as no man, but that actually it happen'd, could have imagin'd. The Catle on which the Internal Ship fell, the Pile-work of the Bridge to St. Mary's Fort, that part of the Naval Bridge next the Catle, Souldiers, Mariners, Commanders, a great number of Cannons, Armour and Arms; all thee this furious Whirlwind wept away together, toed in the Air, and dipert as Wind doth Leaves of Trees. The Scheldt prodigiouly gaping was firt een to dicover its bottom, then welling above the Banks, was even
with the Rampiers, and overflowed St. Mary's Fort above a foot. The motion of the panting Earth N. B. extended its force and fear above nine Miles. [If he means the Miles of that Countrey, or Dutch Leagues, they amount to 36 Englih Miles.] There were found Stones, and that very great ones, as Grave-tones, and the like, a Mile off the River, truck into the Ground, in ome places four Palms.

div.head: To the VIth. Chapter.
Obervation I.
div.p:
WHAT is delivered in this Chapter about the Operation of Sounds and Animals, particularly that which is mention'd (Pag. 72.) about the Effect of Muick upon Serpents at Grand Cairo, may be not onely confirm'd but exceeded, by a trange Relation that I had from a Peron of unupected Credit
Which Narrative having appear'd to me o coniderable, as well to deerve a place among my Adveraria, I hall ubjoin that part of it which concerns our preent Subject, in the words wherein I find it et down.

Sir J. C. a very candid and judicious Traveller, favouring me yeterday with a viit, told me among other remarkable things relating to the Eat Indies, (which Countries He had curiouly viited) that He with divers European Merchants had een, (and that if I mitake not, everal times) an Indian, who by many was thought to be a Magician, that kept tame Serpents of a great bulk.
