And that when the Owner of them plaid upon a Muical Intrument, thee Serpents would raie themelves upright into the Air, leaving upon the Ground but 3 or 4 Inches of their Tail, upon which they lean'd for their upport. He added, that at the ame time that they erected their Bodies, they alo tretcht
and lengthen'd them in a trange and frightfull manner; and whilt they were thus lender, they were taller than He or any man of ordinary tature. But that which appear'd to Him the mot wonderfull and urpriing, was, that they manifetly eem'd to be very much affected with the Muick they heard; inomuch that ome Parts of the Tune would make them move to and fro with a urpriing agility, and ome other Parts of it would cat them into a Poture, wherein they eem'd to be half aleep, and as it were to melt away with pleaure.

div.head: To the VIth. Chapter. Pag. 75.
Obervation II.
div.p:
BEcaue the Truth even of the principal effects of the Biting of the Tarantula, has of late been publickly call'd in quetion, I was glad to meet with an ingenious Traveller,
that in Calabria or Apulia was Himelf bitten by one of thoe venomous Inects; and though it were but lightly, yet the Effects He felt in His own Body, and thoe greater ones He aw produc'd in other Perons, that were more unhappily bitten, brought Credit to the main of what ober Writers affirm of the Symptoms and Cure of that Poyon. And the learned, &c.

div.head: To the VIIth. Chapter. Pag. 83.
div.p:
MUCH of what is delivered in this Chapter and elewhere, about the Operation of Air or inviible Fluids (whoe Motions affect not the Touch) upon Congruous Solids, may be confirm'd by that notable Experiment, which has been publihed in an Elegant Dicoure by the learned Morhofius; about a Dutch Wine Seller in Amterdam, by name Nicolaus Petterus, who, having found the Tone or Note peculiarly
belonging to a large belly'd drinking Glas, Such as the Dutch call Römer, and many here call Rhenih Wine Glaes, would, by accommodating his voice exactly to that Tone, and yet making it loud and lating, make the Veel, though not viibly touched, firt tremble and then burt; which it would not do, if the Voice were, though but a little, too low or too high. This notable Experiment has been een by many Vertuoi, both before and ince he publih'd it. And the very ingenious Writer, as he paed through London, not onely related it to me, but very civily offer'd me farther atisfaction, if I could furnih Him with a Römer, which I was very orry that where we then were was not to be procur'd.

div.head: To the VIIIth. Chapter.
Obervation I.
div.p: IT may add probability to ome things deliver'd in this Chapter and in divers other Paages of this Treatie, if I here recount a trange Phoenomenon, that came into my memory whilt I was running over thoe Parts of this Dicoure.

The Phoenomenon, in hort, was this. Having met with divers pieces of tranparent Glas, which I had reaon to think to be of a Texture or Temper very differing from ordinary Glas, I thought fit to try, whether ome of them were not far more pringy and brittle than their thicknes would make one expect. And accordingly, though I found everal wherein the Experiment would not ucceed, epecially if their figure were not convenient, yet with ome others, I had very good ucces, and
particularly with ome that were hap'd almot like the harper End of the neck of a Retort. For though thee pieces of Glas were much thicker than uch necks are wont to be, being perhaps 6 or 7 times as thick as common drinking Glaes, yet I more than once made the Tryal ucceed o well, that, by obliquely cratching them, or tickling them if I may o peak, on the inide with the head or point of a Pin, they would forceably burt into many pieces in my hand. In which urprizing Phoenomenon, the matter of the Glas eem'd to contribute omething to this odd Effect, of o languid a motion, but much les than the Texture, or Tenion, it obtain'd by the peculiar way of ordering it in the Fire and the Air.

div.head: To the VIIIth. Chapter.
Obervation II.
div.p: TO hew that the Supicion I mention my elf, a little before the end of this Chapter, to have had, that the breaking of the Stones there poken of might poibly be produc'd or promoted by ome impreions, remaining after the trokes employ'd to force the Stones out of their Beds, was not altogether without ground.

I hall here oberve, that it need not eem incredible, that faint trokes and attritions may leave more lating and operative Motions among the Inenible Parts, even of compact and olid Bodies, than one would readily imagine. For I have everal times found, ometimes by Obervations deignedly made, and ometimes by undeigned Accidents, that, having caus'd omewhat thin Veels of Glas, epecially Urinals, to be diligently
made clean with Sand mixt with Water, to looen or grate off the foulnes that adher'd to the ides of the Veel; though the Veels, after having been thus made clean, did not appear to have receiv'd the leat injury, and would continue very intire perhaps for everal hours, yet after that time they would of themelves break with noie, and thereby become unerviceable for the future. But though this happen'd to many Urinals, yet, becaue to more others it did not, it eem'd probable that the diilition depended chiefly upon the peculiar texture of the Glas in this or that Veel, whether acquir'd by a mixture of the Ingredients, that was not uniform enough or made in a due proportion; or ele by the too haty refrigeration of the Veel, epecially if it chanc'd, as is not very unuual, to be cool'd more hatily in one part than another.

div.head: To the IXth. Chapter. Pag. 110.
Obervation I.
div.p:
BEcaue there are divers Gems; particularly thoe Tranparent ones that are Red or Blew, that are much harder than Iron or teel, it may much trengthen the Proof of our 8th Obervation, if I here relate that a Jeweller to a great Princes anwer'd me, that when he polih'd Saphyrs, Rubies, and ome orts of other hard Gems, upon his Mill, they would eem when attrition had made them very hot, to be all on Fire, like o many little Coals: And that each of them had the light it afforded ting'd with a Colour proper to the Stone; o that the Ruby gave a Red Light, the Saphyr a Blew, &c. And I remember that inquiring of a skilfull Cutter of Diamonds and Poliher of Gems, whoe Cutomer I had been, about ome Conjectures I had concerning things belonging to his Profeion, he
anwer'd me that ometimes, when he polih'd certain Stones, epecially Rubies, that were pretty large and perhaps not thick, he could plainly perceive that the Stone gap'd at and near the Edge, as if it were begun to be crack'd; which ign admonihed him to make hate to lacken the Motion of the Mill, let the Stone hould abolutely burt; which if it did not he could not perceive any Flaw in it when it was throughly cold, but, which was trange, it appear'd as entire as ever. He added, in confirmation of what he had aid of the intene Heat that Gems would ometimes acquire by Attrition, whilt they were in polihing, that having lately given by this means too great a degree of Heat, to an Oriental Topaz (which ort of that Gem is very hard,) it crack'd upon the Mill, in o much that one part of it quite eparated from the ret, and poil'd the Stone in the capacity of a Gem; as a Proof whereof he had laid it aide for me, and would needs make me accept it, as
a curious, though not an uefull, thing.

div.head: To the IXth Chapter.
Obervation II.
div.p:
TO confirm what has been aid in the 8th Obervation, to hew that low and inenible Intetine Motions of the Parts of a Body that eem quiecent, may be very operative, chance afforded me a notable Intance, which was this. I had, to preerve a Liquor from which I expected a curious Experiment, inclos'd it in a trong Vial, to whoe neck a thick Glas Stople was but too exquiitely adapted. This Veel I et upon the Edge of a Window, in a high and ecure place, that it might not be mov'd. There it continu'd many Months, or, if I miremember not, above a Year. And the Liquor was of uch a nature, that if any Body had, though but for a few Moments,
taken out the Stople, I could eaily dicover it. But after all this while, one day that I was itting in my Cloet, at a good ditance from the place in which the Vial tood, I heard a loud and brisk noie, almot like the report of a Pitol, and then perceiv'd that omething came rolling to my Feet: I hatily took it up, and, found it to be the thicker and larger part of the Stople of my Vial, which of it elf had flown off, leaving the remaining part o cloely and trongly adjuted to the Neck, which erv'd it for a kind of Socket, that I could by no means pull it out thence. At this Accident I was not a little urpriz'd, conidering the thicknes of the Solid Glas, and that it had tood o long unmov'd, and that the bigger and heavier part of the Stople broke off from the other with uch violence, and was carry'd from it by inviible motors to o great a ditance. Which eem'd the more trange, becaue there was no haking nor treading in the Room, that
could put the parts of the Glas into Motion, there being no Body preent but my elf, who was itting quietly and tudying.

div.head: To the IXth Chapter.
Obervation III.
div.p:
TO confirm what I have in the eighth Obervation and elewhere deliver'd about the latent Motion of Parts that may be in a Body not onely quiecent but olid, I hall here add a trange Intance, which was afforded me by a Diamond, belonging to an ingenious Merchant of that ort of Gems, who brought many fine ones out of the Eat Indies. For having at the Diamond-Mine it elf, purchas'd amongt other Stones that grew there, a rough Diamond that he valued at about a hundred pound, and had well conidered when he bought it; coming to look over his purchae again once
more, about Ten Days or a Fortnight after, he was much urpriz'd to find, to his great los, that this Diamond had of it elf crack'd in everal places, and o became of little or no value, but as 'twas a Rarity: and indeed I could not without wonder, ee o fair and hard a Stone o oddly poil'd with Clefts, that eem'd to penetrate o very deep, that 'twas gues'd 'twould not be very difficult to pull the parts of the Stone aunder. And on this occaion he told me, that he had admir'd this Accident at firt, much more than he did afterwards. For complaining of it to divers Merchants and Jewellers, that he met with in thoe Parts; he was told, that, though it eldom happen, yet 'twas no uch wonderfull Accident; The like misfortune having befallen others as well as him.

div.head: A Potcript.
div.p: THAT every common Reader may undertand whatever is contain'd in the foregoing Treaties, the Publiher thought fit to englih the Latin Paages that are not tranlated by the Authour.

div.head: I. Tract I. Page 21.
div.p:
Simon Pauli, in his ingenious Treatie of Petilential Fevers, p. 71. tells us of a ick Frenchman, who liv'd everal days after his Arm was cut off, though he was all the while mot cruelly tortur'd by not ordinary Convulion
Fits: But what is mot obervable is this that I and others itting one day by his Bed-ide, but not taking notice that the great Guns were going off from the King's Ships, he laying hold, and cherihing the Stump of his Right Arm, broke out at every hot into thee pitifull words: Jeus Maria, What do I not uffer! I am quite bruis'd; o troubleome, and inufferable to him was the hooting of the great Guns, though at a great ditance, they being, fired not in a joining Continent, but on the Balthick-ea.

div.head: II.
div.p: Platerus in the Firt Book of his Obervations, p. 185. gives us this following Account, p. 26.

A Woman being fallen ick on a udden complain'd continually of her being trangled, though there was no great appearance thereof; this he acribed chiefly to a certain Air, or Wind, which he was o enible of,
that if any Body happen'd to come near her, he would immediately complain of her being choak'd, and died the econd day of this odd Ditemper: To which he adds, I have known everal others complain of a not unlike Wind, and that they were in danger of being choak'd, if any body came near 'em: which I conceiv'd always to be a very ill ign.

div.head: III. Page 57.
div.p: If you throw down an Animal into the hole of Viburg, which is in Carelia, a Countrey in Scandia, 'tis reported that there breaketh immediately forth a great and inufferable ound, together with a trong wind: if a mall weight be thrown into the Gap of Dalmatia, though, ays Plinius, in a calm day, there is a torm immediately rais'd not unlike that which is occaion'd by a Whirlwind. Agricola de Natura eorum quae effl. è terra, l. 4. c. 7.

p.hi: I dicharg'd a Pitol, being upon the top of the Hill, which at firt made no greater noie than that which uually happens at the breaking of a mall Rod: but after a little while the noie became tronger, and filled the lower parts of the Hill, the Valleys, and neighbouring Woods. Now coming down lower through Snow that had lain there everal years, and having dicharg'd again the Pitol, the noie became on a udden louder than that of the greatet Guns. Which gave me ome grounds to fear that the whole Hill, being thus haken, hould at length ubide: this ound lated half a quarter of an hour, till it had penetrated into the remotet Grotto's, whence the parts of the Air thruting one another had been trongly rever berated: and becaue no uch concavities were in the top of the Hill, the ound was firt inenibly reverberated, till
coming lower and nearer the Grotto's and Valleys it was trongly dah'd againt 'em.

div.head: V. Tract II. Page 48.
div.p: 'Tis worthy our admiration, ays Beguinus, that though in the Neighbourhood of Hydria, in the Countrey of Gloricia, where a great quantity of Mercury is found, the Pet almot every year rageth, yet it is always free from the Plague: and this was confirm'd to me by Perons of a very great Age, who aid they had receiv'd it from their Ancetours.

div.head: VI. An Attractive Petilential Plater. Page 84.
div.p:
Take of the Gums Sagapen, Ammoniac, Galbanum three ounces, of boil'd Turpentine, and Virgin-wax four ounces, and a half, of the Arenical Loadtone well pulveris'd two
ounces, of Arons Root pulveris'd anounce; let the Gums be depurated with the Vinegar of Squills, and boil'd to the conitency of a Plater, and latly weigh'd; then according to the uual method with other things make up a Plater: cover the Carbuncle with this Plater, and in a few hours it will draw out all the venom.

div.head: The true Preparation of the foremention'd Arenical Loadtone.
div.p:
Take equal parts of Crytal-arenick, of Sulphur of Glas, of Crude Antimony: bray them to powder in an Iron Mortar, et them in a trong Glas on a fire of Sand, till the Glas be very hot, and the foremention's Druggs melted like Pitch: which you hall know when having thrut a Thred into the bottom, the matter ticking to it does rope like Turpentine; which is a ign of its being well enough boil'd: remove then the Glas from the fire, and when it is cold break it; reduce
the matter into mall powder, and keep it for your ue.

div.head: A Paage belonging to the Supplement.
div.p:
Borel. de vi percuionis prop. CXI. has thee obervable words. I was at Tauromenium in Sicily when the Mountain of Aetna broke out near Enna, a Town ditant about thirty miles from Tauromenium; whilt the Gap did end out now and then with a great noie fire and flame all the Houes of Tauromenium were enibly haken: and it was obervable that uch Houes as look'd directly towards the Gap, were mot of all agitated. Thoe that look'd otherwie haking more lowly, upon which matter of fact he argues thus: had this trembling been occaion'd by the haking of the Ground of Tauromenium, all the Houes had been equally hak'd, ince this inequality of motion could not be acrib'd to their different ituation. Hence then
we mut needs conclude that this agitation was produc'd by the impreion of the Air upon the Walls of the Houes, which demontrates to us the great efficacy of a ound, though at thirty miles ditance.
